She said, too, that American women have fewer contraceptive options available to them than European women and women in many developing countries and that there is great need for research into treatment of infertility. ``Sexism in medical practices is a reality,'' Mrs. Schroeder said. ``For some women, there are fatal consequences.'' She said the women's issues caucus will propose legislation next month to bar the arbitrary exclusion of women from federally funded research.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Less than a month before Jane Pauley's prime-time program premieres on NBC, she still doesn't know what to call it. ``You know, my son was almost 4 years old before he got a name,'' she said in TV Guide's June 23 issue. ``I had a cat that was a year old before I gave him a name.'' She knows what she doesn't want to call it _ a newsmagazine. ``It's a news variety show,'' said Pauley, who quit the ``Today'' show earlier this year. An NBC prime-time news program by any name is a risky venture. The new show, premiering July 11, follows a host of short-lived newsmagazines. There was ``Prime Time Sunday,'' which became ``Prime Time Saturday'' before it was canceled, ``NBC Magazine,'' ``Monitor,'' ``Summer Sunday U.S.A.,'' which lasted two months, and the most recent failure, ``Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow.'' Pauley has a commitment from the network for five shows, which will run every two weeks through Sept. 5.

George Steinbrenner, the shipbuilding magnate and unpredictable owner of the New York Yankees, told graduating cadets at the Massachusetts Maritime Academy to dare to be different. ``Be the uncommon man and woman,'' Steinbrenner urged the 119 cadets Sunday. ``Don't worry too much about what you think society dictates, because it's the uncommon men of this country that have led it to greatness.'' Steinbrenner, who has hired 19 managers in the 17 years since he bought the Yankees, pressed the graduates to ``pursue excellence at all costs.'' ``There are those who will teach you that to win is a bad word,'' said the owner of the last-place ballclub. ``It's not a bad word, but if you prefer to say pursuit of excellence, that's OK.'' Steinbrenner was given a honorary doctorate ``in recognition of his service in the American maritime industry.'' He is president and chief executive of American Ship Building and Kinsman Marine Transit.

Bob Castleberry doesn't have to work anymore since winning $10 million in the Publishers Clearing House Sweepstakes, but he's putting in long hours in his new job as mayor. After winning the sweepstakes a year ago, Castleberry quit his sales job with a business forms company and sought the mayor's job in this city of about 50,000 people 35 miles from Dallas. Since his election in May, he said, ``I'm just having a great time!'' He attends meetings of every city board and commission _ not to talk, but to watch and learn, he said. ``I know people think I'm crazy, that I should be out somewhere traveling, taking a trip around the world, instead of coming down here to City Hall every day,'' Castleberry said in a recent interview. ``But I get bored with traveling and want to come home. This _ being mayor _ you feel as if you are helping people, helping to make Denton a better place to live.''

Throat problems have forced Madonna to cancel or reschedule the final U.S. shows of her ``Blond Ambition'' tour. The singer, who appears in the film ``Dick Tracy,'' which opened this weekend, has chronic laryngitis, Warner Bros. Records said Sunday. The June 19 concert at the Meadowlands was moved to June 25, and the June 23 show was canceled. Shows on June 20, 21, and 24 will go on as scheduled. Throat problems also forced the singer to cancel a Friday concert in Philadelphia. It was the third show canceled in the last three weeks by the singer, who started the tour six weeks ago.

NEW YORK _ Gloria Estefan of the Miami Sound Machine, who broke her back in a bus crash in March, says she had always feared becoming an invalid. ``I've had a premonition all my life that I would become a burden to the people I love,'' the 32-year-0ld singer said in the June 25 issue of People. ``That's why when we began building our house (in 1987), I had an elevator put in.'' Estefan said when she was lying in her tour bus after it was rear-ended by a tractor-trailer March 20, ``I thought, `Here it is. This is the thing I've been waiting for.''' The singer has been working out on exercise machines three times a week and has recovered to the point she can put on her shoes by herself. Although the recovery could take a year, Estefan said he is anxious to get back on stage ``and be better than before, to show people that their prayers were not wasted.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Talks Should Get Serious This Week
DOC.TEXT: Late this week, budget talks between the Bush administration and Congress should evolve from preliminary, technical discussions into hard bargaining with election-year politics and billions of dollars at stake. But none of the participants pretends to know what will happen. ``I wouldn't hazard a guess,'' said one, Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. ``These things can go on for so long, and then suddenly as if by magic you seem to reach a critical mass and then there's an agreement.'' After five weeks and eight private sessions, the Democratic and Republican sides agree that somewhere between $45 billion and $60 billion in new taxes and spending cuts are needed for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. Unless some deal is worked out by that date, the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law will force tens of billions of dollars worth of spending cuts, an amount both parties say is intolerable. Yet neither side is eager to be the first to lay a plan on the bargaining table at sessions continuing this week, and risk being accused of championing something that the voters might find dreadful. Among the battlegrounds: will Democrats have to swallow cuts in some of their favorite social programs? And will President Bush's campaign mantra of ``No new taxes'' become obsolete? Democrats say the bargaining can only begin with a concrete offer from Bush, who called for the talks early last month. ``I thought implicitly at the beginning that the administration would present a proposal here,'' Sasser said last week. But Republicans say there is no need for the White House to lay down a proposal, and it has no plans to do so. If Democrats continue to insist that Bush present a budget proposal, ``It would be clear at that point that the Democrats don't intend to work out an agreement,'' said a GOP bargainer, Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas. Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, a Republican negotiator who will retire from Congress this winter, said he might be willing to push a plan forward if no one else will. ``If they need a fall guy, and it's said that lame ducks are good at that kind of stuff, I wouldn't mind being put in that position,'' he said. But that's not likely to satisfy Democrats. ``We're not interested in hearing from Republican legislative members,'' said Sasser. ``That's not what it's all about. This is a negotiation between the executive and legislative branches.'' Contributing to the unpredictability of the talks is the schizophrenic outlooks of the Democratic and Republican teams. Each side has pragmatists like White House budget director Richard Darman and House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. They seem above all to want a deal that once and for all takes a bite out of the federal deficit, which some project could exceed $200 billion next year. But the two teams also have highly partisan members, such as Sasser and White House chief of staff John Sununu, who seem leery of agreeing to anything that might provide a campaign advantage to the other party. Bargainers say the litmus test for the talks will be whether they have accomplished anything by the start of Congress' July 4 recess. They argue that agreement is needed by around then for lawmakers to have time this year to enact a deficit-reduction package. ``Everyone feels that if we work day to day until then, we ought to be either well on our way to putting an agreement together or be pretty much facing a task that's harder than everybody thought,'' said Panetta.

DOC.HEAD: Gap Between Taxes Paid and Owed Hits $100 Billion Mark
With PM-Tax Gap-Figures
DOC.TEXT: A roadside vendor sells a watermelon for cash. A doctor treats a plumber in exchange for a faucet repair. A giant corporation exaggerates a deduction. And the federal tax gap gets bigger. The gap between federal income taxes owed and paid voluntarily is expected to swell to $100 billion this year and to as high as $127 billion two years from now. That does not include uncounted billions more taxes owed on income from illegal sources. Although the dollar figure grows, the tax gap is about the same 17 percent of taxes owed that it was when the Internal Revenue Service began keeping the statistics in 1973. Viewed another way, individuals and businesses pay about 83 percent of their income taxes without further prodding by the IRS and avoid the rest chiefly by under-reporting income and overstating deductions. That is not good enough for Congress, which is interested in any painless way to reduce the budget deficit, or for the IRS, whose leaders fear more and more Americans will join the ranks of tax cheats if they see evidence that others are getting away with it. The latest analysis by the IRS indicates that businesses, ranging from the Mom-and-Pop grocery stores to lawyers to big corporations, are responsible for more than 60 percent of the gap. The worst offenders are one-owner businesses and ``informal suppliers,'' the IRS's designation for sellers _ child-care providers, home repairmen and roadside vendors, for example _ who usually deal in cash and seldom maintain a regular place of business. Those two groups account for more than one-quarter of the tax gap. Nobody has a quick solution. But lawmakers, IRS officials and non-government experts agree on the problems: _Not enough tax returns are audited. Fewer than 1 percent of individuals and 2 percent of corporations will be audited this year. However, IRS officials point out that about 40 percent of individuals, whose incomes are almost entirely from wages, interest and dividends, get what amounts to an automatic audit because their returns are matched by computer against documents that list their earnings. IRS enforcement actions _ mainly audits and stepped-up collection measures _ reduce the tax gap by about $22 billion a year. _Too few people go to jail for cheating. Despite an almost legendary reputation for criminal investigation _ it took the IRS to get Al Capone _ the fact is the IRS brings criminal charges for tax violations against fewer than 3,000 people a year. The figure is declining. ``There is a general perception in the service (IRS) that criminal tax enforcement has become too much oriented toward drug dealers and the illegal sector and as a result, there is not enough threat to ordinary citizens to be a credible deterrent,'' says Peter Scott, former acting chief counsel for the IRS who now is with Coopers & Lybrand accountants. _Requiring the IRS to share in budget cuts of the last several years has been counterproductive, because the agency collects $200 for each $1 it spends. Its collection division has been especially hurt. Over the years, the IRS has built up a backlog of accounts receivable _ assessed but uncollected taxes _ that totals about $87 billion and involves 13 million taxpayers. The agency says as much as half that will never be collected because of death, bankruptcy or other reasons. _The IRS is plagued with high turnover, often outgunned by high-priced corporate lawyers and prone to mistakes. Its computers crank out erroneous tax-due notices that seem almost impossible to correct. Employees, many of them temporary workers, give the wrong answer to at least one of every four tax questions. On average, the IRS loses 70 percent of additional taxes assessed when a taxpayer appeals. Closing the tax gap requires a better performance, IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. told Congress earlier this year. ``Taxpayers are willing to pay what they owe,'' he said. ``They cannot abide complexity, uncertainty, administrative burdens and hassles with the IRS that may take months or years to resolve.'' _IRS computers are woefully outmoded, but a decade-long modernization costing upwards of $8 billion is under way. Any credit-card company can tell a customer the status of his or her account within seconds. But IRS computers can't ``talk'' to each other. When a tax return is processed in Austin, Texas, for example, it must be keyed onto a tape, which then is flown and trucked to the IRS computer center in Martinsburg, W.Va., to be entered into a taxpayer's file. Slow computers affect more than taxpayer services. The General Accounting Office says the IRS lacks sufficient data ``to either identify the issues most responsible for the most troublesome pockets of the tax gap or to track how well its programs reduce the tax gap.'' President Bush's IRS budget for 1991, up $635 million to $6.1 billion, would continue the computer modernization and pay for more auditors and collectors and further improvements in taxpayer services. The plan is designed to increase collections by $9 billion over five years. But the National Treasury Employees Union, which represents IRS workers, says the percentage of returns audited would drop and the total of unpaid accounts would rise under Bush's budget. By spending $4.2 billion more than proposed over the next five years, the IRS could collect almost $25 billion more, the union says.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Tax Gap
DOC.TEXT: Individuals and corporations underpaid federal income taxes on their legal earnings by $94.2 billion in 1987, the Internal Revenue Service estimates. This figure, expected to rise above $100 billion this year, is called the tax gap: the difference between what is owed and what is paid voluntarily, without any additional pressure by the IRS. Here, according to the IRS, is what accounted for the tax gap in 1987, the latest year for which detailed estimates are available. The first figure is the dollar value attributable to each factor; the figure in parentheses is that factor's share of the total gap. Percentages do not total 100 because of rounding. _Unreported income by informal supplies (such as roadside vendors and child-care providers) and sole-proprietor businesses, $24.3 billion (25.8 percent). _Large corporations, $16.8 billion (17.8 percent). _Failure to pay balance due when returns are filed, $7.9 billion (8.4 percent). _Failure to file returns, $7.2 billion (7.6 percent). _Capital gains, $6.7 billion (7.1 percent). _Partnership, rental, royalty income, $6.4 billion (6.7 percent). _Overstated deductions and exemptions, $6.1 billion (6.4 percent). _Small corporations, $5.4 billion (5.7 percent). _Wages, interest and dividends, $4.3 billion (4.6 percent). _Other, $9.1 billion (9.7 percent).

DOC.HEAD: Big Feedlots Continuing to Grow
DOC.TEXT: Huge feedlots that turn out the choicest beef have been increasing in number for many years, and an Agriculture Department economist says the trend shows no sign of letting up. Fewer than 200 feedlots marketed more than half the nation's fed cattle last year, said Ken Krause of the department's Economic Research Service. All had capacities of 16,000 head or more. Less than 30 years ago, there were only 23 feedlots with capacities of 16,000 head or more. And in 1962 those accounted for only 8.3 percent of the 14.6 million fed cattle marketed. ``By 1980, fed cattle output had increased to 23.2 million head while large lots had become more important in the feeding of the increased fed cattle herd,'' he said in the June issue of Farmline magazine. The largest feedlots continued to increase in the 1980s. Last year, 198 of those fed produced about 51 percent of the nation's output of fed cattle. Krause said new information collected by the USDA's National Agricultural Statistics Service showed that 32 feedlots with capacities of 50,000 head or more accounted for 17 percent of the fed cattle marketed last year. ``Although NASS confidentiality rules do not permit identification of the largest existing lots, several operators indicated that their lots have 100,000-head, one-time capacity,'' he said. Typically, feeder cattle weighing 600 to 800 pounds are put in the pens and fed a balanced diet made up of a ``concentrate'' (often corn or grain sorghum), a protein supplement such as soybean or cottonseed meal and some silage or hay for roughage. After five months or so, the fattened ``finished'' cattle _ now weighing 1,000 to 1,200 pounds _ are shipped to packing plants for slaughter and distribution in the consumer pipeline. Krause said there has been a significant decrease in the number of feedlots smaller than 1,000-head capacity. Those are often associated with family-size farming operations that also produce crops and perhaps other livestock. At the same time, the fed cattle industry _ meaning larger feedlot operations _ has been shifting to four Great Plains states. ``In general, the location shift has been to Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska and Texas, where over 71 percent of the cattle were finished in 1989,'' Krause said. ``These four states finished only 28.5 percent of the fed cattle in 1962.'' The decline of small feedlots, meanwhile, has been mainly in the Corn Belt states. Iowa, for example, had 50,000 lots in 1962, most of them small. Those turned out 18 percent of the nation's beef. By 1989, Iowa was down to about 16,000 feedlots, accounting for just 8 percent of the nation's beef cattle. Krause said that while the number and importance of small feedlots have declined the last 30 years, nationally they still produced more than 16 percent of the fed beef last year.

The South is the historic home of King Cotton, but that was long ago. The king, or at least a large part of the royal family, has moved farther west. In 1987, according to an Agriculture Department analysis, six of the 10 the largest cotton counties _ in terms of value of production _ were in California and Arizona. ``In fact, in that year, the value of cotton sales from Fresno County (Calif.) alone exceeded the combined sales of Alabama, Georgia, Florida, the Carolinas and Virginia,'' the report said. The top three cotton counties by value of sale in 1987 were Fresno, Kern and Kings in California's San Joaquin Valley. Combined with three other valley counties _ Merced, Madera and Tulare _ the six California counties ``produced about $890 million in cotton sales in 1987 _ rivaling the $970 million produced in all counties east of the Mississippi River,'' the report said. Among the other top cotton counties in 1987, eight are in Texas, five in Mississippi and three in Louisiana. Here are the rankings of the top 25 counties in terms of sales value in 1987: 1. Fresno, Calif., $293,287,000. 2. Kern, Calif., $226,281,000. 3. Kings, Calif., $198,665,000. 4. Maricopa, Ariz., $141,771,000. 5. Pinal, Ariz., $131,764,000. 6. Tulare, Calif., $99,166,000. 7. Gaines, Texas, $59,999,000. 8. Lubbock, Texas, $54,708,000. 9. Hale, Texas, $54,043,000. 10. Terry, Texas, $50,093,000. 11. Merced, Calif., $48,273,000. 12. Hockley, Texas, $44,956,000. 13. Lynn, Texas, $43,400,000. 14. Dunklin, Mo., $42,044,000. 15. Leflore, Miss., $41,539,000. 16. Lamb, Texas, $41,530,000. 17. Yazoo, Miss., $40,954,000. 18. Richland, La., $39,341,000. 19. Coahoma, Miss., $38,739,000. 20. Dawson, Texas, $38,426,000. 21. Franklin, La., $38,314,000. 22. Washington, Miss., $37,716,000. 23. Morehouse, La., $37,649,000. 24. Mississippi, Ark., $37,534,000. 25. Sunflower, Miss., $37,144,000.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,376.80, down 161.60 points, or 0.50 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Rally Kicks Off Week of Black Student Activism
DOC.TEXT: Black college students are lobbying national leaders this week for better education opportunities, District of Columbia statehood and other causes. Hundreds of students marched on Sunday to a rally at a park across from the White House to launch the week's activities. Civil rights leaders and musicians joined the rally in Lafayette Square, urging a resurgence of black activism to fight for justice for all students at campuses across the nation. ``Whenever young America comes alive, America is always made better,'' Jesse Jackson told the crowd. The ``Student Call to Washington'' also includes a rally planned in front of the U.S. Supreme Court Wednesday. The week was organized by the National Collegiate Black Caucus and several other groups including Black Law Students Association, the African National Congress Youth Division and the United States Student Association. U.S. Capitol Police estimated 850 people participated in Sunday's Demonstration.
DOC.HEAD: PBS Considering Free Air Time for 1992 Presidential Candidates
DOC.TEXT: Presidential candidates and the major political parties could get free air time on the PBS in 1992. Bruce Christensen, president of the Public Broadcasting Service, said Sunday the idea would be under discussion for the next few months. ``What we're looking for is the way to increase the political dialogue,'' Christensen said in a telephone interview from Dallas, where PBS' board of directors is meeting this week. He said the possibilities include several ideas recommended Friday to top PBS officials by the John and Mary Markle Foundation of New York. The foundation, which will present a study to the PBS board on Tuesday, has offered to contribute $5 million of the estimated $15 million to $20 million that the project would cost. The Markle study recommends that PBS offer free air time in blocks ranging from 2{ minutes to 15 minutes to the presidential candidates and-or the political parties. The Markle plan was outlined in Sunday editions of The Washington Post and The New York Times. Christensen predicted that most of the 337 public TV channels in the PBS system ``will sign on to what we are doing.''
DOC.HEAD: AIDS Vaccine Available by End of Decade, Government Expert Says
DOC.TEXT: By the end of the decade, a vaccine to combat the AIDS virus likely will be available for widespread use, a government AIDS expert says. Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of AIDS research at the National Institutes of Health, said Sunday that ``the decade of the '90s will see some important advances that will have a positive impact on HIV-infected individuals.'' ``Over the next several years, you'll see a real acceleration of vaccine development, and hopefully by the end of the 1990s there will be a vaccine that is available for widespread use,'' Fauci said. An estimated 1 million Americans are believed to be infected by HIV, or human immunodeficiency virus, which can develop into the AIDS disease. The Bush administration has come under fire from AIDS activists and congressional critics for not spending enough money on AIDS research and moving too slowly in approving new drugs to fight the disease. The federal government is spending $1.16 billion in the current fiscal year on AIDS research and the administration has recommended an increase to $1.245 billion in fiscal 1991. Fauci appeared on the ABC-TV program ``This Week With David Brinkley'' in advance of the sixth international AIDS conference, which starts Wednesday in San Francisco. The conference, billed as the largest gathering to date of HIV scientists, health care workers and policy-makers, will run through June 24.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Abortion Leaders Vow to Keep Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Despite perceived setbacks in opinion polls, leaders of the country's largest anti-abortion group vowed to keep fighting in the coming decades. The president of the National Right to Life Committee, which wound up its three-day annual meeting Sunday, urged optimism in the face of what he said were skewed public opinion polls, bad press and ``turncoat'' politicians. ``You would not be able to tell here that we had suffered any reverses,'' J.C. Willke said. Delegates bought buttons, bumper stickers and watched anti-abortion videos. One poster showed an infant with the words: ``Kill her now and it's considered murder. Kill her three months ago and it's called abortion.'' Willke said the committee's goals and tactics have not changed since the Supreme Court gave states more power to regulate abortion last year. The group's ultimate goal remains making abortion illegal nationwide. Unlike groups such as Operation Rescue, the National Right to Life Committee avoids clinic blockades and other front-line tactics and focuses on lobbying, legislation and other political activity. Susan Smith, the organization's associate legislative director, said the group is ``working uphill to counter the media hype that the pro-abortion movement creates.' ``Ten, 20 years down the road I expect we'll be a little further along than we are now,'' Smith said. One workshop at the convention was titled ``Working a Biased Media to the Advantage of the Movement.'' Public opinion surveys have frightened some politicians away from the anti-abortion stance, said Richard E. Ryan, senior vice president of the Texas-based polling company Tarrance & Associates. But he questioned the surveys' validity. Even though about 60 percent of those polled tend to favor allowing abortion, some 50 percent to 60 percent also tend to favor placing some controls on abortion, Ryan said. ``They are the mushy middle,'' he said. ``They want to have their cake and eat it too.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Claim Florida's `Old Sparky' Tortures Its Victims
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Florida's electric chair and its ``man-made lightning'' forever silenced the would-be assassin of Franklin Roosevelt and jolted the life out of the charming Ted Bundy. Dubbed Old Sparky, the three-legged oak chair has killed 219 inmates in 66 years. But only the execution of John Spenkelink _ the first person in the nation to be put to death against his will after the U.S. Supreme Court reinstated the dealth penalty in 1976 _ has stirred as much controversy in Florida as the recent botched execution of Jesse Tafero. Because of Tafero's execution, in which 12-inch flames and sparks leaped through the hood over his head, attorneys for poor inmates want to ban the chair. They claim Tafero was burned alive and that the chair is cruel and unusual punishment. That is the issue in the appeal of ``Black Widow'' killer Judi Buenoano. The state Supreme Court on Friday granted her a stay to give her lawyers time to pursue that argument. Ms. Buenoano was condemned for the 1971 poisoning death of her husband. She is serving a life term for the 1980 drowning murder of her paralyzed son. She stands to become the first woman to die in Florida's electric chair since it came into use in 1924. Hewn from an oak tree by prisoners, the chair, which is at Florida State Prison, replaced hanging. It has been used to execute 175 people convicted of murder, 43 convicted of rape and one convicted of a fatal kidnapping. One of the most notorious to die in the chair was Giuseppe Zangara, executed in 1933 for the shooting death that same year of Chicago Mayor Anton Cermak. Cermak was fatally wounded in an attempted assassination of President-elect Franklin Roosevelt in Miami. An account of the execution said: ``Zangara muttered in deliberate, measured tones: `The rich are a bunch of scrum, the rich are a bunch of' _ Just then, a switch clicked and the man-made lightning struck through its appointed target and forever silenced the muttering voice.'' After a 15-year lull caused in part by a U.S. Supreme Court ruling that put the death penalty on hold, executions resumed in Florida in 1979 with Spenkelink. Unlike Utah's Gary Gilmore, the first person executed after the death penalty's reinstatement, Spenkelink did not go willingly. The best-known killer to die in Florida's electric chair was Bundy, executed last year for the slaying of a girl. Bundy also was convicted of murdering two college students in Tallahassee and was believed to have killed as many as 50 women. Florida has executed 22 people since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling, second only to Texas' 35. The latest person to die in the chair was Tafero, on May 4. Witnesses said he appeared to breathe and move after the first and second jolts. The malfunction opened a new avenue of appeals. ``An inmate about to be executed in Florida will likely be burned and tortured during that execution, will be conscious during the event, and will suffer pain,'' said the appeal filed in the Buenoano case. Color photographs of the bodies of nine executed men accompanied the appeals filed by state-paid attorneys in Buenoano's case and in another death row case. After Gov. Bob Martinez ordered an investigation, the state Department of Corrections concluded Tafero's death was instant but that the mistaken replacement of a natural sponge with a synthetic sponge had caused the burning. But the state-paid attorneys, who are from an agency that represents poor death row inmates, maintain that the problem lies with a faulty electrode that reduced the electricity from 2,000 volts to as low as 100 or 90. They blasted the department for testing the flammability of the sponge by using a household toaster and alleged the problem had not been fixed. Spokesmen for Martinez and Corrections Secretary Richard Dugger said the state stood by its investigation. Dugger called the allegations absurd.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. War Dead Incorrectly Identified by North Korea
DOC.TEXT: Last month, Communist North Korea turned over what it said were the remains of five U.S. servicemen killed in the Korean War. Now American officials say they're not sure whose remains they have. The remains were handed over to to a U.S. congressional delegation in an emotional Memorial Day ceremony in the truce village of Panmunjom in what was billed as the first return of U.S. Korean War dead since 1954. Only two of the five bodies were identified by name by the North Koreans, based on dogtags they said were found with them. They were U.S. Army 1st Lt. Jack J. Saunders, 27, of Ogden, Utah and Army Cpl. Arthur Leo Seaton, 20, of Chester, Pa. But the United Nations Command said today that the bodies, which were sent to the Army's Central Identification Laboratory in Honolulu for identification, were not those of Saunders and Seaton. ``While North Korea has indicated name association for two of the five remains, dental and physical characteristics of the remains were compared with the dental and physical records of the those two individuals, with negative results,'' the command said. The command said its findings were preliminary, but said it did not appear that the other remains returned were those of Saunders or Seaton either. ``Until the identification process is complete, we can't even be sure they were the remains of Americans,'' the command added. The soldiers' relatives have been told of the findings, the command said. The other three sets of remains were not identified by North Korea, but it said at the time of the return that they were believed to be those of another Army servicemen and two U.S. Air Force members. All five were believed to have been prisoners of war who died in Hwanghae Pukto province, south of North Korea's capital of Pyongyang. Saunders and Seaton had been listed as missing in February 1951, the Pentagon said. According to U.S. military, 8,172 U.S. soldiers remain unaccounted for from the war. The return of the remains was widely seen as a sign of healing and reconciliation after decades of emnity, an effort by North Korea to improve relations with the United States. The two countries do not have diplomatic ties. The United Nations Command says 33,629 U.S. soldiers were killed and 103,284 wounded in the war. More than 2 million Koreans were killed. The 16-nation command, led by an American general, was formed at the outbreak of the 1950-53 Korean War to help South Korea repel invaders from the North. There were large-scale returns of remains of U.S. war dead in 1953 and 1954. Then, after years of no returns, the North Koreans announced May 14 that they would turn over the remains of the five. Ho Jong, North Korean's deputy permanant representative at its U.N. mission, said at the time that the Communist government was prepared to discuss the return of more remains. He said the move was an ``eloquent illustration'' of North Korea's wilingness to ``settle pending issues with the U.S. government in a good way.'' North Korea acknowledged for the first time in January 1988 that it was still holding the remains of U.N. Command war dead.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Traffic Controller Was Overruled Before Avianca Crash
DOC.TEXT: A decision to accept more planes per hour at Kennedy Airport than an air traffic supervisor recommended may have contributed to the crash of a fuel-starved Avianca jet, New York Newsday reported. The jet crashed in Cove Neck on Jan. 25, killing 73 people, after it had been placed in holding patterns for more than an hour as it flew up the East Coast from Colombia. When the weather is good, Kennedy accepts about 60 planes an hour. But the day of the crash, because of fog and rain, a local air traffic supervisor recommended a flow of 22 planes an hour, Newsday reported Sunday. However, his recommendation was rejected, the newspaper said. After consultations with officials, including the Federal Aviation Administration's Central Flow headquarters in Washington, the rate was set at 33 per hour, the newspaper said, citing unidentified sources. Yet because of the bad weather, the airport barely landed 22 planes an hour, the newspaper said. ``The flow system fell apart,'' an unidentified source was quoted as saying. ``It did not work the way it was supposed to work. They (controllers) were playing a game of catch-up all afternoon. They never caught up.'' The jet's crew never declared a fuel emergency, which would have enabled it to get priority to land before it ran out of fuel. An unidentified investigator told the paper that if the airport had decided to accept fewer planes, there might have been fewer ahead of the Avianca jet. The National Transportation Safety Board will hold hearings Wednesday and Thursday on the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Stocks Slip
DOC.TEXT: The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange declined in slow trading in the absence of market-moving factors. The dollar closed at 153.88 yen, down 0.64 yen from Friday's close of 154.52 yen. The U.S. currency opened at 153.77 yen and ranged between 153.72 yen and 154.18 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 161.60 points, or 0.50 percent, to close the day at 32,376.80. The index had lost 129.71 points on Friday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 87.70 points as of 3 p.m., down from Friday's close of 87.79. Their yield rose to 7.035 percent from Friday's close of 7.015 percent. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, predicted the dollar would move in a narrow range for the time being. ``There are no fresh market-affecting incentives,'' he said. On the stock market, traders said many investors stayed on the sidelines in the absence of market-moving factors. Volume traded in the first section totaled 300 million shares, down from last Friday's 450 million shares. The day's trading was thin with small stocks with good movement drawing buyers' attention, said Masahiro Umemori of Nomura Securities Co. He said there appeared to be little factors that would send the prices further downward. ``The (yen-dollar) exchange rate is stable and there seem to be no big factors that would bother the investors,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Microbe Experiment Continues
With PM-Tanker Blast
DOC.TEXT: Officials hope the second phase of an experiment using oil-eating bacteria to break up a slick from the wrecked Mega Borg will remove any doubts that the process works. On Friday, about 100 pounds of the bacteria was spread over an acre of the slick caused by the Norwegian supertanker that exploded June 8 in the Gulf of Mexico. The Coast Guard estimates 3.9 million gallons of light crude spilled. A flyover Sunday showed little oil in the treated water, and the microbes appeared to have done the job, state officials said. But there was no conclusive proof, and a second test application began Sunday. ``There certainly wasn't any oil over there,'' said Texas Water Commission Chairman B.J. Wynne. But Wynne said it could not be determined if the oil was removed by the microbes or currents or if a buoy marking the treated area had moved. It was the first use of the process _ called bioremediation _ on open water. The process was used this year to clean rocks fouled in Alaska by the Exxon Valdez spill in March 1989. The naturally occurring bacteria break oil down into a harmless fatty substance that is eaten by fish. In the second application, the microbes were to be unleashed in one area while another area would go untreated.

DOC.HEAD: Gadhafi Calls for Push to Make Atomic Bomb
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi has called on Libyan researchers to make a new push to develop an atomic bomb, according to a news report monitored in London. The Libyan news agency JANA, as monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp., quoted Gadhafi as urging scientists Sunday to ``work day and night'' to build a nuclear weapon ``in defiance of America.'' He also called for development of Libyan space technology. ``America manufactures missiles and puts above our heads satellites,'' the Libyan leader was quoted as saying. ``This provokes you and ignites in you the spirit of defiance and revolution to reach space and manufacture the atom.'' He blamed the United States for withholding technology Libya needs. Gadhafi also accused Israel of aiming nuclear weapons at Arab cities, saying, ``This is unacceptable and we must work against it.''

DOC.HEAD: Feline at Center of Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A stowaway cat that survived a 48-day journey from London without food or water may wind up being the most expensive feline in Australia. Dozens of cat-lovers have called animal quarantine officials to say they want custody of the roving feline, which arrived a week ago in a shipping container with a Mercedes Benz. The shipping line and the woman who owns the Mercedes are among those interested. But the stray's owner-to-be will pay dearly. A spokeswoman for the South Australia Department of Agriculture, which runs Adelaide's animal quarantine station, says the black cat must remain in quarantine for nine months. Australia has some of the world's most stringent quarantine laws to keep out rabies and other animal diseases. The tab for looking after the cat will come to at least 1,900 dollars ($1,480 U.S.), the spokeswoman said. A special meeting has been called for Tuesday to sort out the would-be owners.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We will never see peace in Central America while hunger exists in thousands of homes.'' _ Costa Rican President Rafael Calderon, in a speech closing a three-day Central American economic summit.

``Their attitude has been like that old song from the musical `My Fair Lady:' `Why Can't a Woman Be More Like a Man?''' _ U.S. Rep. Olympia Snowe, R-Maine, calling on the National Institutes of Health to include women in research paid for by the government.

``I have never threatened to excommunicate anybody; I have never suggested that any other bishop excommunicate anybody; I have no intention of excommunicating anybody.'' Cardinal John J. O'Connor, claiming a newspaper column he wrote last week should not have been interpreted to mean he supports excommunicating Catholic politicians who support abortion rights.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Strike South, Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms rumbled over Kentucky and rain fell in Ohio early today, while much of the rest of the nation enjoyed fair weather. Thunderstorms were forecast for today in Wyoming, the Dakotas, western Texas and New Mexico. A band of thunderstorms also was expected from Arkansas to Maine and from Alabama through Georgia and northern Florida. Showers were expected from Northern California to Montana. In an early start to summer, which begins Thursday, heat advisories were posted across much of Texas. Hot weather also was expected in Arkansas and Tennessee. The high for the nation Sunday was 107 degrees at Laredo and Childress in Texas and Lake Havasu City, Ariz. On Sunday, showers and thunderstorms extended over much of Florida, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, northeastern Louisiana and northwestern Texas. More than 2 inches of rain fell within six hours at Pensacola, Fla. Thunderstorms developed over Missouri, Illinois, Wisconsin, Minnesota and upper Michigan and were scattered from Montana across Idaho and from Oregon into Northern California. Showers and thunderstorms also were scattered over New York state and Maine. DOC.HEAD: Air Show Director Killed in Front of 75,000
DOC.TEXT: An air show director was killed when his stunt plane failed to come out of an intentional stall and crashed nose-first in front of an estimated 75,000 people. ``When it hit, it just exploded,'' said Kevin Ellis, a spectator Sunday at Will Rogers World Airport. ``No matter how fast the trucks got there, he was dead. It was just a ball of fire.'' Killed was Tom Jones, 46, a former national champion aerobatic pilot and director of the Aerospace America '90 show. The Soviet-made Sukhoi-26M stunt plane never regained power after Jones performed a straight-up stall called a tail slide. The announcer said, ``OK, Tom, OK, looking good _ you can pull up,'' just before the plane hit the ground in a grassy area 100 yards from the crowd. Many in the crowd captured the crash on home video cameras. All civilian performances at the air show were immediately canceled. Military jets, bombers and helicopters performed fly-bys in a tribute to Jones about two hours later. Jets flew the missing-man formation. Jones was a member of the 1988-89 world champion aerobatic team and was the national aerobatic champion in 1988, air show spokesman Mark House said.

DOC.HEAD: In a Flash, Flood Burdens Coroner's Deputy With Grim Duty
With PM-Flash Floods, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The hardest part after a killer flood, a coroner's deputy says, is telling relatives a child has been lost. ``You expect death in the elderly, and it doesn't bother me,'' Chuck Vogt, the Belmont County Coroner's investigator, said Sunday. ``But death in the young ... that's hard. They've never had a chance.'' It is Vogt's job to notify relatives of people who were killed after 5{ inches of rain fell in about three hours in eastern Ohio's Belmont County on Thursday and sent a wall of water crashing down the Wegee and Pipe creek valleys. At least 20 people died and 16 were missing. Vogt, a lifelong resident of this town of about 4,700, said he knew most of the dead and knew relatives of the others. He is responsible for taking survivors to the morgue to identify the remains of loved ones. ``I think that right now, it hasn't hit me yet. It'll hit me later when all this has calmed down, and I'm sure I'll be a basket case some time next week,'' Vogt said. He said it was especially hard to face the mother of Kerri Polivka. Kerri was with Amber Colvin, a 9-year-old who was swept seven miles down a creek and rescued Friday in the Ohio River. ``I see that girl's mother, the girl who was with Amber,'' Vogt said, ``and she gives me that look that says `What have you found? Can you tell me anything?''' Vogt said the worst of his job may still be ahead. He said he did not expect any of the missing who were swept down the creek to be found alive. ``It's just been too long. I don't think there's anybody alive out there. You can't swim out there that long in the Ohio River,'' Vogt said. He said bodies submerged in the river would probably begin surfacing today as gases in them accumulate. Vogt wasn't the only worker putting in overtime since the flood. The sirens that marked the first three days after the storm have given way to the roar of bulldozers and dump trucks. Automobiles, crushed by the water or wrapped around trees like bow ties, were taken out on National Guard flatbeds. Pick-and-shovel crews worked ahead of most of the earth-moving equipment, searching for victims in piles of debris where search dogs indicated bodies might lie. ``If there's enough equipment in there _ I'm talking 'dozers and trucks to haul it out and loaders to load it _ with enough equipment and a month's time, they can clean up a lot of this debris and get it out,'' said Don Keyfer, who drives a backhoe for a construction company. It could take two years before the area is back to normal, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Employee Steals $1.5 Million Via Computer
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout with official confirmation. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A young bank executive broke into his bank's computer security system and stole nearly $1.5 million in Malaysia's biggest case ever of computer fraud, police said today. The executive attracted suspicion when he bought a red Lamborghini, three Porsches and a Mercedes Benz, the New Straits Times daily newspaper said, citing police and banking sources. It said the arrest was made Tuesday. Police confirmed that they had seized luxury cars the 24-year-old man had purchased. His identity was not disclosed. Shamsuri Arshad, deputy director of the criminal investigations department of the federal police, said bank employees and other potential witnesses were being interviewed. Banking sources said the executive was employed in the bank's foreign exchange section. He apparently cracked the bank's computer security system and transferred the money from the accounts of several clients into his own personal account, they said. The money was then withdrawn over a six-month period, and the bank discovered the funds were missing in a spot check by auditors, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower against key currencies in European trading this morning. Gold prices gained. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 153.88 yen, down 0.64 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 153.98 yen. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, predicted the dollar would move in a narrow range for the time being. ``There are no fresh market-affecting incentives,'' he said. The gold market in Hong Kong was closed today in honor of the birthday of Queen Elizabeth II. Silver bullion traded in London at a bid $4.84 a troy ounce, up from $4.80 per ounce late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Brass Band Festival Big Hit, May Become Annual Affair
DOC.TEXT: Organizers of the first Great American Brass Band Festival are already trying to arrange an encore. Organizers estimated that more than 10,000 people turned out for the festival, which featured the music of eight old-time ensembles. The event ended Sunday. ``The measure of success is whether people came and had a good time,'' festival co-chairman George Foreman said. ``And there's bound to be some way to do it again next year.'' Activities at the Centre College campus in town began Thursday and ranged from displays of antique bicycles to a hot-air balloon race. Groups in Saturday's concert series spanned styles and periods. The Civil War-era Regiment Band of the 11th North Carolina Troops, for example, played opposite Danville's Advocate Brass Band, vintage 1890. But the Olympia Brass Band from New Orleans came the farthest and got the biggest response. When the group led a procession down Main Street Saturday to the tune of ``When the Saints Come Marching in,'' some spectators fell in behind and danced along. ``The atmosphere of this music can be experienced in Danville, Ky., or New Orleans, La., just the same, providing people enjoy it,'' said Milton Batiste, one of the band members. ``If people enjoy what we do, the atmosphere is right anywhere we play.''

DOC.HEAD: Armed Man Robs Church Congregation
DOC.TEXT: Churchgoers lying on the floor prayed for themselves and the gunman collecting their wallets during a holdup in the middle of a Baptist service. The man, carrying a sawed-off shotgun, made off with credit cards, checkbooks and at least $500 in cash Sunday morning from more than 130 members of the Faith Way Baptist Church. Mary Gregory, the pastor's wife, said the gunman, wearing sunglasses and a stocking mask, came in through the basement and walked up the steps to the back of the sanctuary. ``He had a gun and he said, `This is a holdup. Everybody get down,''' Mrs. Gregory said. ``Everybody was down and they were praying and he was going around the pews and taking billfolds and purses and things.'' ``It seemed like he was there for an eternity, but actually it was about 10 or 15 minutes,'' she said. The pastor, the Rev. Downing Gregory, said he ``thought this was a prank of some sort. I just stood there and looked at him. Then finally he said, ``Reverend, you bow your head, too.' I got down on the floor.'' The robber threatened the church's associate minister, who was praying more loudly than others, Mrs. Gregory said. ``The man was getting irritated. They were praying for him, what he was doing and that it was wrong,'' she said. As he left, the gunman told the congregation to pray for 15 minutes before getting up, the Gregorys said. Members remained on the floor for two or three minutes, the pastor said. ``I had a time of praise and thanksgiving to thank God for sparing our lives,'' he said. The day's collection was in the church office and was not disturbed. ``We have a couple of elderly folks in church. I'm sure that's what hurt most of all, the financial part,'' Gregory said. He said one woman had been saving for a pair of glasses, and a 91-year-old woman lost about $30 in grocery money.

DOC.HEAD: New Party Could Grow From Communist Party Rift
DOC.TEXT: Radical reformers are threatening to walk out of next month's Communist Party congress if their demands are not met, opening a rift that could lead to the creation of a new party. A conference of the reform faction Democratic Platform on Sunday instructed its delegates to the party congress that begins July 2 to leave the session if delegates do not eliminate party control over the armed forces, the KGB security police and other government bodies. If the 4,700 delegates to the congress balk at those and other demands, as seems likely, the group's estimated 100 delegates are to quit and organize a new party by September. Factions have been banned in the Communist Party since 1922. Also Sunday, the mainstream Moscow city party organization published a pre-congress platform that sharply criticized national leaders for drifting into ``an ideological and organizational crisis'' that was costing them support. ``The danger for the party today is a split among Communists who support perestroika,'' said the Moscow party platform. It did not directly mention Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The moves reflected the growing polarization of party politics and widening dissatisfaction with Gorbachev's failure to push reforms past conservatives who retain control of many government and party bodies. Democratic Platform leaders claim to have the general support of 40 percent of the 18 million Communist Party members, a much higher ratio than reflected in the composition of the party congress. But they say that only about 500,000 party members would take the decisive step of actually leaving the party to form a new one. Democratic Platform, founded six months ago, has included Boris N. Yeltsin, who last month was elected president of the Russian republic, and also the new mayors of Moscow and Leningrad, Gavriil Popov and Anatoly Sobchak. But they have cut their activities in the group since their elections. The resolution adopted Sunday by the Democratic Platform, after two days of often stormy debate, blamed the crisis facing the Soviet Union in part on ``the inconsistency, indecisiveness, and either incompetence or unwillingness of the leading (party) structures to carry out a radical reform.'' ``The polarization of political forces is accelerating,'' it said. The group told members who are delegates to the party congress to present a package of demands that include the transformation of the Communist Party from a ``totalitarian type'' into a ``parliamentary type'' that would compete with other political groups. The resolution demands the Communist Party divide its billions of dollars worth of buildings, publishing houses, vehicles and other assets among emerging political groups. Those steps would vastly reduce the role of the Communist Party. Earlier this year, the party agreed to give up its constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power but has been slow to surrender its privileges in society. The resolution published Sunday by the Moscow party organization, the largest and most influential in the nation, was not as radical as the Democratic Platform resolution. But it also called for an end to party control over the armed forces, police and KGB. It said that ``during the years of totalitarianism and stagnation'' from 1929 until 1985, the party had developed ``a non-democratic structure of power'' and that its mistakes had cost many lives.

DOC.HEAD: Furniture Designer Nakashima Dies At 85
DOC.TEXT: George Nakashima, a renowned designer of wood furniture, has died at age 85. Nakashima, who was born in Spokane, Wash., died Friday evening at his home. His family said he died after a brief illness. He was known for working with untrimmed slabs of wood, especially black walnut and redwood. He often left holes and cracks in the final product to capture the trees' character. In 1986, Philadelphia Museum of Art director Anne d'Harnoncourt called Nakashima a ``national treasure.'' His work appeared in the Museum of Modern Art in New York and in many galleries. The American Craft Museum in New York last year staged a major retrospective of his work. Nakashima's Altar for Peace at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan was dedicated New Year's Eve 1986 with a concert directed by Leonard Bernstein. Nakashima graduated from the University of Washington and later traveled to Japan and worked in the Tokyo offices of an American architect. After designing a monastery dormitory, he married, returned to the United States with his wife and opened a small furniture shop in Seattle. The couple were imprisoned with other Japanese-Americans during World War II, but his former employer, Antonin Raymond, arranged for the Nakashimas to join him at his farm in New Hope in 1943. Nakashima is survived by his wife, Marion, a son, Kevin, and a daughter, Mira Nakashima-Yarnall, who has taken over much of the design work of her father's firm. Funeral services were scheduled for today.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Rebels Claim To Control Most of Central Province
DOC.TEXT: A Cambodian rebel group said today it had seized almost all of the central province of Kompong Thom _ just north of the national capital of Phnom Penh _ and briefly held its capital city. The report could not be independently verified. In the past, the guerrillas in the past have exaggerated military successes. If the claim were true, however, it would be a significant development the provincial capital, Kompong Thom, is just 63 miles north of Phnom Penh. The statement was from the forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, one of three guerrilla armies fighting the country's Vietnamese-installed government. The guerrilla groups have intensified attacks since September, when Vietnam said it pulled its last troops out of Cambodia. The guerrillas seized several strategic areas, mostly in the west and northwest bordering Thailand, only to have them retaken by the government. Fighting has continued although Sihanouk and Prime Minister Hun Sen on June 5 signed in Tokyo an agreement calling for military self-restraint. Hopes for an early political settlement were set back with the failure of talks last week between the deputy foreign ministers of Vietnam and China. China is the major supplier of arms to the guerrillas. In a statement, the guerrillas claimed they launched a four-pronged attack on Kompong Thom city and seized it Sunday after three hours of fighting. They said they withdrew after a few hours, though, ``due to the large civilian population ... and for security reasons.'' The rebels claimed to have seized three district towns in the province in the past three weeks. ``As of yesterday, the entire province is totally in the hands of the Cambodian national resistance forces,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Gay Officers Among Security Team for AIDS Conference
With PM-AIDS-ACT UP, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police will put homosexual officers and community leaders on the front lines to handle security at this week's Sixth International AIDS Conference, which activists have pledged to disrupt. A ``first response team'' of 22 police officers, most of them gay and lesbian, plus gay community leaders will try to pacify any overly strident demonstrators inside Moscone Center, San Francisco police said. The conference is scheduled to begin Wednesday. But none of the gay or lesbian officers is expected to make arrests, said Jill Tregor of Community United Against Violence, a member of the community squad. ``The department is scared of looking like the bad guys. They are willing to try something new,'' Tregor said. ``We'll be trying to read the sentiments of the audience,'' she added. ``If demonstrators want five minutes on the microphone, maybe we can give them five minutes on the mike.'' If the first law enforcement group is unable to deal with protesters, a second tier ``arrest squad'' will be called from inside Moscone, San Francisco police said. A third wave of security will supervise the throng of activists expected outside the convention center. Police have said officers will be tolerant of peaceful civil disobedience. ``We want to make sure the city looks good,'' Deputy Chief Fred Lau said during a press briefing Friday. He said about 100 officers would be based at the conference site, with others on standby. A battalion of officers who have undergone special AIDS ``sensitivity'' training will monitor AIDS activists using modified forms of crowd control, primarily holding batons in less intimidating positions, police said. But Lau added that officers wouldn't let demonstrators get out of control. ``We'd like to maintain control of the barricade line,'' Lau said. ``In the past, demonstrators have become overly zealous and picked up the barricades.''

DOC.HEAD: Latest Cease-Fire Breaks Down; Government, Tamil Rebels Clash
DOC.TEXT: A 2-day-old cease-fire between government troops and Tamil guerrillas collapsed today amid new fighting. The truce, which began Saturday, had been marred by minor attacks. By today, both sides reported exchanges of fire along Sri Lanka's east coast and in the north. The government and the Tamil Tiger rebels had already accused each other of using the cease-fire to fortify their positions and to bring in supplies and reinforcements. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne told Parliament the government ``has been compelled'' to fight. A rebel spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``The war situation continues.'' Ethnic Tamil militants took up arms against the Sinhalese-dominated government in 1983 in their quest for a separate homeland. At least 378 people have been killed since June 11, when the rebels broke a 13-month-old truce. The death toll was compiled from reports by witnesses, military sources and Tiger officials. Rebels in the east coast town of Batticaloa today set fire to the police station they captured a week ago and streamed out of town toward the jungle in jeeps, vans and small trucks, a local journalist reported. Batticaloa is 140 miles northeast of Colombo. On Sunday, the rebels blew up a bridge outside Batticaloa in an attempt to keep the army from advancing, the Tiger spokesman said. Government troops hold an airstrip outside the town. Speaking on condition of anonymity, he said government forces returned fire in at least two areas near Batticaloa and also near the north central town of Vavuniya. Both areas were the scene of fighting last week. Last week's battles began after the Tigers overran the Batticaloa police station, then seized other stations in the region. At least 850 policemen, ordered by their government not to return fire, surrendered to the Tigers last week. The fate of most of them is still unknown. A survivor and military sources said at least 137 of the captive policemen were gunned down by the Tigers after they surrendered. The government opened direct negotiations with the Tigers in May 1989 and implemented a cease-fire that had generally held until last week. During the negotiations, the government pledged to delegate provincial autonomy to the Tamils in the north and east. At the same time, it allowed the Tigers virtually a free hand in the region. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, are predominantly Hindu and claim the Sinhalese majority, who are mostly Buddhist, discriminate against them in jobs and education. Sinhalese comprise 75 percent of the population. More than 11,000 people have been killed since the insurrection began.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Moved To Launch Pad
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Atlantis was moved out to the launch pad today in preparation for a secret military flight next month. It's the same pad that Columbia occupied until June 12, when the shuttle was returned to the hangar for repair of a hydrogen leak. Columbia's astronomy mission with the Astro observatory is tentatively set for mid-August. Atlantis began the 3{-mile trip from the hangar to the launch pad at 11:16 p.m. EDT Sunday night. The move takes six to eight hours. The five crew members were expected to arrive later today for a countdown demonstration test Wednesday and Thursday. The Pentagon mission, scheduled for mid-July, will be the seventh of 36 shuttle flights dedicated to a classified, military cargo.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0469 to CORRECT cycle designator
Central American Economic Accord at a Glance
With PM-Central America
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the joint economic plan signed Sunday by five Central American presidents at the conclusion of their three-day economic summit in Antigua, Guatemala:

MAIN POINTS: The newly formed Central American Economic Community will try to mesh the region's economies with coordinated action on foreign trade and debt, on rebuilding infrastructures, on agricultural and industrial policy and attracting investment. The Central American Economic Action Plan calls for creation of a new set of rules in the region for eliminating obstacles to integrated economic growth. It calls for the cutting of bureaucratic red tape in the transportation of passengers and freight in the region. It also calls for making customs and migration procedures less complicated.

PARTICIPANTS: Nicaraguan President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and Costa Rican President Rafael Calderon, both elected this year, signed the plan as first-time participants in a regional summit. Signing for Guatemala was President Vinicio Cerezo, for El Salvador, President Alfredo Cristiani and for Honduras, President Rafael Callejas. Panamanian President Guillermo Endara signed as an invited observer.

TIMING: Ongoing negotiations between the Central American governments are necessary to turn the plan into action, the presidents say in a six-page document. They say that within one month bankers and financiers should set up a forum to handle Central America's foreign debt. Within three months all countries in the region are to present tariff regulations offering reciprocal treatment on trade duties and government and private sector councils are to be in place to allow a dialogue for development. A joint agriculture policy for food exports and imports is to be designed within three months. Within six months, the presidents expect to have a program in place for improved transportation, telephone, mail, electricity and customs services. A strategy for boosting research, science and technology would then be devised. Also within six months, a program should be devised to help small businesses, underground enterprises and less affluent sectors of society share in regional development.

DOC.HEAD: Strains Inside Shamir's Cabinet Over Handling U.S. Ties
DOC.TEXT: Aides to Foreign Minister David Levy are angry with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir for rebuffing American proposals on starting Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, a leading Heberw daily reported today. The Haaretz newspaper also said Levy blocked the delivery of a message Shamir wanted to send to Egyptian leaders through the Israeli Embassy in Cairo last week. Shamir's new right-wing government assumed power last week. Levy is the No. 2 man in the Likud bloc, and his aspirations to eventually replace Shamir as Likud leader have caused past diputes between the two. In Shamir's last Cabinet, Levy was a chief critic of U.S. peace plans, but he has taken a more moderate stance since taking over the Foreign Ministry. Levy's spokeswoman, Aliza Goren, said in a telephone interview today that the reports of disagreement between Shamir and Levy were ``an exaggeration and blown out of proportion.'' Levy, 52, was hospitalized last week after a mild heart attack. He has begun working from his sickbed and is expected to be released this weekend. Israeli-U.S. ties have been strained in the past year because of disagreement over Middle East policies and the American dialogue with the PLO, which Israel considers a terrorist organization. Haaretz said aides to Levy were annoyed by statements made Friday by Shamir's top political adviser, Yossi Ben-Aharon. Ben-Aharon suggested on Army radio that Israel wanted to shelve peace proposals raised last year by Secretary of State James A. Baker III as a way to revive Israel's stalled initiative for Palestinian elections. ``We are asking to start from the beginning,'' Ben-Aharon said. According to Haaretz, Levy's aides considered the remark, among others coming from Shamir's office, to be ``unneccesary instigation at a sensitive moment.'' Haaretz did not say what was in the censored message to Cairo. It said Ben-Aharon sent it to the Israeli Embassy in Egypt last week and that Levy ordered staff members not to deliver it. The newspaper said Levy was angry that he had not been consulted before the message was sent to Egypt, the only Arab country to make peace with Israel and a key middleman in negotiations with the Palestinians. Shamir himself sharply criticized the United States today for continuing a dialogue with the PLO despite an aborted seaborne attack May 30 that was claimed by a PLO faction. ``Week after week passes and they are still holding consultations, there in the political offices in the United States, about whether indeed the PLO is still a terrorist organization,'' Shamir told students in a speech in a Tel Aviv suburb. The United States has demanded that the PLO condemn the aborted raid as a condition for continuing diplomatic contacts that began 18 months ago in the PLO's home base of Tunis. So far the PLO has only indirectly criticized the action.

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal Denies He Supports Excommunicating Pro-Choice Politicians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `If such...', to end with 6 grafs to CORRECT typo in `persist,' add further quote from O'Connor on difference between having a power to penalize and using it; restore dropped name of program in penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal John J. O'Connor says a newspaper column he wrote last week should not have been interpreted to mean he supports excommunicating Catholic politicians who support abortion rights. O'Connor said Sunday the column instead was intended to help prevent excommunications. ``We don't want to see people excommunicated,'' O'Connor said at a news conference. ``We're talking about ... trying in every way possible to bring it about that individuals won't excommunicate themselves.'' ``I have never threatened to excommunicate anybody; I have never suggested that any other bishop excommunicate anybody; I have no intention of excommunicating anybody,'' he added. In the column in the Archdiocese of New York's weekly paper, the cardinal said Roman Catholic officials risked being excommunicated for supporting a woman's right to choose abortion. Those at risk, he wrote, are Catholics who ``are perceived not only as treating Church teaching on abortion with contempt, but helping to multiply abortions by advocating legislation supporting abortion, or by making public funds available for abortion.'' ``If such actions persist,'' he wrote, ``bishops may consider excommunication the only option.'' But he also read a portion of the column Sunday that said: ``To have the power to impose penalties and to use that power ... are two different things.'' Excommunication is a rarely used sanction that bars a Catholic from most sacraments. In an interview televised Sunday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Catholic who says he is personally opposed to abortion but supports abortion funding, reaffirmed his pro-choice position. Cuomo said on WNBC-TV's ``News Forum'' program that he still favored public funding for abortion. But he said no Catholic could feel good about a cardinal suggesting his soul was in peril. ``I love being governor,'' said Cuomo. ``I wouldn't do it if I thought I were risking my soul.''

DOC.HEAD: Dry Rot Blamed In Balcony Collapse That Injured 14
DOC.TEXT: Weekend revelers dancing on a wooden balcony plunged eight feet to the ground when the rotting structure collapsed and hit at least two people underneath, officials said. Fourteen people were injured Saturday at the fourth annual Summer Fest, including two women caught under the balcony who were seriously hurt. About 20 people were dancing on the 8-by-10-foot balcony of a historic building during the arts and wine festival. The two women caught underneath suffered back injuries and were listed in serious but stable condition at San Jose Medical Center Sunday. A triangular support decayed because it was not treated to withstand wet weather, said Scott Baker, city director of building services. The accident occurred in the rear of the city's Old Town shopping center, a historic Spanish-style elementary school converted to house shops. Building officials will inspect Old Town for other structural problems, but finding the dry rot would have been difficult during normal maintenance and inspections because it was ``virtually hidden,'' Baker said. Los Gatos is an affluent San Jose suburb on the eastern slope of the Santa Cruze Mountains, about 60 miles south of San Francisco. It was hard-hit by the 7.1 magnitude earthquake that hit Northern California in October.

DOC.HEAD: Party Chief Defends Policies In Letter To California Students
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press Writer= BEIJING (AP) _ Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin, in a long letter to nine California university students, defended last year's military suppression of the pro-democracy movement. He acknowledged that the disintegration of communist rule in Eastern Europe was a ``setback'' for socialism but said China will not tolerate opposition to its socialist system. The official Xinhua News Agency today carried the text of the letter it said was written to nine political science students from California State Polytechnic University in San Luis Obispo. It said Ma Yuzhen, China's consul-general in Los Angeles, delivered the letter to the students on Friday. Xinhua said the students had asked about China's current policies in a March 8 letter to Jiang. Jiang, repeating previous government statements, said authorities displayed ``maximum patience'' toward student demonstrators last year. He said the military was only called in when a small number of agitators used the student unrest in an attempt to overthrow the Communist Party and the government. He said the Western press ``concocted a lot of false, sensational stories'' about the crackdown, in which hundreds and perhaps thousands were killed. Some foreigners, he said, ``based their judgment merely on their own values.'' Jiang said China wants good relations with the United States, but in an apparent reference to U.S. criticism of China's human rights record, he denounced ``foreign interference and bullying.'' Jiang became party general secretary last June after his predecessor Zhao Ziyang was purged for supporting the students. He indirectly criticized Zhao, saying ``divergent views'' on how to respond to the democracy movement pushed the nation to the brink of disintegration. Jiang said China's people today are ``living and working in peace and contentment, (with) extensive democratic rights and freedom unseen in our history.'' He noted the demise of Communist governments in Eastern Europe but said ``one should not conclude from this that socialism has failed or collapsed.'' Thousands of students and other activists from last year's democracy movement remain in prisons without being formally charged. Leaders of the movement have been accused of ``counterrevolutionary'' crimes. The closest Jiang came to expressing regret over the bloodshed was when he said China should learn from the West and ``keep a certain amount of police force armed with necessary non-lethal weapons'' to put down disturbances. He urged Chinese who participated in pro-democracy demonstrations while studying in foreign countries to return, saying they would not be punished. It was Jiang's latest defense in the United States of last year's June 3-4 crackdown. In an interview last month on ABC's ``20-20'' television news program, he said the Western outcry over the killings was ``like much ado about nothing.''

DOC.HEAD: Hero of Chernobyl Disaster Described As Gravely Ill
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet helicopter pilot hailed as a hero for trying to douse the meltdown at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor was near death today after a lung infection worsened during leukemia treatments. Anatoly Grishchenko, 53, was listed in critical condition at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center with a high fever and a lung infection. He has been on a respirator since early Friday. Grishchenko showed no signs of improvement and doctors said his chance of surviving the infection were poor, center spokeswoman Susan Edmonds said Sunday. ``He's the same, there's been no changes,'' she said. ``My understanding is he's sedated but cognizant of what's going on around him. He does recognize people who are there.'' His wife, Galina, and a cousin were with him, Ms. Edmonds said. Grishchenko was stricken by the infection last week, after undergoing a bone-marrow transplant to fight leukemia linked to radiation exposure. Grishchenko repeatedly flew his heavy-lift copter through the intensely radioactive gases spewing from the Chernobyl plant, dumping sand and cement in an overmatched effort to cap the crippled reactor. He and a handful of others in the operation were designated heroes of the Soviet Union, that country's highest honor. At least 31 deaths are officially blamed on the April 26, 1986, explosion and fire at the plant in the Ukraine, and scientists say many more people may eventually be stricken with radiation-related diseases. Despite lead shielding on the aircraft and other protective gear, Grishchenko suffered radiation sickness and was found to have pre-leukemia in September 1988. He was diagnosed with acute myelocytic leukemia late last year. ``A lot of people are praying for him,'' said Cap Parlier of Mesa, Ariz., an administrator for McDonnell Douglas Corp. Parlier arranged for the transplant after hearing of Grishchenko's plight from a Soviet colleague during the 1989 Paris Air Show. He arrived in Seattle April 11 for the marrow transplant, which was performed April 27, after he underwent chemotherapy and radiation treatment to kill off his own marrow. The pre-transplant therapy leaves patients with no natural immunity against disease until the new marrow, which is transplanted intravenously, takes hold, Ms. Edmonds said. Grishchenko had been in stable condition and doctors were expecting a normal recovery when they decided Tuesday to operate to remove a fungal infection in his right lung. Antibiotics had failed to knock down the potentially life-threatening infection, which Grishchenko developed before coming to Seattle, she said. The surgery was successful and Grishchenko appeared to be doing fine until Thursday night, when he developed the high fever and breathing problems. Doctors had waited until Grishchenko appeared strong enough to tolerate the surgery, but the procedure may have ben too much for his weakened system.

DOC.HEAD: Genscher, Shevardnadze Meet on German Unification
DOC.TEXT: The West German and Soviet foreign ministers met today at the site where Germany's divisive Thirty Years War ended, hoping to resolve issues involving Germany's latest attempt at unity. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and his Soviet counterpart, Eduard Shevardnadze, sat down at a table with advisers in the old armament room of Muenster's town hall. Their talks, the second in two weeks, were expected to last several hours. ``We want our accomplishments to be in the interests of the German nation and contribute to building up of a new Europe, and we are moving in that direction,'' Shevardnadze said during a welcoming ceremony in the Peace Hall. The building is where Germany's rival Protestant and Roman Catholic forces _ along with their respective European allies _ signed a treaty ending the 1618-48 war, fought mainly in Germany. Shevardnadze said previous talks on the international aspects of German unity had gone well, and that he and Genscher would try to find further common ground at the meeting, which was expected to focus on the military stance of a united Germany. ``We have to ... find a common language on problems that haven't been solved yet. These problems are complicated, but we're of good will,'' he said through an interpreter. The meeting in Muenster comes one week after Genscher and Shevardnadze met in the Soviet city of Brest near the border with Poland. It is their second meeting on the international aspects of German unification since President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev discussed the historic developments at their Washington summit earlier this month. Genscher and Shevardnadze also have held previous discussions on German unity. The Soviet Union and the Western allies have been locked in a dispute over the military alignment of a unified Germany. West Germany, the United States and their allies have insisted on NATO membership for the new German state, but the Soviet Union has resisted. However, U.S. officials in Washington have said in the last few weeks the Soviets appear to softening their opposition. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has been promoting a nine-point program of assurances and incentives to help ease Soviet concerns. Over the weekend, Genscher told a meeting of West and East German members of his Free Democratic Party that unification could only be reached with the Soviet Union support. The Free Democrats are part of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's governing coalition. Genscher said the Soviet Union must become part of Europe.
