He said the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe must produce political, military and cultural structures that will bind the Soviet Union to a future Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Hear Appeal of Columbia, S.C., Officials and Ad Company
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to hear an appeal by Columbia, S.C., officials and a billboard company jointly found to have violated federal antitrust law. The court said it will review a ruling that the city and company conspired to exclude a rival advertising firm from putting up new billboards. The rival company, Omni Outdoor Advertising Inc., was awarded $3 million by a federal jury in 1986. The award was overturned by a trial judge but reinstated last December by the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The appeals court ordered Columbia Outdoor Advertising Inc. to pay the sum, and barred city officials from enforcing an ordinance the appeals court said was aimed at giving that company a virtual billboard monopoly in the city. Omni's lawsuit said Columbia Outdoor Advertising established its dominance in the city through the lifelong friendship of its principal owner, J. Willis Cantey, with Mayor Kirkman Finlay. He no longer is Columbia's mayor. The jury also heard evidence that Columbia Outdoor Advertising gave Finlay and Columbia City Council members either free or reduced-rate space on its billboards for their political ads. The council in 1982 adopted a moratorium on billboard construction that blocked Omni from entering the market. After a state court declared the moratorium unconstitutional, it was replaced the same year with an ordinance requiring billboards be at least 1,000 feet apart. The new law had the effect of preventing Omni from putting up signs. The 4th Circuit court said the Supreme Court has granted cities a broad exemption from federal antitrust law when they enact anti-competitive rules in accord with state policies. But the appeals court said the exemption does not permit the type of behavior engaged in by Columbia officials. ``Sufficient evidence supports the jury's finding that there was a conspiracy between the city and Columbia Outdoor Advertising,'' the appeals court said. The city was ``participating in the conspiracy solely for the purposes of restraint of trade and monopolization.'' The appeals court said the city is immune from paying damages because of a federal law that exempts local governments from such awards. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for the city and Columbia Outdoor Advertising said the company engaged in ``wholly legitimate and successful lobbying of city officials'' to restrict outdoor advertising in the city. The case is City of Columbia vs. Omni Outdoor Advertising, 89-1671.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Agrees To Review Ruling on Texas Thrift
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to consider killing a lawsuit by a Texas businessman who says federal regulators caused the financial ruin of his failed savings and loan association. The court said it will review a ruling that revived part of Thomas M. Gaubert's negligence suit against the government. The suit alleges the federal regulators who assumed day-to-day operation of the Irving-based Independent American Savings Association ran it out of business. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last Oct. 17 reinstated that part of the suit in which Gaubert is seeking compensation for $25 million worth of real estate he lost when the thrift went bust. The appeals court, however, did not let Gaubert pursue his bid to collect from the government the $75 million lost value of his Independent American shares. Gaubert, a prominent political fundraiser who persuaded former House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, to intervene with federal regulators on his behalf, acquired a controlling interest in what was to be known as Independent American in 1983. The rapidly expanding S&L proposed in 1984 to merge with Investex Savings, a failing Texas thrift, and purchase 22 branch offices from United Savings Association. According to Gaubert's suit, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board favored the merger but postponed approval. Government lawyers said regulators were awaiting completion of an investigtion into Gaubert's dealings with an Iowa thrift, Capitol Savings and Loan. Before approving the merger, the bank board persuaded Gaubert to sign a ``neutralization agreement'' that effectively removed him from Independent American affairs. Gaubert also personally guaranteed Independent American's minimal net worth with real estate worth over $25 million. In 1985, he agreed to remove himself permanently from Independent American's management and not to serve as an officer or director of any institution insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. Federal officials subsequently assisted Independent American in its merger with Investex. ``Federal involvement came as a result of the inherent persuasive power of the FHLBB, which no doubt rises from the position of authority it occupies,'' the 5th Circuit court recounted. ``The government euphemistically refers to this ability to pressure S&Ls as jawboning.'' The thrift's board of directors was replaced under bank board supervision, and in 1986 a former federal regulator was installed as Independent American's chief operating officer. In May 1987, the Texas Savings and Loan Department closed Independent American, and the bank board appointed the FSLIC as a receiver. After an unsuccessful administrative claim, Gaubert sued under a law that in some instances waives the federal government's sovereign immunity. The law, the Federal Tort Claims Act, does not allow lawsuits based on federal employees' discretionary duties _ and government lawyers cited that exception in seeking to have Gaubert's suit dismissed. A federal trial judge threw out the suit, but the 5th Circuit court reinstated it. The appeals court said past Supreme Court rulings have distinguished discretionary and day-to-day operational duties when deciding whether lawsuits against the government should be allowed. Federal regulators ``were only protected by the (law's) discretionary function exception until their actions became operational in nature and thus crossed the line,'' the appeals court said. The case is U.S. vs. Gaubert, 89-1793.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Right To Jury Trial in Hank Williams Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to kill a lawsuit in which a woman who claims to be Hank Williams Sr.'s daughter seeks some of the late country music legend's copyright royalties. The justices, without comment, let stand a federal appeals court ruling that Cathy Yvonne Stone, 37, is entitled to have her legal fight put before a jury. At the same time, the court rejected an appeal by country singer Hank Williams Jr. that sought to reverse an Alabama Supreme Court ruling that declared Ms. Stone a legal heir to the elder Williams. Named as defendants in Ms. Stone's royalties suit are Hank Jr. and other copyright owners. Ms. Stone was born in Alabama five days after Williams died at age 29 in 1953. Her mother, Bobbie Jett, and Williams had signed an agreement months earlier in which he acknowledged he might be the father of the then-unborn child. The girl first was adopted by Lillian Stone, Williams' mother. After Mrs. Stone died, the child was adopted by George and Mary Deupree. The Deuprees in 1967 refused to be included in court proceedings to determine whether Williams had fathered any children other than Hank Jr. Mrs. Deupree first told her adopted daughter in 1973 that the elder Williams might have been her father. But Ms. Stone did not take any immediate legal action to establish her real parentage. Soon after marrying attorney Keith Adkinson in 1985, Ms. Stone filed federal and state court lawsuits seeking a share of Williams' songwriting royalties. State courts in Alabama initially ruled that she was Williams' daughter but not a legal heir. The federal lawsuit was dismissed by the New York-based 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in April 1989. Presuming that Williams was Ms. Stone's father, the appeals court said she had waited too long before suing. Ms. Stone then appealed to the nation's highest court, but the justices rejected her appeal last November. Meanwhile, the Alabama Supreme Court last July reversed lower state court rulings that had denied Ms. Stone status as an heir. The state Supreme Court ruled that some of the defendants _ but not Hank Jr. _ had intentionally and fraudulently concealed Ms. Stone's identity and legal rights. The 2nd Circuit court, citing the Alabama Supreme Court's ruling, set aside its April 1989 ruling last Dec. 5. ``The evidence of fraud'' excuses Ms. Stone's delay in taking legal action, the appeals court said. It added: ``The figure representing justice is blindfolded so that the scales are held even, but justice is not blind to reality. (Ms. Stone) therefore should have her day in court and an opportunity to have a jury determine the merits of her claim.'' In the royalties case appeal acted on today, lawyers for Hank Williams Jr. and the other copyright owners argued, among other things, that the Supreme Court's denial of review last November should have ended the federal case. They said the appeals court was not authorized to grant a rehearing after the high court turned down Ms. Stone's initial appeal. Ms. Stone has begun her own country-singing career, using the stage name Jett Williams. The cases are Williams vs. Stone, 89-1538 and 89-1563.

DOC.HEAD: Court Leaves Intact Decision on Boston University Professor
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact a decision forcing Boston University to grant a lifetime professor's job to a woman found to have been a victim of sex bias. The court, without comment, rejected arguments that requiring the university to grant her tenure interferes with its academic freedom. A key issue in the case of English literature professor Julia Prewitt Brown was the admissibility of trial evidence allegedly showing university president John Silber harbored sexist attitudes. Silber is on leave from the university to seek the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in Massachusetts. The university argued that evidence of Silber's alleged sexism should not have been presented to a federal jury that awarded Ms. Brown $200,000. A judge added $15,000 to compensate Ms. Brown for emotional distress, and ordered the university to reinstate her with lifetime tenure. Ms. Brown currently is teaching at Providence University in Rhode Island, where she has received tenure. She said she would return to Boston University if the university lost its Supreme Court appeal in the decade-long dispute. Ms. Brown had been teaching at BU for six years when she became eligible for tenure in 1979. An English department committee voted, 22-0, that she receive tenure, and its recommendation was supported, 9-2, by a university committee. But Silber opposed tenure and recommended instead that Ms. Brown remain on probation for three more years. Silber relied in part on a report by the university provost questioning Ms. Brown's scholarly credentials. She had published a book of criticism on Jane Austen's novels that generally was well reviewed by other scholars. But the provost said the university should await further evidence of Ms. Brown's abilities before awarding tenure. After Ms. Brown rejected the offer of three more years on probation, the university board of trustees denied her tenure. When her lawsuit reached a trial, evidence was introduced of Silber's alleged sexism. It included a remark he made describing the English department as ``a damn matriarchy'' at a time when the department was headed by a woman and included six female and 20 male faculty members. Silber also had told another woman on the faculty that she should not be worried about job security since ``your husband is a parachute,'' an apparent reference to the fact her husband was employed. The jury also heard a portion of an old speech by Silber in which he lamented the lack of parental supervision in families in which both husbands and wives work outside the home. The 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in ruling last year for Ms. Brown, refused to order a new trial in which the Silber remarks would be excluded. The appeals court also rejected the university's arguments that awarding Ms. Brown a lifetime job interfered with its academic freedom. ``Academic freedom does not include the freedom to discriminate against tenure candidates on the basis of sex or other impermissible grounds,'' the appeals court said. ``Awarding (Ms. Brown) tenure is the only way to provide her the most complete relief possible.'' The American Council on Education, representing some 1,500 colleges and universities, supported the university's appeal. The American Association of University Professors urged the high court to reject the appeal. The case is Boston University vs. Brown, 89-1680.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Fine Against Maryland Man for Loud Preaching Against Abortions
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact the conviction and $250 fine of a man cited for preaching too loudly outside a Hagerstown, Md., abortion clinic. The justices, without comment, refused to hear arguments that the state law used to prosecute Jerry Wayne Eanes violates free-speech rights. Maryland's highest court rejected those arguments by a 4-3 vote last February. The challenged state law makes it a crime to disturb the peace in public places ``by making loud and unseemly noises.'' Eanes was arrested outside the Hagerstown Reproductive Clinic on May 18, 1988 while preaching on the city sidewalk outside the clinic. The police officer who arrested Eanes had previously asked him to lower his voice, and said Eanes continued to shout. There was testimony that Eanes could be heard over a block away. Although Eanes was arrested during business hours on a busy downtown street, the neighborhood has several residential apartment buildings. Police received complaints from residents about the loudness of Eanes' voice, but not about his message. Eanes did not try to restrain anyone who entered or left the abortion clinic. He did not try to block access to the clinic, threaten anyone, trespass on private property or use profanity. A day before his arrest, Eanes had been acquitted in the Washington County Circuit Court for allegedly making ``loud and unseemly noises'' in front of the same abortion clinic on in July 1987. Eanes had not returned to the clinic until his acquittal. Judge Frederick C. Wright III found Eanes guilty of ``willfully disturbing the peace and tranquility of that particular neighborhood (on May 18) by making loud and otherwise unacceptable ... noises.'' The judge said Eanes' loud preaching was ``improper under the circumstances.'' The Maryland Court of Appeals last February upheld the misdemeanor conviction, ruling that the law was aimed at the manner of Eanes' communication, not its content. ``Judge Wright properly balanced Eanes' First Amendment rights against a substantial public interest protected by a narrowly drawn, content-neutral regulation,'' the state court said. The three dissenting judges voted to overturn Eanes' conviction. ``Eanes was entitled to deliver an unamplified speech on the topic of abortion from a public sidewalk in downtown Hagerstown during the late morning,'' the dissenters said. ``To punish as criminal the making of the speech, purportedly because it was too loud, distorts both the statute and our basic constitutional guarantees.'' The case is Eanes vs. Maryland, 89-1745.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MOSCOW
Soviet Pilot Lands Plane, Requests Asylum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with plane landing in Turkey, pilot asking for asylum, other details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet pilot landed a small plane on a beach on the Black Sea coast today and requested political asylum, a government official said. The official Soviet news agency Tass reported in Moscow that an AN-2 plane was hijacked in Izmail, near the Ukrainian port of Odessa. The Turkish official, who requested anonymity, said the pilot was alone in the 12-seat Soviet passenger plane when it landed near Kumcagiz village in Kocaeli province at 1:30 p.m. There are no airports in the province, and the plane landed on a beach known as Kefken, the official said. The official said the Soviets immediately asked Turkey to return the plane and the pilot. The semiofficial Anatolia news agency identified the pilot as Valeri Yurevic, 29. He was reportedly taken to a police station for questioning. Tass said the pilot had resigned several months ago from his job with an Odessa air crew. It did not give further details.

DOC.HEAD: New York City Preens for Mandela Visit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `The proceedings...', to CORRECT that 14 sted 13 nations included in tour.
DOC.TEXT: When Nelson Mandela steps off his borrowed private jet Wednesday, the man many regard as a modern civil rights hero will be greeted by New York City at its best _ and its worst. There will be a ticker-tape parade and traffic jams; diplomatic meetings and media circuses; adoring crowds and hostile protesters; speeches of sweeping scope and T-shirt proclamations. For the deputy leader of the African National Congress, released in February after 27 years in South African jails, it will be his first view of the United States. And for the city, disrupted at times by its own racial, ethnic, political and economic animosities, it could be a rare moment of self-appraisal. ``The fact that this is the first stop gives the average New Yorker a great sense of pride,'' said Jean Owensby, a local spokeswoman for Mandela's national tour. ``If there's a time to come together, this is it.'' In a city so big, togetherness is a relative thing. A Bronx rabbi, Avi Weiss, announced he will hold a prayer vigil to protest Mandela's friendly relations with the Palestine Liberation Organization. But planning for the visit has mainly drawn cooperation. There are the small details, such as the Trans Lux Corp.'s donation of 100 miles of ticker tape. And there are the major ones, such as producer Bill Graham's volunteer work organizing a concert and rally for 60,000 people at Yankee Stadium. Like Mandela, ``I came out of a suppressed society,'' said Graham, a Jew born in Berlin. ``There is something about freedom of expression that's always meant a great deal to me, and a great deal to all of us.'' Mandela also will raise money at star-studded fund-raisers _ including one with Robert De Niro as host _ and lobby for his cause at a session with business leaders. He will address the U.N. General Assembly and submit to interviews, including an hour and a half with ABC's Ted Koppel. The proceedings will be similar in the other cities on Mandela's 10-day tour, which is part of a 14-nation, six-week tour of the world. Gatherings are scheduled at Tiger Stadium in Detroit, the Los Angeles Coliseum and the Oakland Coliseum. Bostonians are planning a luncheon at the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and a public reception at Boston Common. In Miami, he is to address the convention of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. In Atlanta, he is expected to stop at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center and will receive an honorary degree from a group of black colleges. The political peak will be in Washington, where he meets with President Bush and addresses a joint session of Congress. The highlights in New York include a motorcade Wednesday morning through Brooklyn and then the parade up lower Broadway in Manhattan to City Hall, where Mayor David Dinkins will give Mandela the key to the city. Mandela will spend Wednesday, Thursday and Friday nights at Gracie Mansion, the mayor's residence. ``I would be delighted to be just standing in the throng, just one of those persons in the audience, listening to him, looking at him,'' Dinkins said. ``And so to be in a position to welcome him in an official capacity as mayor of the city and to have him stay at Gracie Mansion is beyond my fondest dreams. I just never envisioned anything as wonderful and as great as this.'' Another major gathering is Thursday evening in Harlem, where Mandela will address what organizers say will be as many as 100,000 people. Then, Thursday night at Yankee Stadium, 60,000 are expected at an ANC fund-raiser, with tickets selling for $5 to $25. Billy Joel, who plays the stadium the next two nights, is lending the rally his production equipment. Graham and tour planners have declined to identify which bands will perform, saying they want the focus to remain on Mandela and his cause. That will not be difficult for people like Owensby, who were too young to have joined the civil rights marches of the 1960s. ``This is like me witnessing history for the first time in my life,'' she said. ``I'm about to bust.''

DOC.HEAD: India Agrees to Talks with Pakistan on Easing War Tension
DOC.TEXT: India and Pakistan agreed today to hold talks to try to ease the threat of war over the disputed northern region of Kashmir. An Indian government spokesman said top officials of the nations will meet early next month but that the date and location had not been decided. The Foreign Ministry spokesman could not be indentified under briefing rules. In Islamabad, Pakistan's foreign secretary, Tanvir Ahmed Khan, confirmed the proposed meeting. ``I think this is a welcome development,'' he said. ``This could be a good beginning.'' A dispute over the Kashmir Valley has brought the neighbors close to their fourth war since they gained independence from Britain in 1947. India and Pakistan both claim Kashmir, a predominately Moslem state that joined mainly Hindu India when Britain partitioned the subcontinent along religious lines. The territory is divided between the nations by a cease-fire line, and the armies of both countries have massed troops and artillery along the border. Talk of war has disturbed many countries because both nations are believed to possess nuclear weapons technology. India exploded an atomic device in 1974. Two of the three previous India-Pakistan wars, fought in 1948 and 1965, have been over Kashmir. Both were won by India. India accuses Pakistan of arming and training Moslem Kashmiri militants who are fighting for independence from India. Pakistan denies the charges. However, Islamabad has often said it supports the Kashmiri secession, calling it a movement for self-determination. India launched a crackdown on the separatist movement on Jan. 20. Since then, more than 550 people have died in the valley, mostly independence activists or their supporters. In May, a deputy U.S. national security adviser, Robert Gates, traveled to Pakistan and India to urge them to open talks. Western diplomats in New Delhi today credited the Gates' visit and Soviet pressure with helping to defuse the situation slightly. ``The Americans read the Pakistanis the riot act and the Soviets have done the same to the Indians,'' said a Middle Eastern military official. ``Now we have some hope.'' The Indian Foreign Ministry spokesman said the decision today was taken after a meeting between Indian Foreign Secretary Muchkund Dubey and Pakistan's ambassador, Bashir Khan Babar.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Seated, Sequestered in Mayor's Cocaine, Perjury Trial
DOC.TEXT: A jury was seated today in the cocaine and perjury trial of Mayor Marion Barry and was immediately placed in the care of U.S. marshals for the duration of the case. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson scheduled opening statements in the case for Tuesday morning and said the jurors will be sworn in at that time. The judge told them they would collect their belongings and be sequestered. The panel of 12 people plus six alternates includes 13 blacks and five whites. There are just three men among the 18 people. Barry, 54, is black, and a number of prospective jurors questioned in the past two weeks said they thought race and politics played a role in the investigation and prosecution of the three-term mayor. During the trial, the group of 18 won't be told which are jurors and which are being held as alternates. U.S. marshals will transport them between the U.S. Courthouse and an area hotel, where they will be housed until the trial is over. Barry is charged with 10 counts of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his alleged involvement with drugs. Many of the prospective jurors questioned for Barry's trial expressed strong opinions about the case and the FBI sting operation that led to the Washington mayor's arrest. The 18 were drawn from a group of 81 people approved during two weeks of questioning. Barry announced last week that he would not seek re-election to a fourth term as mayor of the District of Columbia. Plea bargaining discussions haven't produced any agreement that would avert a trial. Sources familiar with the case say U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens is insisting Barry plead guilty to a felony, which would almost certainly mean at least a short jail term. On Friday, defense lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy said there was ``nothing going on'' except preparations for a trial. The jury that will sit in judgment of the mayor was drawn from a group that includes: _An art teacher at a private school who said she would have difficulty presuming Barry's innocence. _A retired Census Bureau worker who said the FBI sting operation aimed at Barry was an invasion of the mayor's privacy. _A man who said he thought it was unfair for the FBI to bring ex-model Rasheeda Moore all the way from Los Angeles to help them catch Barry smoking crack cocaine in a hotel room. ``The videotape should not have been done,'' the man said of the undercover operation. Despite these responses and similar answers by numerous other potential jurors, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson made them eligible to serve on the jury. All said they would be fair and impartial if they sat as jurors, even though they had strong opinions about aspects of the case and some voiced concern that the fact that Barry is black and a Democrat could have figured in the investigation. The judge disqualified more than 60 other people whose answers suggested they couldn't set aside their personal views and focus only on the evidence presented in the courtroom. But some of those who remain expressed doubts about their ability to be totally impartial. Mundy asked the art teacher if it was difficult to overcome a presumption of guilt. ``It is,'' she conceded. ``But I don't think it would be impossible.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Spares Federal Pension-Protection Program Potential Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 7-18, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today spared the federal program protecting the pensions of 30 million American workers from a potential financial crisis. By an 8-1 vote, the court broadened the authority of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to order employers to restore terminated pension plans. A federal appeals court limited such authority last year by setting aside the agency's order that LTV Corp. and its subsidiary, LTV Steel Co., restore three pension plans with unfunded liabilities of $2.3 billion. Today's decision reversed the appeals court ruling. Government lawyers told the justices the appeals court ruling, if not overturned, ``could lead to a financial crisis similar to that currently facing'' the government insurance program for the savings and loan industry. At issue was the agency's power to shift liability for pension payments back to an employer in what is called an ``anti-follow-on policy.'' Writing for the court, Justice Harry A. Blackmun said the policy ``is not contrary to clear congressional intent and is based on a permissible construction'' of federal law. In other action, the court: _ Buttressed the power of police to videotape and record and responses of suspected drunken drivers. By an 8-1 vote, the justices ruled that police did not violate a Pennsylvania man's rights when _ without warning him of his rights _ they recorded his answers to questions about his height, weight and color of his eyes. _ Ruled that a federal law reducing patent infringement protection for drug companies applies to medical devices. The court, by a 6-2 vote, refused to reinstate a $26.7 million award against Medtronic Inc. of Minneapolis. Eli Lilly and Co. of Indianapolis said Medtronic infringed patents on a device implanted in patients to correct potentially fatal heart rhythms. _ Agreed to consider killing a lawsuit by a Texas businessman who says federal regulators caused the financial ruin of his failed savings and loan association. The court said it will review a ruling that revived part of Thomas M. Gaubert's negligence suit against the government. The suit alleges the federal regulators who assumed day-to-day operation of the Irving-based Independent American Savings Association ran it right out of business. _ Refused to kill a lawsuit in which a woman who claims to be Hank Willilams Sr.'s daughter seeks some of the late country music legend's copyright royalties. The justices, without comment, let stand a federal appeals court ruling that Cathy Yvonne Stone, 37, is entitled to have her legal fight put before a jury. _ Left intact the conviction and $250 fine of a man cited for preaching too loudly outside a Hagerstown, Md., abortion clinic. The justices, without comment, refused to hear arguments that the state law used to prosecute Jerry Wayne Eanes violates free-speech rights. _ Rejected a challenge to California's day-care licensing system by a religiously affiliated pre-school center. The court, without comment, left intact rulings that the center's religious freedom was not violated by state licensing rules that include a ban on corporal punishment for children attending day-care centers. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, modeled after the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., is wholly owned by the federal government. Its board of directors is comprised of the secretaries of labor, treasury and commerce. The agency protects the pension benefits of the 30 million workers who participate in single-employer pension plans. When a pension plan is ended with insufficient money to satisfy promised benefits, the agency becomes the pension plan's trustee, taking over its assets and liabilities. The agency then pays _ with taxpayer money _ benefits workers had earned as of the date the pension plan ended. The PBGC in fiscal year 1988 paid $324.7 million in insured benefits to 113,000 retirees who participated in 1,476 terminated pension plans. The cost of the pension insurance is paid primarily by employers with active pension plans and by employers who terminate underfunded pension plans. But the PBGC has money problems of its own _ a $1 billion deficit. It currently lists assets of about $3.2 billion and liabilities of about $4.2 bilion. The PBGC's executive director, James B. Lockhart, told a congressional subcommittee last week the agency soon could be unable to meet its obligations. Lockhart told the subcommittee, ``The overall pension system is extremely healthy. We're not an S&L crisis. I don't think we'd have to go to the taxpayer for a bailout.'' But lawyers representing the PBGC previously had raised the S&L crisis analogy in briefs submitted to the Supreme Court. The Dallas-based LTV and its Cleveland-based LTV Steel subsidiary, after filing for reorganization under federal bankruptcy law in 1986, advised the PBGC that they could not fund the three pension plans they sponsored. The plans were ended in 1987. In a deal with the United Steelworkers union, however, LTV Steel agreed to what government lawyers contended is a ``follow-on'' arrangement. Under it, LTV agreed to make up any benefits lost to retirees because of the pension plan's termination _ those benefits not covered by the federal pension insurance program. The result: retirees continued to receive the same benefits they did before the plans were terminated, and payment of underfunded pension liabilities was shifted to the PBGC. LTV was responsible for $75 million in annual supplemental retirement benefits, and the federal agency was picking up the tab for some $400 million in annual obligations to LTV pensioners. The PBGC contended such arrangements are abusive, and the agency ordered LTV to re-assume responsibility for the three pension plans. When LTV refused, the agency sought to enforce its order in federal court. A federal judge threw out the PBGC's order for restoration, and the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld that ruling. Both lower courts ruled that Congress never intended to give the agency the power to order restoration based on the creation of such ``follow-on'' benefit plans. In seeking the Supreme Court's help, lawyers for the PBGC said ``other companies will follow LTV's example and use pension insurance as a subsidy to reduce costs and gain a competitive edge.'' The PBGC estimates that the underfunding of pension plans it insures could run as high as $30 billion. Today, the high court ruled for the PBGC. Only Justice John Paul Stevens dissented. The court's ruling comes against a backdrop of serious problems in the administration of private pension programs. An Associated Press investigation last year found that one in four of the private pension plans audited by the government is violating the law. Fraud and mismanagement could wipe out the retirement nest eggs of millions of workers and saddle taxpayers with a multibillion-dollar bailout, experts told the AP. Nationwide, some 870,000 private pension plans hold assets of about $2 trillion dollars. Most claims for PBGC money have come from the steel industry, but Lockhart cautioned that his agency's $1 billion deficit could double if the PBGC has to bail out the financially ailing airlines industry. ``If they go bust, the taxpayer picks up the bill _ just like the S&Ls,'' said Joe McGowan of the Labor Department's inspector general's office. The case is PBGC vs. LTV, 89-390.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Police Arrest Second Alleged IRA Runaway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUB 5th pvs, `Neither of...' to UPDATE with identification of two men. SUB 6 grafs for 13th pvs, `The overwhelmingly...' to ADD background on Harte, IRA attacks; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police today arrested a man wearing handcuffs and said he was a suspected Irish Republican Army member who had escaped from Belgian authorities. Police in Belgium had apprehended three people Saturday and seized a car containing two handguns, an automatic rifle, ammunition and explosives. But two of those arrested and handcuffed managed to escape the authorities and flee to the Netherlands. Police said they arrested one of the suspects several hours later near the Dutch town of Ulvenhout. The second escapee was arrested today after a tip by residents, national police spokesman Stephan Worm said. Worm sad the suspect was still wearing handcuffs. A police bulletin broadcast by Dutch Television identified one of the two detainees as 27-year-old Gerard Majella Harte. The other suspect, about 30 years old, was identified only by his alias, Andrew Edward Thornton. Belgian police said the third suspect was a woman, and they identified her as Donna Maguire of Newry, Northern Ireland. Ms. Maguire, 23, was charged on Sunday with possessing a false U.S. passport, using a false name and criminal association. She is wanted in West Germany on IRA-related terrorist charges. Ms. Maguire was acquitted in February in Ireland of possessing explosives and switches used to detonate bombs. A companion, Leonard Hardy of Belfast, Northern Ireland, was convicted and sentenced to five years in prison. The court ruled there was no evidence Ms. Maguire knew what Hardy was carrying. Irish police said the two, arrested July 12 after stepping off a ferry from France to Rosslare, Ireland, carried several false passports and that Hardy had photographs of British army bases in Germany. West German authorities are seeking the arrest of Ms. Maguire, Hardy and three others for IRA attacks in Osnabrueck and Hanover that killed one British serviceman. Harte, of Lurgan, Northern Ireland, served a four-year sentence in Ireland for IRA-related offenses and was released in 1985. The British, meanwhile, had sought his extradition to Northern Ireland. Harte appealed to Ireland's supreme court and was granted bail pending a ruling. He was later convicted in Craigavon, Northern Ireland, of petrol bomb and arson charges stemming from incidents in 1979, and was sentenced to a year in prison. The overwhelmingly Roman Catholic IRA seeks to end British rule of Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland and unite it with the southern Irish Republic. It has conducted dozens of attacks against British military targets in West Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands. Last month, the IRA fatally shot two Australian tourists in the Netherlands because it mistook them for British soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Patent-Infringement Law Applies to Medical Devices
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today that a federal law reducing patent-infringement protection for drug companies applies to medical devices. The court, by a 6-2 vote, refused to reinstate a $26.7 million award against Medtronic Inc. of Minneapolis. Eli Lilly and Co. of Indianapolis said Medtronic infringed patents on a device implanted in patients to correct potentially fatal heart rhythms. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the court, upheld Medtronic's interpretation of a 1984 patent-infringement law. The statute applies to patented inventions as well as generic drugs, he said. Scalia said Medtronic did not infringe on Eli Lilly's patent as long as the activities of the former firm were reasonably related to the development of information necessary to obtain federal approval for its device. The case now goes back to a lower federal court to determine whether Medtronic met that condition. The 1984 law is intended to help generic drug manufacturers seeking to place their substitutes for patented drugs on the market as soon as patents expire. The law permits the generic drug firms to get information from the federal Food and Drug Administration and apply to the FDA for approval of their substitutes prior to expiration of the patented drugs. Also, as long as the purpose is related to its application to the FDA, the generic companies are allowed by law to ``make, use or sell a patented invention'' prior to the patent's expiration. Eli Lilly, with support from other major medical companies and patent holders, said applying the law to medical devices could undermine health care research and development of life-saving inventions. It said the pace of costly, innovative research will be slowed because patent holders will fear their work soon would be copied. But Medtronic said Eli Lilly is distorting economic reality. Medtronic said the value of the heart-implant devices it tested is less than $415,000. By contrast, it said, Eli Lilly is expected to sell more than $100 million worth of the devices before a two-year extension of its patent expires on Oct. 26, 1990. Medtronic said its new device is intended to treat cardiac distrubances painlessly with low-energy electrical impulses as a substitute for the higher-energy shocks that accompany the Lilly device. Lilly's appeal to the Supreme Court was supported by Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, sponsor of the 1984 legislation, and Rep. Carlos Moorhead, R-Pa., floor manager of the bill in the House. The case is Eli Lilly vs. Medtronic Inc, 89-243.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Cloud Forces 1,500 To Evacuate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with evacuation order canceled, new, reduced estimate on number of evacuees; CORRECT that plant makes cleaning materials, sted chemicals for paint and plastics; add status of 15 taken to hospitals. No pickup. Irl is cq in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A cloud of fumes spewing from a chemical plant forced about 1,500 people from their homes for several hours today, authorities said. Fifteen people were taken to hospitals. The injured were treated for burning eyes and throats, skin irritation and nausea after fumes vented a tank at the Alcolac Inc. plant around midnight. All were released, city administrator Irl Tessendorf said. Plant manager Richard Faulkner identified the chemical as allyl methracylate. Tessendorf said the fumes, which dissipated before dawn, would cause serious health problems only in strong doses. The evacuation order was canceled about 8 a.m., Tessendorf said. Pressure from a chemical reaction caused a tank to vent the fumes into the air, where it formed a cloud and began drifting southeast, said Fire Chief Mike Ditzfeld. A retirement home and other residences on the east side of Sedalia and several other small communities were evacuated. Medical teams were called out to treat residents who may have suffered skin irritations or other problems from the fumes. There was no fire at the plant, which manufactures soap and other cleaning materials. Faulkner said the accident was caused by either a mechanical or employee failure. The state Department of Natural Resources and the Department of Health were investigating the accident, he said. Sedalia is about 85 miles southeast of Kansas City and has a population of about 21,000.

DOC.HEAD: Searchers Find 21st Flood Victim; Little Hope for Missing
LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: The death toll from last week's flash floods mounted to 21 today when a body was found in the Ohio River, and authorities said there was little hope for the 14 people still listed as missing. ``It's just been too long. I don't think there's anybody alive out there. You can't swim out there that long in the Ohio River,'' said Chuck Vogt, Belmont County coroner's investigator. The search for the missing was suspended briefly this morning when a thunderstorm rolled through the area. Heavy rain fell for about 45 minutes, swelling Wegee Creek, one of two creeks that overflowed in Thursday night's flash flood. By midmorning, the muddy creek was nearly crossing a road about three miles upstream from where the floods inflicted the most damage. Lt. Dean Irvin of the Ohio Army National Guard said there were no immediate reports of additional property damage. The body found this morning was in the Ohio River near Moundsville, W.Va., about 10 miles south of Shadyside, according to Chuck Vogt, Belmont County coroner's investigator. The number of names on the list of missing dropped from 18 to 14 with the identities of three victims and a call by one person alerting authorities that she was safe, Vogt said. One of the recovered bodies remains unidentified. Authorities are not ruling out the possibility that other people not on the list could be missing. Four bodies were recovered Sunday. Officials said Friday that 60 people were missing; some of those later were found dead, while others notified authorities that they were safe and officials learned that still more had moved out of the area. Wegee and Pipe creeks overflowed during storms that dumped 5{ inches of rain in 3{ hours. The floods destroyed as many as 70 houses and damaged up to 40 others. Most of those whose homes and belongings were swept away by the wall of water will have to put their lives back together largely without benefit of insurance. Few people in the coal-mining and steel-making area carried flood insurance, and homeowners' insurance will not cover damage from Thursday's flood, residents and insurers said. ``We didn't think we needed to have flood insurance. For what? That creek never flooded. Then this. Everybody just got wiped out,'' said Julia Kulazenka. Rainwater running down hillsides had forced debris into the creeks and formed dams at bridges spanning them, Shadyside Fire Chief Mark Badia said. ``Eventually the bridges couldn't hold any more. The debris broke loose, and that's when we got three big gushes of water,'' Badia said. The home Mrs. Kulazenka shared with her husband until his death last July was damaged as Wegee Creek raged out of control. She said replacing a machine shop, garage, deck and automobiles she and her son owned would cost more than $80,000. ``They told us homeowners' won't do us no good. So unless the government helps us rebuild, I don't know what I'll do with this place,'' Mrs. Kulazenka said. The Federal Emergency Management Agency said it will open an office Tuesday in Shadyside to accept applications from residents for low-interest loans and grants to help them rebuild. Before the flood, land in the Wegee Creek valley fetched handsome prices, said Kulazenka's son, Charles Kulazenka. That was especially welcome to residents, many of whom were either retired or laid off from jobs in coal mines in Belmont County, where unemployment in April was 6.8 percent. ``Ground was at a premium down here before this because it was just outside the city limits (of Shadyside). It was quiet and peaceful and people were looking to buy and build new homes out here. Now, you couldn't give it away,'' Kulazenka said. ``But we can't be bitter, though, because we've got our lives, and a lot of our neighbors, real close buddies, weren't that lucky.''

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Boycott Urged
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group called on consumers today to boycott products containing a chemical used in such items as hornet sprays and art supplies, which it said is harming Earth's ozone layer. The Natural Resources Defense Council also accused the Bush administration of ``waffling'' in its position on an international agreement designed to curb production of the chemical, 1,1,1-trichloroethane, The NRDC said approximately 724 million pounds of the chemical, known as 1,1,1 for short, were produced in the United States in 1988. David Doniger, an attorney with the group, said 90 percent of the substance is used in industry, where it is an ingredient of solvents used to clean electronic and metal parts. Among consumer goods which contain the chemical, the NRDC said, are some of the varnishes and fixatives marketed by M. Grumbacher Inc., the art supply firm. Godfrey Chambers, technical services manager for Grumbacher, said by telephone from the firm's headquarters in Cranbury, N.J., that the company has eliminated 1,1,1 from some of its products and is hoping to get it eliminated from the ones listed. Chambers said the products _ Damar varnish, Myston, Retouch varnish and Tuffilm fixative _ are manufactured by a supplier and purchased by Grumbacher for resale. ``The person we purchase it from is continuing research in this matter to try and eliminate it,'' he said. ``Formerly, more of our aerosols did contain it, but through the process of research, we have been able to eliminate it,'' he said. ``It is a concern of the industry at large,'' Chambers said. Doniger said substitutes are available for 1,1,1 in most of its industrial and consumer uses. ``We recommend that consumers avoid buying products which contain 1,1,1-trichloroethane, or any other substance which contributes to the destruction of the stratospheric ozone layer,'' the council said. ``For most applications, there are alternative products on the market that serve the same purpose.'' The NRDC listed 141 products, but said there are more. The ones listed included hair sprays, spot removers, solvents and cleaners, furniture polish, water repellents, insecticides, automotive products and other office and household items. Doniger said he will be pressing for phasing out of 1,1,1 when representatives of more than 70 nations gather in London Wednesday under sponsorship of the United Nations Environmental Program to consider revisions to an international agreement on the ozone layer. ``The U.S. delegation is still waffling somewhere between a 25 percent rollback and a 100 percent phaseout by 2000,'' he said. ``Indications are that the European Community and Japan, and now the United States, are balking at going farther than 50 percent,'' he added. Some environmentalists say manmade chemicals are eating away the Earth's protective ozone shield, allowing more ultraviolet rays to reach the planet's surface. They contend this increases the risk of skin cancer, cataract formation and disruption of the environment.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Communists Win Control of Bulgarian Parliament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with opposition coalition winning 24 of 26 seats in Sofia, premier confident of coalition. Pickup 11th pvs, `The Communists...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The heirs of the Communist Party have won control of Parliament in Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years, but unofficial results today showed the capital firmly in opposition hands. Bulgaria's ruling Socialists are the only reform Communists to hold onto power in an Eastern Europe where authoritarian rule gave way to popular elections this year after decades of Soviet domination. Premier Andrei Lukanov today said he was confident he could form a government with broad support. He said he was encouraged by the main opposition coalition's support for a government of non-partisan administrators. Members of Bulgaria's Communist Party formed the Socialist Party and state-run Sofia radio said unofficial final results showed the Socialists won 39 of the 81 seats at stake in Sunday's run-offs. That would give them them a total of 211 seats in the 400-member Parliament. The main opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces, won 37 seats for a total of 144, the radio said. Among those were six more seats in Sofia to give the alliance 24 of the capital's 26 seats, unofficial counts showed. The opposition in this country of 9 million gets much of its backing from the urban intelligensia, while the Socialists are seen as a force for stability in the Balkan country's more conservative countryside. The Agrarian Party, a once docile ally of the Communists, won 16 seats in the June 10 first round and had no candidates in the runoff. Other smaller opposition groups and independents won a total of six seats. Official results were expected Tuesday. Non-Communists have triumphed in nationwide elections in East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Romania, although the party that swept last month's balloting in Romania has many former Communists in its leadership. The Communists have been a strong political force in Bulgaria for nearly a century and as the Socialist Party, the name they took in April, have essentially maintained political control of small towns and villages. Opposition leaders have accused the Socialists of using intimidation and fraud to secure votes. Foreign observers say they have not noted significant irregularities and Sunday's voting appeared to proceed smoothly at most polling sites. However, state television reported some irregularities, including illegal canvassing. Dimiter Ivanov, an activist from the Association for Fair Elections, said that in some cases, the number of people voting exceeded the number of people registered in the respective precincts. Outside a polling station in the town of Stanke Dimitrov, about 40 miles south of Sofia, a young soldier who refused to give his name said he voted for the Socialists ``because I want security, I am scared of the UDF.'' The opposition was only nascent when reform Communists ousted longtime Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov in November and had wanted the elections postponed until the fall to give it more time to organize. Shortly before the polls closed, state television said 75 percent of the eligible voters had cast ballots. In the first first round, 91 percent voted. The Socialists have proposed a coalition government of national unity, but the Union of Democratic Forces has resisted. The Socialist leader, Alexander Lilov, said in an interview published Sunday in the party daily Duma that if the opposition refuses to join a coalition his party will approach ``respected personalities'' to form a government of ``experts and professionals.'' Petar Beron, a Union of Democratic Forces leader, said today that his 16-party coalition would favor such a government if it were temporary: ``Such a government is usually a caretaker government, but it cannot rule the country for very long.'' The chief task of the new government will be tackling the country's $10 billion foreign debt, rising inflation and consumer goods shortages while gearing the economy toward capitalism. The Union of Democratic Forces favors sweeping private ownership and privatization of agriculture. The Socialists would prefer to leave some industry government-run for the time being and are vague on the future status of farming, which is currently government-owned or cooperative.

DOC.HEAD: Experiment Linking Welfare to School Attendance Praised, Criticized
DOC.TEXT: A Wisconsin experiment aimed at keeping welfare children in school was praised Monday as a long-term investment in youth and, at the same time, criticized as cruel and ineffective. The federal government is interested enough in the ``Learnfare'' concept, which cuts off welfare payments to families whose teen-agers miss class, to authorize an expansion. Supporters acknowledged it is too early to judge whether the program, begun in 1987, has worked. Patricia A. Goodrich, secretary of the Wisconsin Department of Health and Social Services, told a Senate Finance subcommittee hearing that Learnfare provides ``the unique opportunity to have a direct and positive influence on the futures of our children and, through them, the future of our state and nation.'' Learnfare covers 27,000 Wisconsin teen-agers whose parents receive Aid to Families with Dependent Children, and ``92 percent of those students are meeting the program's attendance requirements,'' Ms. Goodrich said. If a teen-ager whose parents receive welfare has more than two unexcused absences in a month, the family's welfare payment is cut by the amount normally included for the teen-ager's needs. Carol Croce, executive director of the Wisconsin Nutrition Project, said Learnfare exacerbates family situations already strained by poverty and the pressures of single parenting. ``Grants reduced by Learnfare sanctions have resulted in evictions and utility shutoffs and have forced some families into emergency shelters,'' Ms. Croce told the subcommittee. ``It has had a perverse and destructive effect on family structure by giving teens unwarranted control over the family's income.'' Even with the program, she added, ``We still don't know why these teens are absent from school.'' Backers of the program say that requiring teen-agers to stay in school will help break the cycle of poverty and prepare them for better jobs. The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services recently approved Wisconsin's proposal to expand the program to cover younger children. However, families of these children will not face a reduction in their welfare payments so long as parents cooperate with Learnfare case workers.

DOC.HEAD: Most of U.S. Soldiers Wounded in Panama Were Victims of U.S. Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds one graf of White House comment.
DOC.TEXT: Nine of the 23 U.S. soldiers killed in the invasion of Panama were accidentally slain by their comrades, and most of the Americans wounded were probably hit by friendly fire as well, Newsweek says. The apparent reason is that Americans did most of the shooting, the magazine reported in its June 25 issue, which goes on sale today. As many as 60 percent of the 347 U.S. soldiers wounded in the Dec. 20 attack were probably hit by fire from their comrades, and nine were killed by other American servicemen, Newsweek said, citing unidentified military sources. ``We just don't have any comment on that at this time,'' said Pentagon spokesman Ken Satterfield. The magazine also said it had learned the surprise attack was compromised by up to 15 different security leaks. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega knew at 10 p.m. the night before the invasion that there was a chance the United States would attack, Newsweek said. However, Noriega dismissed the reports, Newsweek said. The leaks came from girlfriends of U.S. soldiers in Panama, Panamanian customs agents who warned of arriving cargo planes and a Panamanian telephone operator at Fort Clayton who monitored calls about the invasion, the magazine said. Newsweek also said it had learned that, contrary to the Bush administration's insistence that the invasion was a last-minute response to provocation after a U.S. soldier was shot, plans for the invasion were approved by President Bush in November. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater declined today to respond to the report and said, ``We continue to believe that the Panama invasion was very effectively, efficiently carried out'' given the ``complexity of the operation.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Will Award Florida Soldier Back Pay
DOC.TEXT: An Army private who was demoted and thrown out of the service after his rifle was stolen will receive an honorable discharge and back pay, the service said today. The action involves Pfc. James Griffin III of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., whose case was the subject of a ``60 Minutes'' television report last month. Griffin was serving with Task Force Arriba in San Lorenzo, Honduras, in March 1989 when he was charged with loss of his rifle. The enlisted man contended that the rifle had been stolen but his U.S. superiors turned him over to Honduran authorities for interrogation. He was released 18 hours later after undergoing brutal questioning and was eventually returned to Fort Bragg, N.C., where five months later he was thrown out of the Army. The Army decision to reverse its earlier action was taken by the Army Board for the Correction of Military Records, according to Army spokesman Maj. Joe Allred. It calls for giving Griffin an honorable discharge, dated June 8, 1990, restoration to the rank of private first class and E-3 pay grade, and lifting a ban on his reenlistment. Allred said Griffin will receive full back pay and allowances for the period covering his initial discharge date of Sept. 19, 1989, to June 8, 1990, but that the exact amount has not yet been determined. The Army action came after the Pentagon's inspector general recommended that Griffin receive the honorable discharge. The inspector general said Griffin had been the victim of a ruse devised to obtain information about the lost weapon. Four Army officers stationed in Honduras with Griffin were involved in the affair. Three were given letters of reprimand while a fourth received verbal counseling.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas' First Execution in 26 Years Set for Tonight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Arkansas plans...', to CORRECT date of second pending execution to June 25 to June 26. INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf pvs, `The U.S....', to UPDATE with attorney saying no more legal action seen. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Swindler was...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Florida's Chair, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Barring a last-minute reprieve, John Edward Swindler tonight will become the first person executed in Arkansas since 1964. Swindler, 46, is scheduled to die in the electric chair at the state prison near Grady for the 1976 slaying of a policeman during a shootout while on the run from a double murder he committed in Columbia, S.C. Arkansas would become the 14th state to carry out an execution and Swindler the 130th inmate put to death since the U.S. Supreme Court in 1976 let states resume use of capital punishment. Arkansas plans another execution on June 25. Ronald Gene Simmons is to die by injection for the 1987 killings of 16 people, including 14 family members. Because Swindler was sentenced before Arkansas changed its method of execution from electrocution to injection, he was given a choice of either method. He left the choice up to prison officials, who selected the method originally specified in his sentence, electrocution. The U.S. Supreme Court denied a stay on Saturday. Only the intervention of Gov. Bill Clinton _ who last week denied clemency _ or a last-ditch appeal from Swindler's lawyers or another group could stop the 9 p.m. execution, Attorney General Steve Clark said. None of those scenarios appeared likely, Clark said. One of Swindler's attorneys, Gerald Coleman, said there would be no 11th-hour appeal from them. ``I'm not planning on doing anything. I know of no other plans of anybody else to file anything,'' Coleman said in a telephone interview today. ``We reviewed the case and took our best shot. There's nothing else that could be done that wouldn't be just a frivolous filing,'' he said. ``You could file most anything, making some allegation in just trying to delay it. Swindler was sentenced to die for the murder of Fort Smith police officer Randy Basnett, who was killed at a gas station after recognizing Swindler. At the time, Swindler was wanted for killing two people in South Carolina three days after his release from the federal prison at Leavenworth, Kan. Swindler, who was driving a stolen car, told authorities he was headed back to Kansas to kill as many people as he could for his treatment there. While awaiting execution in Arkansas, he was convicted of two murders in South Carolina and sentenced to four life terms. The last person executed in Arkansas was Charles Franklin Fields, who was electrocuted in 1964 for rape. About 50 members of the human rights group Amnesty International held a 26-minute vigil Sunday night commemorating 26 years without an execution in the state. Amnesty International member Cynthia Crawford read a statement imploring Clinton ``not to end the decency of the past 26 years by reinstituting this brutish form of violence.'' ``The members of Amnesty International in Arkansas are repulsed at this reactivation of this state's machinery of death,'' Crawford said. ``Just as Amnesty International opposes any use of torture, we also oppose executions, the ultimate form of torture.'' The group urged Clinton to grant clemency to Swindler and Simmons. Crawford urged citizens who oppose the death penalty to wear black armbands on the execution days. There was no counter-protest, but someone in a passing car shouted, ``Burn, Swindler, burn.'' Peggy Basnett, the mother of the policeman Swindler killed, also welcomed the execution. ``It will be a very happy occasion,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: High Court, in New Jersey Case, to Decide Effective Date of Drug Law
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today said it will decide the effective date for a 1986 federal law setting tough new minimum sentences for drug violations. At issue is whether the law's penalty provisions took effect in 1986 or 1987. The court agreed to hear an appeal by Moshe Gozlon-Peretz, who was convicted in New Jersey of conspiracy to distribute heroin and related offenses and was sentenced to 15 years in prison plus five years of supervised release after he completes his term. He also was fined $200,000. Gozlon-Peretz was caught in a Drug Enforcement Administration sting when he sold heroin to a federal agent in Atlantic City in February 1987. Gozlon-Peretz said he should not be subject to the five-year supervised release provisions of the 1986 law because those provisions did not become effective until Nov. 1, 1987 _ after the commission of the crime. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said the penalty provisions of the law took effect Oct. 27, 1986, the date the law was enacted. The case is Gozlon-Peretz vs. U.S., 89-7370.

DOC.HEAD: Rostenkowski To Mayors: No More Money for Cities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Rostenkowski saying big increase in money for cities unlikely; pick up 6th graf, `Sunday's votes ...
DOC.TEXT: The chief tax-writer of the House of Representatives today bluntly dashed the hopes of mayors seeking billions of dollars of the expected peace dividend for their cash-poor cities. ``There's no money to pay for such programs,'' House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski told the U.S. Conference of Mayors. ``The peace dividend is already going to be swallowed.'' Rostenkowski said budget negotiations between Congress and the White House are going ``fairly well.'' But he said the budget is unlikely to include more money for cities. ``We need to slash spending and raise taxes merely to reach ground zero,'' the Chicago Democrat told more than 200 mayors meeting in his home city. Two Democratic mayors challenged Rostenkowski to confront President Bush and demand that aid to cities be increased. They said the $500 billion or more needed to bail out the savings and loan industry should be found elsewhere. ``We haven't got the votes,'' Rostenkowski said. He broke off the questions and left the meeting after telling the mayors good-naturedly: ``I'm going to tell you like it is. If you don't like it, too bad.'' While the mayors expressed affection for Rostenkowski, a supporter of their causes, they did not like the message. ``The cities are in desperate need,'' said Atlanta Mayor Maynard Jackson. ``I really don't feel we have a partner in Washington.'' Rostenkowski said he was prepared to support an array of new taxes. But he said his fellow Democrats want Bush to be the first one to propose new taxes. Rostenkowski was the first of two congressional Democrats to address the mayors on the first full day of their summer meeting. Nebraska Sen. Robert Kerrey was to address the mayors at lunch. Rostenkowski delivered the dour message to the mayors a day after they gave initial approval to a broad, costly domestic agenda that calls on Congress to abandon the Gramm-Rudman law, complaining the deficit-reduction measure unfairly chops urban programs first. ``We're always first in line when it comes to cuts,'' New Bedford, Mass., Mayor John K. Bullard said Sunday as the mayors gave initial approval to a sweeping and costly domestic agenda that would get most of its money from a Congress that has been cutting aid to cities for a decade. Sunday's votes by the conference's key policy committee must be ratified by the full conference of more than 200 mayors on Wednesday, but few changes are expected in a plan that blames many urban woes on federal cutbacks and warns that urban tensions are at dangerous levels because cities are too strapped for cash to deal adequately with drugs and housing. The centerpiece of the mayors' agenda is a handful of economic development proposals that include the demand that Congress repeal the Gramm-Rudman law. The mayors said they were reluctant to take that stance but said they had little choice because Congress and the Bush administration have failed to negotiate a comprehensive deficit-reduction plan. Gramm-Rudman imposes automatic cuts if the deficit eclipses certain targets. ``The mayors across this country have got to say this is a charade,'' said Mayor Lee Robinson of Macon, Ga. ``We've got to say enough is enough.'' Mayor Paul Soglin of Madison, Wis., added, ``Too many of our members of Congress and the administration are seing this as a crutch to hide some of the problems of our economy.'' Conference staff members said the mayors would be the first national organization of elected officials to call from Gramm-Rudman's repeal. Also included in the blueprint is a call for Congress to reduce the Social Security payroll taxes paid by nearly 120 million workers and lift the outside earnings cap on Social Security recipients. The plan given initial approval also calls on Congress to stop using the balance of the Social Security Trust fund to mask the true size of the deficit. And if formally adopted Wednesday it will put the mayors on the record in opposition to a reduction in capital gains taxes favored by President Bush. The mayors' agenda, crafted at three days of committee meetings, also seeks new powers for cities to regulate and remove billboards along federal roads. But the conference committee that endorsed the package refused to adopt a measure that would have put the mayors on record against all tobacco and alcohol advertising.

DOC.HEAD: Read it Now _ List of More than 9,000 Secret Police Hangouts
DOC.TEXT: The hottest newspaper in East Berlin on Monday was a special edition of West Berlin's Tageszeitung, which listed 9,251 addresses purported to be hideouts of the former secret police. Included were addresses said to be secret police vacation homes, swimming pools, offices, as well as houses and apartments once used by agents to spy on the country's 16.6 million citizens. The Tageszeitung published the list, despite concerns it could inflame tensions in East Berlin. A supply of several thousand newspapers quickly sold out at East Berlin's sprawling Alexanderplatz. Tageszeitung, a far-leftist publication, claimed to have received the list from a committee overseeing the dissolution of the Communist regime's secret police. East Berlin's Interior Ministry had protested the publication of the list, which included specific apartment numbers.

DOC.HEAD: Herds Flee Timber Men, Destroy Crops
DOC.TEXT: Herds of elephants frightened by noise from loggers' heavy machinery have destroyed many farms in southern Gabon while fleeing the jungle, the Gabon News Agency reported Monday. The agency said many people face severe food shortages as a result of the stampedes and have demanded the government chase the elephants away. Four-fifths of this Central African nation is covered by forest, providing sanctuary for thousands of elephants who face slaughter elsewhere on the continent.

DOC.HEAD: Norwegian Environmentalists Violate Soviet Border in Protest
DOC.TEXT: Norwegian environmentalists pushed past police and violated Soviet and Finnish borders to protest pollution in the arctic, reports said Monday. About 30 local politicians and other protesters, shouting ``Stop the Soviet death cloud!'' defied Norwegian police Sunday and chained themselves around a stone marker at the point where the three countries meet. They told reporters that annual emissions of sulphur dioxide from the Soviet Kola Peninsula are killing Norway's arctic forests. ``If we lose the battle against pollution from Kola, we lose everything we love,'' activist Arne Ulvang told the national NTB news agency. ``Nature's threshold of pain has been reached. We just have a few years to save our wilderness.'' Soviet and Finnish border guards reportedly watched the protest from a distance. No arrests were made, but the protesters could face questioning and fines of up to $2,300 for illegally crossing the border, the Dagbladet newspaper reported.

DOC.HEAD: Brundtland Snubs Environment Meeting With South Africans
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland boycotted a 45-nation environment conference for engineers Monday because it was attended by South Africans, organizers said. Brundtland, who chaired the United Nations Commission on the Environment, canceled her opening address after learning that nine South Africans were among the 300 delegates, said Tom Rollsve, a conference spokesman Norway was not officially represented, making it the first host country to snub the annual conference opening, said Svein Erik Noerholm of the FIDIC consulting engineers association. ``If they didn't want these people in Norway, then official Norway should not have granted them visas. What happened is ridiculous and regrettable,'' Noerholm told the Dagens Naeringliv business newspaper. Norway has embargoed trade with South Africa to protest its policy of racial segregation, which denies the black majority a voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Foundation Turns Down Idea for Environmental Prize
DOC.TEXT: The foundation that finances the Nobel prizes on Monday rejected a proposal from 30 laureates to create a Nobel environmental prize. The laureates, including Peace Prize winners Willy Brandt of West Germany and Adolfo Perez Esquivel of Argentina, suggested the prize be awarded in the Netherlands by a committee of the Dutch Parliament. ``We fear an inflation of prizes would seriously diminish the value of those already existing,'' said Stig Ramel, chairman of the Nobel Foundation. The first Nobel prizes were awarded in 1901 from a trust bequeathed by Alfred Nobel, the Swedish inventor of dynamite. He established prizes in medicine, chemistry, physics, literature and peace. A sixth prize in economic sciences was established in 1968, funded by the Bank of Sweden, and was called a Nobel memorial prize to distinguish it from the others. This year each prize is worth $650,000. Ramel said there will be no more prizes. The foundation has exclusive rights to the Nobel name and will not allow it to be linked to another prize, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Doctors Stage Four-Day Strike For More Pay
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of doctors went on strike Monday for higher pay and brought state hospitals across the country to a standstill. More than 70 percent of the country's 10,000 doctors walked off the job, said Vassilis Laopodis, vice president of the Greek Federation of Hospital Doctors' Unions. The strike was to last four days. ``We just want to be paid for the hours we work. We haven't received a proper increase since 1983, and many overtime shifts go unpaid,'' Laopodis said in a telephone interview. The doctors are demanding a 30 percent salary increase, in addition to inflationary adjustments covering the past seven years. This year, the State Audit Council ruled that public employees could not earn more than their monthly salary in overtime pay. The cost-cutting measure could force some clinics to close unless doctors are willing to work for no pay, according to the doctors' union. The union said interns receive $212 per month, not quite half the wage of a factory worker.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Explodes at Religious Affairs Bookstore
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded at a government bookstore Monday and wounded eight people, officials reported. No one claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred at a store run by the Religious Affairs Foundation. The agency oversees religious affairs in Turkey and came under criticism last week from Moslems planning to make the holy pilgrimage this year to Saudi Arabia. The Moslems were angry because the agency collected money from them in advance for the pilgrimages, even though the Saudi government decided to restrict the number of Moslems allowed into the country for the annual pilgrimage. The foundation collected $740 from each pilgrim for travel and accommodation expenses. It said it will return the money to those who are denied Saudi visas.

DOC.HEAD: Matchmaker Heaven: 5,000 Marriages Set Up at Fair
DOC.TEXT: About 25,000 men flocked to India's only marriage fair for matchmaking negotiations, and news reports said 5,000 couples agreed to tie the knot. The fair was held over the weekend in a meadow in Bihar state, about 550 miles southeast of New Delhi. Groups of men in sarongs negotiated with the male guardians of prospective wives. Lineages were checked, with information supplied by local priests. Negotiations were limited to points such as what the man earns and what the bride-to-be looks like. No women were present. If the priest gives the go-ahead _ that is if the bride and groom are not related by blood ties _ the marriage is on. The couples will meet for the first time at their weddings. According to Press Trust of India, the practice was started by a 14th- century king to make it easier for upper-caste Brahmin families to fix marriages and eliminate the expensive practice of giving dowries. The marriage fair attracts prospects from Brahmin families all over northern India. Priests reportedly maintain the lineage registers of Brahmins from 16,800 villages in the region and check back seven generations to avoid marriages between couples sharing blood ties. The report said the number of people visiting the annual fair is declining. A few decades ago at leat 150,000 people would visit the fair each summer, it said. The reason for the decline, the report said, was that more people prefer private negotiations, where questions of dowries can be raised. Although ostensibly outlawed, the dowry practice is widespread in India, where about 90 percent of marriages are arranged by families. In India, the family of the bride presents a dowry, usually consisting of gold, to the family of the groom.

DOC.HEAD: World Cup Fever Brings Periods of Calm to Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: World Cup fever is sweeping Lebanon. When matches begin, rival Christian fighters lay down their guns, switch on their portable television sets and for a while, the country is calm. The only gunfire comes when excited militiamen shoot in the air in jubilation when their favorite soccer teams score. When West Germany played Yugoslavia last week, a group of scruffy militiamen from Samir Geagea's Christian militia gathered around a mobile anti-aircraft gun in east Beirut's Ashrafiyeh district. They watched the game on a portable TV propped up beside the weapon. A few yards away, their rivals _ the troops of Gen. Michel Aoun _ also watched the game, on a TV powered by a truck battery. When West Germany's Lothar Matthaeus scored his second goal, both groups whooped for joy and fired off clips of bullets into the air. The Germans' 4-1 victory triggered more celebratory gunfire. It was easy to forget for a moment that Aoun's troops and Geagea's militiamen have been fighting since Jan. 30 in a savage struggle for control of the Christian enclave north of Beirut. ``The World Cup has been a godsend,'' said one man in east Beirut. ``We really needed a diversion, even if it's only for a month. ``We know we'll be going back to the `salt mines' afterward,'' he said, reflecting fears that a cease-fire between Aoun's troops and Geagea's militiamen will collapse like others have. The uneasy cease-fire reached last month is violated frequently. But when World Cup is on television, both sides are too engrossed to skirmish. Across the devastated city, in the teeming Shiite Moslem slums of south Beirut, it is the same. The Hezbollah and Amal movements have been battling for three years for dominance of Lebanon's Shiites. But when the soccer matches begin in Italy each day, television sets in the Shiite battleground and across Lebanon switch on, and the country's 15-year-old civil war eases for a few hours. Electricity in Beirut has been cut off since early February because the city's power plants were knocked out in the Aoun-Geagea fighting, so everyone uses generators. The city hums. The authorities have allowed generators to run until midnight, or until the end of the last game, whichever comes first. Just before the World Cup telecasts begin, the city of Beirut shuts down. The streets are virtually deserted. Shops are shuttered. People go home or congregate in bars to watch the games on TV. Entire streets, for reasons known only to their residents, support different teams. The choice is usually arbitrary. Few Lebanese have particular links with any of the countries competing in Italy. Tiny Lebanon has not had a national soccer team for years, and when it did, it never got anywhere near qualifying for the World Cup. But Lebanese, like most Arabs, are big on soccer. At the American University of Beirut in the city's Moslem sector, the campus is festooned with the flags of the competing soccer nations. The night Egypt scored a surprise 1-1 tie with the Netherlands, Arab emotions erupted. When the underdog Egyptians held Ireland to a scoreless draw Sunday, militiamen let their guns rip with wild abandon.
