Joyful AUB students ran through campus carrying burning torches, beating drums, waving Egyptian flags and lobbing plastic bags filled with water at by-standers. ``I got at least 30 waterbags on my head when I tried to cross from the dorms to the classrooms,'' said one student.

DOC.HEAD: University of Michigan Provost Elected President of MIT
DOC.TEXT: Charles M. Vest, provost of the University of Michigan, was elected the next president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Monday after a yearlong search. The 48-year-old mechanical engineer was elected unanimously by the MIT Corp., the school's governing board, said MIT spokesman Ken Campbell. Vest, who will succeed Paul Gray, will start work at MIT in mid-fall. He becomes the 15th president of the 125-year-old school. Vest leaves a job at a state-supported university with 50,000 students on three campuses for a private research institution with 9,700 students. Gray announced in March 1989 his plans to step down after 10 years at the post. He will become MIT Corp. chairman following the retirement of David Saxon.

DOC.HEAD: Small Quake Near Malibu
DOC.TEXT: A small quake struck near here Monday but no damage or injuries were reported. The temblor struck at 6:24 a.m. and measured 3.0 on the Richter scale, said Robert Finn of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. It was centered 15 miles west of Malibu. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area.

DOC.HEAD: `Dick Tracy' Opens to $22.6 Million Box Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 16 graf lead UPDATES with preliminary figures on top five box office, Disney stock falling. Edits throughout to conform. Picks up 14th graf pvs, ``Dick Tracy...
DOC.TEXT: A weekend raid by ``Dick Tracy'' netted an estimated $22.6 million in box office receipts, including $1.2 million in sales for T-shirts that served as tickets at midnight openings. The total led all other movies for the weekend but was lower than the early receipts of some recent blockbusters. Disney stock fell on the news. The ``Tracy'' debut put the cuffs on Warner Bros.' ``Gremlins 2: The New Batch,'' which finished fourth with $9.8 million for its first weekend. In second place behind ``Tracy'' was ``Another 48 HRS.'' with $11.1 million, followed by ``Total Recall'' with $10.2 million, according to estimates this morning from Exhibitor Relations Co. In fifth place was ``Back to the Future III,'' with $5 million in ticket sales. The debut weekend box-office championship remains with another comic-book crime fighter, ``Batman,'' which cleaned up $40.5 million for Warner Bros. on a first weekend last summer. ``Dick Tracy'' also failed to top the debut earnings of Arnold Schwarzenegger's ``Total Recall,'' which earned $25 million in its opening earlier this month. Investors regarded the ``Tracy'' results, as well as those for ``Gremlins,'' as disappointing. Common stock in the Walt Disney Co., bid up last week on the New York Stock Exchange on favorable reviews, fell by $3.37{ per share in midday trading today to $128.37{. Time Warner Inc. stock fell by $1.12{ to $105.37{ per share. But Dick Cook, president of Disney's Buena Vista Pictures Distribution, said he believes ``Dick Tracy'' has staying power. ``It's never where you start, it's where you end,'' Cook said on Sunday. ``The way it's been reviewed, and the favorable way it has been received _ it is going to do extraordinarily well,'' Cook said in a telephone interview Sunday. ``And there's a lot of summer left.'' And there are a lot of movies yet to be released too, including Tom Cruise in ``Days of Thunder'' and sequels to ``RoboCop'' and ``Die Hard.'' Nevertheless, Cook said ``Dick Tracy'' was a record opening for Disney and had all the signs of a summer winner. The movie, directed by its star, Warren Beatty, features Madonna and a thieves' den of other big-name actors. Reviews were mostly favorable. Cook estimated a weekend box-office of between $22 million and $23 million and said ``Dick Tracy'' would get ``double the amount of business that any other movie will do this weekend.'' An industry observer who spoke on condition of anonymity said the opening was ``not great _ somewhere in between. ... It's not a bad opening.'' Both noted ``Dick Tracy'' was opening against ``Total Recall,'' ``Back to the Future III'' and ``Another 48 HRS.'' ``Dick Tracy'' opened at 2,223 theaters around the nation with a new Roger Rabbit cartoon, ``Rollercoaster Rabbit.'' Admission for midnight Thursday openings was a T-shirt, sold by theaters for as much as $20 apiece. Disney said it will include the price of the T-shirt in its box-office gross, despite protests from others in the movie industry that it would inflate the film's numbers. ``It is part of the box office, the ticket to the event,'' said Cook. ``It didn't amount to that much.'' One source placed the T-shirt boost at $1.2 million to $1.5 million. Cook said the opening of ``Dick Tracy'' outstripped Disney first weekend earnings for ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,'' which took in $14.2 million last year, and ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' which took in $11 million. ``Honey'' went on to earn $130 million domestically; ``Roger'' brought home $160 million as the hit of 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Happy Father's Day ... In Triplicate
DOC.TEXT: When Father's Day started, Frank Gonzalez was just another candidate for Lamaze class. Seven hours later, he was celebrating the holiday with his wife and three new daughters. ``This is one I'll always remember. I'm sure a lot of people in my family will remember this one, too,'' Gonzalez said about six hours after meeting the triplets born Sunday. ``I just thought about that on the way to the hospital: it's Father's Day. And when I got there, all the nurses were congratulating me, wishing me a happy Father's Day. It was very nice,'' the first-time father said. Madeline Gonzalez, 30, and her three newborns _ Amparo Crystal, Esther Christina and Marilyn (no middle name yet) _ were all doing well at Brooklyn Hospital, said spokeswoman Carol Rubiano. The infants, who were three weeks premature, were put in the neo-natal intensive care unit because of low birth weights. Amparo weighs 4 pounds, 10 ounces; Esther Christina is 4 pounds, 7 ounces; and Marilyn is 3 pounds, 7 ounces. Gonzales, 29, said he has no plans to mark any future Father's Day with a repeat performance. ``These are the first, and probably the last,'' he said. ``I don't think there'll be any more after this.'

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Predicts Germanys Will Unite By End of Year
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Monday that full unification of the two Germanys will occur this year, but an East German leader countered that too many questions remain. Kohl's remarks came as Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze met to find what Shevardnadze called ``a common language'' for settling remaining questions. In Britain, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said she was apprehensive about German unification. ``It's not surprising if you look back at the history of this century _ World War I and World War II,'' she told a BBC radio talk show. Kohl spoke to a meeting of Christian Democrats that was attended by East Germany's prime minister, Lothar de Maiziere. Kohl told his conservative party the year 1990 ``will be the year of German unity.'' The comments followed Sunday's stormy session in East Berlin's parliament, where lawmakers surprisingly agreed to consider immediate unification. The legislators later backed away from a vote to dissolve the country and automatically join West Germany. Wolfgang Thierse, the leader of East Germany's Social Democrats, said too many questions on unification remain to be resolved to permit it to happen this year. The Social Democrats form part of de Maiziere's governing coalition but favor slower unification than the Christian Democrats. Thierse said lingering topics include the completion of the two-plus-four talks between the two Germanys and four victorious World War II Allies _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France. The foreign ministers of the six nations are scheduled to meet this week to discuss aspects of unification. ``It would show insensitivity to our neighbors'' to complete unification before the two-plus-four talks are completed, Thierse said. His remarks were in reference to the question of what will happen to former German land ceded to the Poles after World War II. Kohl and de Maiziere have already said their governments are ready to sign a treaty guaranteeing a united Germany will respect the existing Polish border. At Monday's Christian Democratic meeting in Bonn, a resolution reiterating that guarantee was passed. Kohl's Christian Democrats have also called for united German elections to take place Dec. 9, replacing West Germany's federal elections currently set for Dec. 2. Both the West German and East German Social Democratic parties are against holding the ballot this year. Kohl's main challenger for the chancellorship, Social Democrat Oskar Lafonatine, has also said they are against quick economic, monetary and social union with East Germany, which is to take effect next month. However, Kohl said at Monday's meeting he was completely confident that the West German Bundestag and Bundesrat, the lower and upper houses of parliament, would ratify a treaty with East Germany this week to ensure economic and monetary union begins July 2 as planned. ``There are no alternatives,'' Kohl said. The symbolic vote of 267-92 in East Berlin's parliament on Sunday for discussions on immediate unity also bolstered Kohl's confidence, giving him a preview of how strong support for unification is in East Germany. Among the issues covered by Shevardnadze and Genscher in the city of Muenster was a united Germany's military alliance once the two countries have merged. The United States, and Kohl and Genscher, support a united Germany being in NATO. The Soviets oppose NATO membership for the new country.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Survives Two-Story Drop into `Sure Hands'
DOC.TEXT: An infant survived a two-story fall without injury when a baby sitter dropped her from a smoky apartment into the hands of a former high school basketball player, authorities said. ``I got some sure hands, man. Sure hands,'' James Harris, 39, said after making the catch of his life Sunday. Eight-week-old Heather Lynn Yeckley slept soundly after the ordeal as firefighters doused the apartment fire. Sitter Robin Stilwell said she found herself trapped by heat and smoke when she awakened from a noontime nap. ``I couldn't get out the door,'' she said, so she grabbed the baby and rushed to a window. Firefighters arrived just as the baby was dropped to Harris. They rescued Ms. Stilwell, 21, from the window with a ladder. Paramedics said Ms. Stilwell appeared to be overcome with fear and didn't heed their shouts no to drop the child. No one was seriously injured in the blaze. Investigators blamed the fire on an old television in another apartment.

DOC.HEAD: Central American Presidents Declare War on Poverty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with comments by Central American presidents; EDITS to conform, tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III met today with five Central American presidents and discussed how to coordinate U.S. and other foreign aid to build the region's economies. He arrived in Antigua on Sunday night to attend the close of the three-day meeting, in which the Central American leaders agreed to form a Central American Economic Community to fight poverty. Officials said Baker outlined a plan for coordinating aid, trade and investment in Central America from a variety of nations and organizations. The idea is based on the model adopted by a group of 24 developed nations for helping Poland and Hungary make the transition to free-market democracies. Baker's proposal is seen as a clear affirmation of U.S. intentions to maintain its traditional influence in the region. After a breakfast meeting with Baker, President Rafael Callejas of Honduras told a joint news conference the Central American leaders fully expect the U.S. proposal to mean additional aid for the region, but that no specific sums _ nor the touchy issue of who would manage the program _ had been discussed. The United States has been saying it wants to manage the program, but the region's leaders have indicated they want to manage it themselves or have the final decision on who would run it. ``We didn't talk about sums or structures,'' Callejas said. Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani said there will be more detailed discussions at the next Central American summit, to be held sometime within the next three months in Costa Rica. He said Baker had committed the United States to further talks with the donor countries. Among the industrialized nations expected to provide Central America with aid are Japan, Canada and the European Economic Community. Baker also was to hold individual meetings with each of the presidents today. The presidents _ all elected civilians _ agreed in two accords Sunday night to try to mesh the region's economies. They pledged coordinated action on foreign trade and debt, on rebuilding infrastructures, on agricultural and industrial policy and attracting investment. Costa Rican President Rafael Calderon said the region, deeply scarred by a decade of civil strife, needs international support. ``We don't extend our hand to ask for charity,'' Calderon said. ``But we say to you, here are the Central American people who are willing to give their labor, their effort and their dedication but who also need the friendly hand of the developing world.'' Callejas has said Central America needs at least $2.5 billion in aid over the next three years to begin rebuilding. The task will be immense. According to a study by the U.N. Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean, the regional gross domestic product has fallen 20 percent since 1978. The summit marked a turning point for Central America, which has suffered decades of dictatorship, revolution and political, social and economic crisis. ``War and violence are an act of human cruelty, but poverty is an act of human abandonment we must confront,'' the presidents of Guatemala, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras and Costa Rica said in their accords. ``Violence is a part of our history we will not forget, but we must not repeat. Now we set out on other roads.'' The Antigua meeting was the eighth Central American summit, but the first to deal almost exclusively with economic issues. The presidents hope to repeat the success of the Nobel Prize-winning regional peace plan. In Nicaragua, the plan helped end the war and brought elections that ousted Central America's only leftist government. The peace plan was also the catalyst for peace talks now under way between leftist rebels and the governments of El Salvador and Guatemala. The economic accords reflect a search for solutions acceptable to the region's powerful vested interests. Attempts to redistribute wealth have cost tens of thousands of lives, and the development agenda for the 1990s aims at generating more wealth instead of at redistribution. Nicaraguan President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and Costa Rican President Calderon, both elected this year, signed the plan as first-time participants in a regional summit. Signing for Guatemala was President Vinicio Cerezo. Panamanian President Guillermo Endara signed as an invited observer.

DOC.HEAD: 9-Year-Old Boy Shot in Head During Father's Day Dinner
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old boy had just taken his seat at a Father's Day family dinner when he slumped suddenly _ a bullet lodged in his skull. ``You are not even safe in our own back yard,'' said the victim's mother, Christine Philpott. After surgery Sunday to remove the slug, Dale Philpott was alert, talking with his parents and complaining that he was hungry. ``It certainly is a mystery,'' said Hillsborough sheriff's Detective Rich Figueredo. ``We have no idea at this point whether it was accidental or deliberate.'' Twenty family members had gathered on an open-air porch in the back of the boy's grandparents' home for dinner. ``We weren't sure what was wrong with him until we looked at the back of his head and saw the hole,'' said Mary Lou Heyer, the boy's great aunt. At Humana Hospital Brandon, X-rays revealed a bullet lodged in his skull. ``We are real lucky. Another centimeter and the doctor said Dale would be dead,'' Mrs. Philpott said.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Prepare for Spill to Wash Ashore
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with volunteers cleaning up beaches; initial numbers smaller than expected. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Tar balls...'. DELETES 7th graf pvs, `Mauro said...', now outdated.
DOC.TEXT: Crews started laying booms and volunteers began cleaning up beaches today to make them ready for an oil slick expected to wash ashore Tuesday from the wrecked supertanker Mega Borg. ``We cannot wait any longer,'' Texas Land Commissioner Gary Mauro said. ``We don't know if oil or tar balls will ever make it to the coast, but we have to get ready.'' Although 200 or more volunteers were expected, only about 60 initially showed up this morning at Sea Rim State Park to get ready for the slick to hit the beach. They walked the sandy beaches picking up seaweed and garbage to make it easier to clean up any tar balls that may wash ashore. Tar balls were expected to begin showing up Tuesday along the 45-mile stretch of coastline from High Island, some 30 miles north of Galveston, to Sabine Pass at the Texas-Louisiana line, the Coast Guard said. Officials tracking the 30-mile slick, situated about 10 miles offshore Sunday, hoped the oil would hit the area's small, sandy beaches instead of its marshes, which include wildlife refuges. ``If it hits the marshlands, it seeps into the ground and kills off the vegetation and the eggs in that area,'' said Gary Clark, president of the Houston Audubon Society. He said birds could then face starvation. Sandy beaches also are easier to clean, officials said. Crews on Sunday stretched a boom across the eastern end of Bolivar Peninsula, between Galveston and High Island, to deflect any oil from marshy areas. Coast Guard officials said the 886-foot Norwegian tanker, crippled 57 miles off Galveston by an explosion June 8, has stopped leaking oil. The vessel had been carrying 38 million gallons when the blast occurred. The Coast Guard also lowered the spill estimate from 4.6 million gallons to 3.9 million, still the fifth-largest U.S. spill. Officials said salvage crews found about 700,000 gallons in smaller tanks that catch runoff from the larger tanks on the ship. Two crew members died and two are missing and presumed dead. The cause of the blast, which occurred when the ship was transferring oil to a smaller vessel, has not been determined. Most of the spilled oil either evaporated or burned in fires that raged on the ship for a week, officials said. Twelve skimmer vessels have captured 250,000 gallons of the crude, according to the Coast Guard. Cleanup crews had expected the Angolan light crude to begin washing ashore late Sunday near Galveston, but shifting winds pushed the slick to the northeast, parallel to the coast. In the first open-sea use of a process called bioremediation, which uses bacteria to break down oil into a harmless fatty substance, oil-eating microbes spread over part of the slick appear to have worked, state officials said. On Friday, about 100 pounds of bacteria were spread over an acre. A flyover Sunday showed little oil in the treated water, but a second experiment was planned to confirm whether the process worked or whether the oil was removed by the current, officials said. Meanwhile, salvage crews working on the Mega Borg began transferring oil from a ruptured cargo tank to another holding bin aboard the vessel. Crews from Smit America Salvage Inc. also began pumping water out of another holding tank that flooded during the firefighting. Once those operations are finished, crews will probably start transferring the rest of the ship's cargo to smaller vessels, the Coast Guard said. By Sunday, crews had stopped dousing the hull of the Mega Borg. Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Mark Sedwick said officials believed there was no longer a threat of the fire reigniting. Divers attempting to rescue five loggerhead sea turtles spotted Saturday near the edge of the slick were unable to locate the reptiles, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said. NOAA planned to continue searching for members of the threatened species.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Soviet Politburo Member Critical of Steps Toward Capitalism
DOC.TEXT: The leading conservative on the Soviet Politburo, Yegor K. Ligachev, on Monday criticized advocates of a free market and called for a referendum on whether the nation should be capitalist or socialist. Ligachev spoke out in an interview published by the Communist Party newspaper Pravda. In two weeks, the party is to open a crucial congress to debate the course of reform. ``Let's ask the people what direction restructuring should take _ to socialism or capitalism. Let's hold a national referendum,'' Ligachev said. He outlined a traditional Marxist-Leninist position that contrasted sharply with calls for reform being heard in the Soviet media and legislative bodies, and he urged that the nation stick with a planned market economy. ``Those who advocate a free market are pushing us back to private appropriation of the results of the labor of other people to their exploitation,'' he said. ``We have already realized the destructiveness of such `freedom' at the macrolevel, when large units and republics try to secede from an integrated community, thereby harming other republics and peoples,'' he said, alluding to the steps toward independence by the Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. Meanwhile, the reformist weekly Ogonyok published results of an opinion poll that indicated diminished support for the Communist Party among Soviet citizens. The poll was conducted by the All-Union Center for the Study of Public Opinion. It said that of Soviets surveyed last month, 49 percent believed the Communist Party was ``losing the initiative.'' Ogonyok said 11.2 percent of those surveyed thought the party was ``leading society on the path to democratic renewal,'' while 13.8 percent thought ``the party was putting the brakes on the process of democratic renewal.'' Asked which institutions commanded the most authority in the Soviet Union, 61.8 percent expressed ``complete faith'' in the army, 47.9 percent complete faith in the church and 40.8 percent complete faith in the Supreme Soviet legislation, the three most respected bodies. At the low end of the scale were the Communist Party, with 29.5 percent expressing complete faith, the police with 22.2 percent and the Young Communist League with 10.1 percent. The poll did not say how many people were questioned or give a margin of error.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Battle Moves to Florida Courtroom
DOC.TEXT: The state of Florida will test the new legal climate for abortion restrictions this week when it asks a federal judge for more authority to regulate abortion clinics. Eight years ago, U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez issued a ruling that limited regulation of private abortion clinics to four areas. On Tuesday, Gonzalez is to hear testimony and arguments in his Fort Lauderdale courtroom over proposed changes in that injunction. State officials hope the result will be a ruling that gives them broader powers to regulate sanitation and other aspects of abortion clinic operations. Abortion rights activists hope Gonzalez will continue to give the state only limited authority over the clinics. This is the second high-profile case in a month for Gonzalez, who on June 6 declared an album by the rap group 2 Live Crew to be obscene. In the abortion case, the state has argued that current rules of Florida's Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services aren't strong enough to guarantee public health and safety. ``Women served by abortion clinics are now treated as second-class citizens in comparison to similar patients at birthing centers and ambulatory surgical centers,'' the motion says. Charlene Carres, a lawyer representing a Fort Lauderdale clinic owner named as a plaintiff in the class-action lawsuit, said the state wants to further regulate a procedure that already is safe and protected as a fundamental privacy right. ``There is no justification for changing the injunction, mainly because the safety of abortion has not declined since 1982,'' Carres said last week, citing the state's own statistics that first-trimester abortions are far safer than childbirth. While a single abortion-related death is recorded every few years, she said, anywhere from 15 to 23 childbirth-related deaths occur each year. ``The numbers of death and injuries from abortion is so low it's even difficult to make a valid statistical comparison,'' Carres said. The state has less faith in that data because women are reluctant to come forward with complaints about abortions, said Jim Peters, assistant attorney general. In its motion before Gonzalez, the state says it can no longer rely on the assumption that first-trimester abortions are safer than childbirth. In 1982, Gonzalez said the state can inspect only to see if the clinic posts its license, maintains records, properly disposes of fetal remains and allows only physicians to perform abortions. Under the judge's order, the state is not allowed to enforce requirements on minimum care standards, transportation of patients in emergencies, staffing and equipment. The state didn't appeal Gonzalez's ruling, but Peters said that a U.S. Supreme Court ruling last summer and a Florida newspaper article last fall justified a change in the order to let the state inspect abortion clinics for such aspects as sanitation and infection control, equipment maintenance, staffing, emergency procedures, medicine storage and administration. In its Webster ruling last July, the nation's high court upheld a Missouri law requiring viability testing of fetuses before allowing abortions after 20 weeks. Two months later, The Miami Herald detailed dirty and dangerous conditions in South Florida clinics created an unroar, prompting HRS to use emergency powers under Florida's public health statute to close four clinics.

DOC.HEAD: Chief Says Arsonist May Be Responsible For 20 Fires
DOC.TEXT: A lone arsonist may be to blame for a string of 20 fires in one section of the city in the past two months, the fire chief said. Eight of the blazes were set last weekend, six of them in two hours Sunday morning, Fire Chief Fred Postel said Sunday. Since April 9, the fires have been set in an area northwest of the city's center. All were setly the chairman himself, seem to think, however, that slow growth or even a recession might be the price to pay to bury inflation for years to come.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Guerrillas Disarm Abu Nidal's Followers
DOC.TEXT: PLO guerrillas swept through a refugee camp in southern Lebanon on Monday and disarmed followers of the notorious terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal, police said. The operation followed weekend fighting between supporters and opponents of Abu Nidal within his Fatah-Revolutionary Council group. At least five people were killed in the violence. Police said about 100 Palestine Liberation Organization military policemen seized all weapons of Abu Nidal's followers in a house-to-house search in the Rashidiyeh refugee camp, outside Tyre. ``Abu Nidal's base in Rashidiyeh has been dismantled. He has no followers left here,'' said a police spokesman in Tyre, who cannot be named under standing rules. He said 40 Abu Nidal loyalists surrendered to the PLO on Sunday, and a dozen were arrested in Monday's operation. PLO sources, who refused to give their names, said Abu Nidal still has about 150 followers in the Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp, which is near the southern port city of Sidon, and in hills east of Sidon. Two kidnapped employees of the International Committee of the Red Cross are believed held in the Sidon area. The Swiss hostages, Emmanuel Christen, 32, and Elio Erriquez, 23, were abducted Oct. 6, 1989 near a Red Cross orthopedic center that cared for war victims. Lebanese police and the PLO blamed the kidnappings on Abu Nidal. His group denied responsibility. Abu Nidal, whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, is believed to be in Libya. A U.S. State Department report last year described Abu Nidal as the world's most dangerous terrorist. It blamed his hirelings for 34 terrorist attacks in 20 countries since he split from Yasser Arafat's PLO in 1973. At least 900 people were killed or wounded in these attacks, the report said. The atrocities included the December 1985 attacks on Rome and Vienna airports that killed more than 20 people.

DOC.HEAD: Businesses Caught Using Child Workers Face Fines Over $1 Million
DOC.TEXT: Businesses caught illegally employing 3,800 youngsters during a one-day federal sweep this month face more than $1 million in fines, the Labor Department said Monday. Most of the child labor violations involved youngsters working more hours than is allowed under federal labor law, the agency said. But there were also 490 minors, mostly 16- and 17-year-olds, who were working at dangerous tasks such as using power-driven meat slicers or paper-baling machines. The June 6 sweep, in which investigators visited 2,033 businesses, uncovered violations in 753 establishments, or at 37 percent of the companies visited nationwide, the department said. The names of the companies were not released. The most recent sweep is part of an ongoing effort to crack down on employers illegally using teen-age labor. In March, investigators working on a three-day sweep visited 3,400 businesses and found that nearly half were in apparent violation of child labor laws. Investigators have found 15,500 violations as a result of the March sweep. Fines from that effort are expected to total $5 million. Federal law forbids 14-year-olds and 15-year-olds from working more than three hours on a school day or 18 hours in a week during the school year. Eight hours are permitted on weekend days and 40-hour weeks are permitted in summer and during school vacations. Youngsters under 14 are prohibited from working in all but a few exempt jobs, such as newspaper delivery workers.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Allege Sexual Bias in Medical Research
DOC.TEXT: Government medical research is so sexually biased that even male laboratory rats are the preferred animal for studies, according to congressional testimony Monday. ``What it's really saying is, it's OK to put women's health at risk,'' Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., told the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on Health and the Environment. She was among critics who say clinical trials and the resulting data are skewed in favor of men. The lack of gender-specific data ``communicates to doctors that women really aren't that much at risk,'' she said. As a result, women's problems often aren't taken seriously until they reach a critical stage. The National Institutes of Health has a $7.6 billion research budget this year. An NIH advisory committee reported in 1987 that less than 14 percent of the institute's budget went to women's health issues even though women make up more than half the population, Schroeder said. Only $17 million is spent on basic breast cancer research annually while less than 2 percent of NIH grants for research went to obstetric and gynecological programs in 1986 and 1987, she said. Heart disease and cancers of the lung and breast are the top killers of women. NIH has only three obstetrician-gynecologists on its permanent staff, added Schroeder, mentioning also a ``dearth'' of money for research on infertility and contraception. Schroeder also referred to conclusions of a congressionally mandated study that the National Institutes of Health has made little progress in implementing its policy of including women in research study populations. The policy, announced in October 1986, has neither been well communicated nor well understood, the draft study by the congressional General Accounting Office said. The report was released at the hearing. Although NIH was not given the customary opportunity to review the draft and have its comments made part of the final report before its release, the acting head of the institutes said he generally agreed with its findings. ``My colleagues and I agree that the matter warrants sustained, high priority attention,'' said William Raub, referring to the ``arrogance or indifference'' of scientists who knew the policy but refused to implement it. He acknowledged under questioning by Rep. Henry A. Waxman, D-Calif., the subcommittee chairman, that most laboratory researchers begin their work using male animals to rule out the menstrual cycle as a variable. Raub said this ``control'' is usually confined to the early stages of research. Waxman asked whether such a control skewed the results from the outset, and Raub acknowledged that the control argument has been ``an overworked and overused rationale.'' Dr. Claude L'Enfant, head of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, disputed one of the key assertions of the GAO report: that research on the effects of aspirin in preventing heart attacks in women was blocked because of cost concerns. L'Enfant said the only reason for leaving women out of the study begun in 1981 on aspirin and heart attacks was that its design was flawed.

DOC.HEAD: Barge Runs Aground off Massachusetts Near Site of Cruise Ship Grounding
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with little fuel spilled, revised distance from earlier crash to less than one mile sted less than 2; add details on cargo. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `The seagoing...
DOC.TEXT: A fuel oil barge being towed by a tugboat ran aground in Buzzards Bay this morning, but leaked only briefly, the Coast Guard said. The barge hit within one mile of the site where the cruise ship the Bermuda Star ran aground in fog June 10, officials said. The barge stopped leaking shortly after it hit the rocks and Coast Guard crews planned to pump remaining fuel out and refloat the barge, Petty Officer Jim Chenard said. The Rea Bouchard was carrying between 7,500 and 8,000 barrels of fuel oil, Chenard said. It hit bottom about one half-mile northwest of Cleveland Ledge Light. The seagoing crash was first reported about 10:30 a.m. Mello said the Coast Guard dispatched vessels with oil-catching booms shortly before 11 a.m. The Bermuda Star ran aground with hundreds of passengers and crew aboard, ripping a 90-foot gash in its hull and spilling thousands of gallons of diesel fuel. Those on board were ferried to safety. Buzzards Bay fronts the western shore of Cape Cod, about 50 miles southeast of Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Court Will Use Case of California Eye Surgeon to Study Antitrust Law
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said today it will use the case of an eye surgeon denied staff privileges at a Los Angeles hospital to study the scope of a key federal antitrust law. The justices agreed to hear an appeal by the hospital seeking to dismiss the doctor's antitrust suit. A ruling is not expected until next year. The case stems from a dispute between Dr. Simon Pinhas and Midway Hospital Medical Center, which is owned by Summit Health Ltd. Pinhas, a member of Midway's staff since 1981, protested in 1986 a hospital requirement that an assistant surgeon be present for the performance of eye surgery. Medicare reimbursement for assistant eye surgeons was discontinued in 1986, and Pinhas said requiring him to have an assistant present when he performed operations would cost him $60,000 a year. The hospital refused to abolish the assistant surgeon requirement but offered Pinhas what he called a sham contract promising to pay him $60,000 a year for non-existent consulting services. Pinhas refused to sign the contract or to return it to hospital officials. He said that prompted hospital administrators to suspend his staff privileges at Midway. He then sued, accusing hospital officials of engaging in an anti-competitive conspiracy forbidden by the Sherman Antitrust Act. He said the officials boycotted his practice and prevented his continued competition in the marketplace. A federal judge threw out the suit. But it was reinstated last year by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. At issue is whether there is enough of a connection with interstate commerce to invoke the Sherman Antitrust Act. The 9th Circuit court said Pinhas ``need only prove that peer-review proceedings have an effect on interstate commerce, a fact that can hardly be disputed. The proceedings affect the entire staff at Midway and thus affect the hospital's interstate commerce.'' Hospital officials said Pinhas should be required to show that the hospital's alleged anti-competitive conduct affects interstate commerce, not merely that the hospital is engaged in interstate commerce. The California Association of Hospitals and Health Systems supported Midway's appeal. The case is Summith Health Ltd. vs. Pinhas, 89-1679.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed, Six Critically Wounded in Office Building Shooting Rampage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT type of weapon from 30-30 to .30-caliber rifle, add that it was semiautomatic.
DOC.TEXT: A man whose car had been repossessed methodically gunned down customers and employees at a GM financing agency today, killing seven people and critically wounding six others before committing suicide, police said. ``He just started walking through the building and shooting,'' Jacksonville Sheriff James McMillan said. The unidentified gunman used a .30-caliber semiautomatic rifle and a .38-caliber revolver in the shootings, and may be connected with two other weekend shootings usin the same kind of rifle, the sheriff said. ``It's just a terrible, terrible, senseless thing,'' said McMillan. The shootings occurred inside the General Motors Acceptance Corp. building at the Baymeadows Office Park just before 11 a.m. EDT, said Jacksonville police spokesman Sgt. Steve Weintraub. GMAC is the car-financing arm of the General Motors Corp. McMillan said the man's car had been repossessed. The sheriff said the man went up to the counter, shot a customer and then began walking through the office shooting his weapons. Most of the shots apparently came from the rifle, McMillan said. Richard Langille, a GMAC employee, said as soon as employees heard gunfire, they dived beneath their desks. ``And then we realized the guy was pointing his gun underneath people's desks and killing them one by one,'' said Langille. ``I just saw the bottom of the carpet and just prayed.'' Five employees and another customer, along with the gunman, died at the scene, said John Andrews, a spokesman for GMAC in Detroit. McMillan said an eighth person _ a GMAC employee whose husband was a police officer _ died shortly after being transported to a hospital. The gunman killed himself at the end of the shootings, said the sheriff. The wounded were airlifted or taken by ambulance to two local hospitals, University Hospital and Baptist Medical Center, where they were all described as in critical condition. Jay Edelberg, of Baptist Medical Center, said the three wounded brought there had been shot repeatedly. One man had gunshot wounds on both sides of his chest and in his abdomen, and was on the operating table, he said. A woman, also in the operating room was shot on both sides of her chest and bleeding from her abdomen. ``The third one, who is the most stable, probably had the worst injuries because she got hit about seven times, hitting her arms, her legs, shattering bones and severing nerves and arteries,'' the Baptist spokesman said. Vince Scolaro, spokesman with University Hospital, said the facility had three patients from the shooting, all in the trauma center. They, too, were all in critical condition. Ambulances, police and office workers from surrounding companies circled the office building soon after the shooting. Several large corporations have their regional headquarters in the office park, which lies south of downtown Jacksonville. Fred Bateh, owner of a sandwich shop across the street, said a GMAC employee ran into his store about 10:45 a.m. and said ``somebody's shooting people at close range. A lot of them are dead.'' The massacre was the worst since Sept. 14, 1989, when Joseph T. Wesbecker, a 47-year-old pressman on disability for mental illness, fatally shot eight people and wounded 12 others at a printing plant in Louisville, Ky., before taking his own life.

DOC.HEAD: House Sends Zionism Bill to Bush
DOC.TEXT: The House on Monday passed and sent to President Bush a bill calling on the United Nations to repeal a 15-year-old resolution equating Zionism with racism. On a voice vote, the lawmakers approved a measure rhetorically asking ``all member states of the United Nations General Assembly to take immediate action'' to repeal U.N. Resolution 3379, passed in 1975. The congressional legislation, passed May 3 by the Senate, also requires the president to report to Congress periodically on progress toward repeal. The administration supports the bill and is expected to sign it. The resolution states that the U.N. action has been used to justify terrorist attacks, has encouraged anti-semitism and has been a device to damage Israel's legitimacy. Zionism, the movement to establish a Jewish homeland, is opposed by many of Israel's Arab neighbors and their allies. But John Bolton, assistant secretary of state for international organizations, told Congress in March that some countries which voted for the resolution now have changed their thinking. He said U.S. officials are talking with U.N. member nations, including the Soviet Union, about repeal. The administration would like to act on the issue when the General Assembly reconvenes in the fall, Bolton said, but will not take up the matter unless repeal is assured.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says Bush Ready to Veto Family Leave Bill
DOC.TEXT: Candidate George Bush advocated job protection for parental care, but President Bush is ready to veto a bill that would offer such protection. The White House on Monday denied any conflict between the two stances, suggesting that Bush _ now as then _ supports such protection only if it is voluntary for employers. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush stands ready to cast the 13th veto of his presidency on the parental-care bill. ``I wouldn't be surprised to see it this week,'' Fitzwater said. The measure, passed by Congress last week, would guarantee workers as much as 12 weeks' unpaid leave for childbirth, adoption or serious family illnesses. The measure would apply to all businesses with 50 or more employees. During his presidential campaign, Bush touched on the issue Sept. 9, 1988. ``Look, we also need to assure that women don't have to worry about getting their jobs back after having a child or caring for a child during serious illness,'' he told the Illinois Federation of Republican Women in Rockford. Fitzwater, who was President Reagan's spokesman throughout 1988 and did not work in the Bush campaign, said he was unaware of those Bush comments. But, Fitzwater said, the president opposes the present legislation because ``it is a federally mandated benefit and we're opposed to federally mandated benefits.'' Deputy press secretary Alixe Glen, who was a 1988 campaign aide to Bush, said the president ``supports and encourages'' parental and medical leave policies designed to meet the needs of individual companies and employees. ``He has always been opposed to the federal government dictating or mandating what every business in this country should do,'' she said. ``This particular bill would badly impact a lot of companies. ``It reduces small business flexibility, reduces U.S. competitiveness and really could undermine the current trend toward flexible policies,'' Ms. Glen said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Reported to Seek Weapons Money for Angolan Rebels
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores dropped words at end of 5th graf, In the
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has asked Congress to add $10 million or $15 million to a secret arms program for rebels fighting the Soviet-backed government of Angola, a congresional source said Monday. Some of the money would be used to buy Hawk anti-aircraft missiles, adding to an arsenal of shoulder-fired Stinger rockets the rebels have used to attack government planes, said the source, who spoke only on condition of anonymity. The request for the extra money prompted an angry letter from the Congressional Black Caucus to Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee which oversees the U.S. aid. Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., head of the caucus, said U.S. weapons were directly responsible for rebel landmines that have resulted in Angola having the largest population of amputees in the world, according to Red Cross figures. He called U.S. aid ``morally indefensible.'' In the June 12 letter, Dellums told Boren he was writing ``in advance of reported pending action in your committee which would again direct United States resources'' to the Angolan rebels. He said the caucus ``is unalterably opposed to congressional action to direct American aid to (rebel) forces'' and asked Boren and his committee ``to reject all attempts to allow U.S. resources to enter this war region.'' Word of the request for extra money came as representatives of Angola's Marxist government met in Portugal with rebels of the Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) to discuss a cease-fire and an end to their country's 15-year civil war. The current annual allocation for the secret program, which is handled by the CIA and overseen by the House and Senate intelligence committees, is thought to be $50 million this fiscal year that ends Sept. 30. The program grew from an estimated $30 million two years ago, partly to make up a shortfall caused by South Africa's agreement to stop arming UNITA. The United States airlifted large quantities of weapons to UNITA last January to counter a massive government offensive into rebel-held territory. Rebel leaders credit the airlift, which followed a hiatus of several months in U.S. arms supplies, with helping to turn the tide against government forces and bring about their retreat from the strategic town of Mavinga last month. But UNITA representatives have said recently that their stocks were depleted by the battle for Mavinga and that they would require additional arms. The Soviet Union, which supports Angola's government with $800 million annually, according to the State Department, has proposed to the United States a cessation of arms to both sides. Secretary of State James Baker said last week the United States would only consider stopping its support for UNITA if the government of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos agrees to rebel demands for free elections in the one-party state. But he disclosed that the Americans and Soviets have proposed joint sponsorship of peace talks between the sides. U.S. officials argue that Angolan forces have far bigger stockpiles of weapons than the rebels, and an arms cutoff now would place UNITA at a disadvantage. UNITA has been fighting the government since shortly after Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. An initial cease-fire mediated by Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko last June collapsed within days and peace talks only restarted in April in Evora, Portugal.

DOC.HEAD: 21 Tibetans Arrested in Lhasa, Says Dalai Lama's Office
DOC.TEXT: Chinese authorities arrested 13 monks and 10 students this month in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa, the Dalai Lama's office in India said Monday. A statement by the office quoted an unnamed visitor to Lhasa as saying the monks were arrested June 8 in central Lhasa when they tried to demonstrate against Chinese rule of Tibet. Later that day, about 100 students of Tibet University held a pro-independence rally, which armed policemen broke up, the statement quoted unidentified witnesses as saying. It quoted an unidentified tourist as saying gunshots were heard during the police action. The reported demonstration coincided with the Tibetan religious festival of Saka Dawa, the statement said. It said no further details of the June 8 incident were available but added that this was the first reported demonstration since the lifting of martial law in Lhasa on May 1. China had imposed martial law in Lhasa 13 months earlier to prevent pro-independence riots. Chinese troops marched into Tibet in 1950. Nine years later, an uprising led by the Dalai Lama, Tibetans' spiritual leader, was crushed. The Dalai Lama fled with 80,000 followers to India, where he set up his government-in-exile. More than 6 million Tibetans worldwide rever the Dalai Lama, who won the Nobel Peace Prize last year for his peaceful resistance to Chinese rule. Beijing claims Tibet has been part of China since the 13th century.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves $50 Million For Breast, Cervical Cancer Screening
With AM-Sexist Research
DOC.TEXT: The House on Monday approved spending up to $50 million next year to help screen low-income women for breast and cervical cancer. The measure was approved on a voice vote and goes to the Senate. It would authorize the Centers for Disease Control to make grants to states to set up screening programs and educate the public about the need for screening. States seeking the grants would need to provide $1 for every three federal dollars and give priority in their programs to low-income women. Even if the measure is approved by the Senate and signed into law, Congress would still have to take additional action to appropriate the money needed to carry out the programs. In separate action, the House also approved a $36 million reauthorization of the CDC's tuberculosis control program. That measure also was passed on a voice vote and sent to the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Approve Bill To Allow Security Forces to Stop Demonstration
LaserPhoto XBUC1
DOC.TEXT: A parliamentary chamber on Monday gave police and soldiers authority to move against government opponents who re-took a Bucharest square after being brutally routed by police last week. Also Monday, opposition parlimentarians demanded the government investigate the events that led President-elect Ion Iliescu to summon thousands of miners to help crush the unrest last week. The miners, swinging iron bars and sticks, beat anyone they suspected of opposing Iliescu. A student leader who was severely beaten was taken into police custody Monday and charged with helping incite the unrest. Hundreds of people gathered for a second day in University Square to demand the ouster of Iliescu, and students said they would go on strike Tuesday. Iliescu's inauguration had been scheduled for last week and has been postponed for later this week amid the turmoil. Of the lawmakers present in the newly elected 377-member Chamber of Deputies, only 72 voted against the motion to have ``the forces of law and order'' end the University Square demonstration. Seven abstained. The vote split generally along party lines, with deputies of Iliescu's National Salvation Front and splinter parties supporting it, and the three main opposition parties against it. It was unclear when action might be taken against the protesters, who numbered about 300 late Monday. Passage was virtually certain in the Senate, where the Front also holds a clear majority. The unrest began Wednesday, when police broke up a 535-day sit-in by protesters demanding Iliescu and other Communists be banned from office. When the unrest continued, Iliescu summoned thousands of miners to the city to crush the protests. Six people were killed and more than 500 injured in the ensuing violence, the worst since the December uprising that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Student leader Marian Munteanu was moved Monday from the Emergency Hospital to a police hospital after being charged with ``instigation and participation in violence,'' according to his opposition group, the Students League. Munteanu was beaten and suffered a fractured skull and broken left leg and arm, doctors said. The league told a news conference that students and faculty at the University of Bucharest would go on strike Tuesday to protest violence directed at them in the past few days. On Sunday, force was not used against the demonstrators, and the government promised dialogue. There was no sign Monday of talks between the two sides. The protesters, who demand Iliescu and other ex-Communists be banned from politics, shouted ``Down with Iliescu!'' Some spectators berated them and urged them to disperse. Two truckloads of army troops equipped with nightsticks and machine guns were parked nearby. Sen. Radu Campeanu, head of the Liberal Party, told reporters as lawmakers convened that his party would push for a special parliametary commission to investigate the clashes. His party's officies were sacked. Outside Parliament, Dan Iosif, a senator close to Iliescu, defended the government's actions. He said there were ``excesses on both sides'' but insisted the miners' excesses were ``not so blameworthy.'' Iliescu did nothing to stop the attacks, and his tactics cost the government Western aid. The violence ended after he thanked the miners ``with all my heart'' and ordered them home late Friday. That miners were called in to put down Thursday's rioting raised questions about whether Iliescu commands the loyalty of the police and army. Some Romanians wondered whether Iliescu's Front might have provoked the unrest in order to crack down on the opposition. The government claims Wednesday's rioting constituted a right-wing revolt. It has said the miners seized incriminating material from opposition party headquarters and elsewhere _ but has yet to produce any evidence. The University Square demonstrators accuse Iliescu's Front, which took power in the December revolution, of running a disguised version of the old Communist order. The Front won May 20 elections by a landslide, but Iliescu and many other of its leaders are former high-ranking Communist officials and opposition activists are demanding that former Communists be barred from holding office.

DOC.HEAD: Military Ruler Warns Against Early Power Transfer
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to update with military ruler saying government will not rush to relinquish power. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The head of Burma's military junta on Monday stressed that his government will not be rushed into handing over power to the civilian opposition that won national elections on May 27. Gen. Saw Maung said a new constitution must be drafted and emphasized that it will be a complicated and lengthy process. He spoke to members of historical commission. ``A constitution should be sound and stable so that there would be no subsequent problems arising out of its shortcomings,'' he said. He implied that the constitution adopted in 1947 at the end of British rule was flawed and led to national strife that climaxed with the 1988 civilian uprising against the military. Burmese took to the streets that year to press for democracy, briefly triumphed, then were brutally crushed by army gunfire. Several thousand civilians were killed. ``We will not tolerate recurrence of the 1988 situation,'' said the general, ``and will not tolerate endangerment to our three basic duties _ preventing disintegration of the union, preventing disintegration of national solidarity, and perpetuating national independence and sovereignty.'' Referring to foreign media comments urging an immediate transfer of power, Gen. Saw Maung said ``It is not a trivial matter. We are an independent nation and we are not subservient to any foreign influence. ``We have done what we should do and every person with an objective mind appreciates it. Except the insurgents, we have no opposition,'' he said. It appeared to be strong warning against pressure for immediate transfer of power. The opposition scored a huge victory over conservative, pro-military forces in the May 27 vote. Tallies show the Parliament will be overwhelmingly dominated by the junta's harshest critic, the National League for Democracy. The military has promised to yield power after newly elected legislators enact a constitution and form a civilian government. But many are skeptical this promise will be kept. Gen. Saw Maung seized power last September, replacing the 26-year socialist system of army strongman Ne Win, who many believe still holds behind-the-scenes power. The tense political scene in Burma is complicated by economic malaise and insurgencies by groups demanding more autonomy. Guerrillas of one of the groups, the Karen ethnic minority, attacked a ferry in eastern Burma on Saturday and wounded 17 passengers, the state-owned Working People's Daily said Monday. The paper said 20 guerrillas attacked the double decker ferry on the Salween River in Karen State, about 100 miles northeast of Rangoon. They retreated when security personnel aboard the ferry fired back, it said. The Karens have been fighting more than four decades. Rebel sources say fighting has resumed in the northern part of Karen State following a two-week lull that coincided with the May election. The Karens have suffered heavy losses during intensified government offensives in the past two years.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Gives Teeth To Pension Protection Agency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, There was, with 2 grafs LTV comment; picks up 9th graf pvs, Labor Secretary
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court gave broader powers Monday to an agency guarding the pensions of 30 million American workers, making it less likely that taxpayers will have to pay billions in bailouts down the road. By an 8-1 vote, the court said the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation acted within its authority when ordering LTV Corp. and its subsidiary, LTV Steel Co., to restore pension plans with unfundf $2.3 billion.ed liabilities o Government lawyers told the justices the appeals court ruling, if not overturned, could have led ``to a financial crisis similar to that currently facing'' the government insurance program for the savings and loan industry. Referring to the pension corporation's current deficits, Labor Department lawyer Joe McGowan had said, ``If they go bust, the taxpayer picks up the bill _ just like the S&Ls.'' James B. Lockhart, the PBGC's executive director, said Monday the decision ``removes a cloud that has been overhanging the agency for 2{ years.'' He said the ruling will discourage other companies from terminating pension plans through bankruptcy maneuvers. Michael S. Gordon, a Washington pensions lawyer, sl. An estimated 10,000 people were forced from their homes, and high water caused hundreds of millions of dollars in crop and property damage.

DOC.HEAD: Rex Harrison Remembered as an Actor of `Charm, Elegance and Wit'
DOC.TEXT: Rex Harrison was recalled Monday as an actor of ``charm, elegance and wit'' at a memorial that combined an Anglican church service, jazz interludes and recollections by colleagues and Harrison's sons, Carey and Noel. The crowd that gathered for the ceremony at the Church of the Transfiguration included such performers as Claudette Colbert, Glynis Johns, Douglas Fairbanks Jr., Kitty Carlisle Hart, Zoe Caldwell, Eileen Atkins, Maggie Smith and Cliff Robertson. Harrison, who died June 2 at age 82 of pancreatic cancer, was particularly remembered for portraying Henry Higgins in the stage and film versions of ``My Fair Lady.'' The role won him both a Tony and an Oscar. ``The craft of acting is a most secret, subtle and complicated mystery and the art of comedy perhaps the most difficult and mysterious quality to describe or define,'' said Miss Smith, now appearing on Broadway in ``Lettice & Lovage.'' ``But Rex Harrison somehow managed in his long career to master the difficulty and to understand the mystery. ``The charm was, of course, not always evident off-stage,'' she added as the congregation laughed. ``He seldom suffered fools gladly and his relationships with certain pompous directors and many overbearing leading ladies were often stormy. He could be exceedingly sharp. But to the general audience, whether in London or New York, he was the total matinee idol.'' Noel Harrison, the actor's older son, recalled some advice from his father _ ``Don't cower. Charge.'' _ three words he says he keeps in his heart as his father's epitaph. ``Striding _ that's how I remember him,'' Noel Harrison added. ``He loved to take walks. He didn't saunter. He strode, carrying himself with style with his head held high, putting the world and the elements to the test.'' Carey Harrison spoke of his father's keen sense of himself _ faults and all. ``He never preached to anyone, least of all, to his sons,'' Carey Harrison said. ``He forced us _ and God bless him for it, it was the only thing he forced on us _ to see him clearly as a man and not blindly as a parent. And that's how he'd want us, his sons, to talk about him _ as a man.'' Brendan Gill, retired theater critic of The New Yorker, praised Harrison's style on stage. ``He only had to step from the wings to seize our attention,'' Gill said. ``We leaned forward in our seats to hear the least utterance of that quirky, enchanting voice. Even before he spoke, his body language was, in effect, moving us.'' Gill also apologized on behalf of the American Theater Wing for not mentioning Harrison's death on the television broadcast of the 1990 Tony Awards. Harrison died the day before the awards ceremony. A remembrance by Jessica Tandy was planned, Gill said. ``But TV is an ill-mannered medium at best'' and because the program ran 20 minutes over schedule, the television tribute was never done.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Agency Honors Cambodian Refugee, Hawaiian Lei Maker, Montana Poet
DOC.TEXT: An elderly Pennsylvania silk weaver from Cambodia, a Hawaiian lei maker and a ``cowboy poet'' were among 13 folk artists honored by the government Monday for contributions to their traditional arts. Bun Em, 71, a Cambodian refugee who uses leftover silk from a Harrisburg, Pa., tie factory, was one of those honored by the National Endowment for the Arts. The winners each receive a $5,000 National Heritage Grant and will have their work displayed at the Capitol in the fall. There were 197 candidates for the NEA honors, many nominated by state arts agencies. The NEA began the grants in 1982 to honor the nation's most accomplished folk artists. The winners ``not only reflect the diversity of our multi-cultural background, but also help to preserve this richness for ours and generations to come,'' NEA Chairman John E. Frohmayer said in a prepared statement. The other winners were Marie McDonald, a lei maker from Waimea, Hawaii; Wallace McRae, a ``cowboy poet'' from Forsyth, Mont.; Howard Armstrong, a string band musician from Detroit; Natividad Cano, a Mexican mariachi musician from Monterey Park, Calif.; Giuseppe and Rafaela DeFranco, southern Italian musicians and dancers from Belleville, N.J.; and Maude Kegg, a Native American (Ojibwe) beadworker from Portage Lake, Minn. Also: Kevin Locke, a Native American (Lakota) flute player from the Standing Rock Indian Reservation, S.D.; Art Moilanen, a Finnish accordionist from Mass City, Mich.; Emilio Rosado, a woodcarver from Utuado, Puerto Rico; Robert Spicer, a buck and square dancer from Dickson. Tenn.; and Doug Wallin, a ballad singer from Marshall, N.C. Although the awards were announced Monday, the recipients won't formally be recognized until a reception and exhibition of the work here on Sept. 26. The NEA said Bun Em brought her four daughters and two sons to Pennsylvania in 1980. Speaking only halting English, she struggled to assimilate until given a loom and weaving materials by friends last year. That allowed her to continue a tradition that had brought status to her family for years in her native land. In Cambodia, Bun Em used silk from cocoons. In Pennsylvania, she uses silk left over from the men's tie factory and adds tapioca and coconut oil to give her sarong skirts more luster. The loom ``made Bun Em truly happy for the first time in nine years,'' according to a biography supplied by the NEA.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules on Need for Miranda for Suspected Drunken Drivers
With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Police may ask suspected drunken drivers most routine questions and videotape their answers without warning them of their rights, the Supreme Court ruled Monday. The 8-1 ruling in a Pennsylvania case means slurred responses to questions about age, height and weight may be used to convict motorists who have not been told they have a right to a lawyer and to remain silent. But the court said police may not ask a suspect more difficult questions _ for example, the date of the driver's sixth birthday _ without giving so-called Miranda warnings. Justice William J. Brennan, writing for the court, said responses to questions about height, weight and similar biographical data are ``admissible because the questions fall within a routine booking question exception which exempts (them) from Miranda's coverage.'' The court ordered a state court to consider reinstating the drunken-driving conviction of Inocencio Muniz. It was the second time in a week the court upheld police tactics to fight drunken driving. The court ruled last week that sobriety checkpoints don't violate motorists' rights. An Upper Allen Township, Pa., policeman noticed Muniz's car stopped by the side of the road Nov. 30, 1986, with the motor running. The officer said he smelled alcohol on Muniz's breath and that the man's eyes were glazed and bloodshot. The officer said he told Muniz not to drive until he was in a condition to operate the car safely, but Muniz drove off as the officer returned to his patrol car. The patrolman pursued Muniz, ordered him to stop and told him to perform some sobriety tests. Muniz failed all the tests. The officer took Muniz to a police station where the motorist was videotaped answering questions about his name, address, height, weight, eye color, date of birth, age and date of his sixth birthday. Only after those responses was Muniz given the Miranda warnings. Muniz, convicted previously of drunken driving, was convicted again and sentenced to 45 days to 23 months in prison. The Supreme Court action Monday reversed a Pennsylvania appeals court ruling that threw out the latter conviction in 1988. Brennan said permitting the judge who convicted Muniz to hear his slurred responses did not violate Muniz's privilege against self-incrimination. But Brennan said asking Muniz to state the date of his sixth birthday falls into a different category. Muniz ``was left with the choice of incriminating himself by admitting that he did not then know the date of his sixth birthday or answering untruthfully by reporting a date that he did not believe to be accurate,'' Brennan said. He said that unlike Muniz's responses to the other questions, the suspect's answer to the sixth-birthday question was incriminating because of its content, not just because of the delivery. Four justices said they would permit the sixth-birthday question as well. They are Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. Justice Thurgood Marshall dissented, voting to bar Muniz's conviction.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Hank Williams' long-lost daughter is delighted the U.S. Supreme Court thinks she should have the chance to fight in court for royalties from some of her late father's country music hits. The high court, without comment, on Monday let stand a federal appeals court ruling that Cathy Yvonne Stone, 37, is entitled to have her legal fight put before a jury. ``I feel wonderful,'' Ms. Stone said in a telephone interview from her Washington home. ``There's just not words. You really can't express it.'' The court also rejected an appeal by country singer Hank Williams Jr. that sought to reverse an Alabama Supreme Court ruling declaring Ms. Stone a legal heir to the elder Williams. ``I feel it's as big a victory for my father Hank Williams, as myself,'' she said. ``This is what should have been done in the beginning.'' Named as defendants in Ms. Stone's royalties suit are the younger Williams and other copyright owners. Ms. Stone was born in Alabama in 1953, five days after Williams died at age 29. Her mother, Bobbie Jett, and Williams had signed an agreement months earlier in which he acknowledged he might be the father. Years went by without her knowing her lineage, but ultimately she found out. Soon after marrying attorney Keith Adkinson in 1985, she filed federal and state court lawsuits seeking a share of Williams' songwriting royalties.

Former racing champ and auto designer Carroll Shelby was in fine tune Monday, less than two week after a pit stop for a heart transplant, a hospital spokesman said. ``He's great,'' said Ron Wise, spokesman for Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. ``He is making an outstanding recovery from his heart transplant, or as I refer to it, his new engine. ``We've changed Carroll Shelby's engine and he's very happy with it.'' Shelby, who had been suffering from congestive heart failure for about a year, got the transplanted heart June 8. Wise said he could be released next week. Shelby, 67, lives on his ranch in Pittsburg, Texas, about 120 miles northeast of Dallas. He was a three-time U.S. Sports Car Driver of the Year and designed of the famed Cobra muscle car. The American-built Cobras, the first affordable performance cars at $6,000, led to the first and only U.S. victories at LeMans in the mid-1960s.

The crowd of 100,000 people who jammed into the Riverbend Festival had to pay to see Bill Cosby, but police Sgt. Brian Bergenback got paid for his time with the down-to-earth TV comedian. Cosby took a limousine to the show Friday night, but told Bergenback he wanted to ride in a patrol car on the trip back to the Chattanooga airport. ``I thought he was kidding, but when he got back from performing, he got in the car and said, `Let's go,' '' Bergenback said. To avoid festival traffic and give Cosby some sightseeing, Bergenback drove up Corridor J, a new highway that the comedian called the last road in the United States without billboards. ``He also talked about how he thought Chattanooga was growing,'' Bergenback said. ``He said you can always tell how big a city is by how many car dealerships you have in one place.'' Bergenback said he and Cosby discussed ``normal things'' during the celebrity delivery. ``And he talked about the last time he rode in a police car,'' the sergeant said. ``He said they caught a speeder doing 82. Evidently he's done this before.''

The bygone days of sock hops and greasy kid stuff returned at a weekend nostalgia concert by Chubby Checker and Paul Revere and the Raiders. Checker got the crowd swiveling with the invitation, ``Come on baby, let's do the twist.'' A crowd of more than 4,000 joined in at the Nebraskaland Days show on Saturday. Checker was just 17 when he recorded the song that started a national dance craze in the 1960s. The singer, wearing red-and-black checkerboard shoes, told the audience he was unhurt in a concert tour bus accident in Oklahoma last week. ``The bus is totaled but we're still alive, thank God,'' he said. Revere and the Raiders wore tight white pants, knee-high silver boots and Colonial-style jackets. Revere wore his traditional three-cornered cap. Revere showed off a keyboard built into the grill of a Ford Mustang with renditions of ``Indian Nation,'' ``Shake It Up'' and ``Louie Louie,'' one of the most covered songs of the era. ``I'm here to tell you we recorded it first,'' Revere said of the song made famous by the Kingsmen, ``and I'm going to live long enough to play it last.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Announces New Ethics Chief
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday announced his long-delayed selection of a new director for the Office of Government Ethics, naming Washington D.C. lawyer Stephen D. Potts. Potts, 59, would succeed Frank Q. Nebeker, a holdover appointee. The ethics office reviews all personal financial filings of federal officials and interprets laws and regulations relating to conflicts of interest. During his presidential campaign, Bush vowed to enhance and expand the powers of the office and to appoint a ``senior counsellor to the president.'' Even so, the post has remained under interim management through the 17 months of Bush's presidency. His first choice for the job, Paul Pressler of Houston, a fundamentalist religious leader, was withdrawn from consideration after a routine FBI check uncovered what White House aides at the time called an ``ethics problem.'' Potts has been a partner with the law firm of Shaw, Pittman, Potts and Trowbridge since 1961. A native of Memphis and graduate of Vanderbilt University, Potts is a former vice president of the Cherokee Life Insurance Co. in Nashville, Tenn. A White House fact sheet on Potts also notes that ``Mr. Potts has won five national Father-Son Tennis Championships.''

DOC.HEAD: Rostenkowski to Mayors: The Check is NOT in the Mail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf pvs with Flynn reax, Kerrey speech; picks up 6th graf pvs, ``During the...; DELETES final 2 grafs to tighten
DOC.TEXT: A leading congressional Democrat bluntly told the nation's mayors Monday they stood no chance of getting billions _ or even millions _ more for urban programs from expected federal defense savings. ``There's no money for such programs until the budget blockade is broken,'' House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski told the U.S. Conference of Mayors. ``The peace dividend is already going to be swallowed.'' Rostenkowski's address to the more than 200 mayors quickly dampened the spirits of a group that for three days had been making the case that cities need a multibillion dollar infusion from the federal government to fight drugs, poverty, housing, education and other problems. Rostenkowski came home to Chicago to tell the mayors they would be going it alone. ``Yours is not an easy task,'' the congressman said in a speech blaming the Reagan administration for most festering urban problems. He added that Congress, too, was far from ready to come to the aid of mayors and that taxpayers were unlikely to support higher taxes to help cities. ``He devastated everybody,'' said Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn. Later, the mayors heard a somewhat more encouraging talk from Democratic Sen. Robert Kerrey of Nebraska. Still, even Kerrey said peace dividend money will not ``fall like manna from heaven'' to cities. Mayors' hopes rest on selling their ideas to voters, much like Reagan sold his military buildup in the early 1980s, Kerrey said. During the weekend, the mayors crafted an ambitious, costly battle plan for attacking urban problems. The centerpiece of the plan was a demand that money from the programs come from expected defense cuts, with the mayors seeking half of whatever savings materialize. Rostenkowski's speech in effect made much of the mayors' new lobbying agenda appear moot even before it gets final approval Wednesday. Rostenkowski said he personally would support most of the mayors' causes but decided in advance of the speech not to offer an upbeat prognosis. ``Lying is not only dishonest it can also be politically dangerous,'' he said. He closed his speech by saying, ``I'm going to tell you the way it is. If you don't like it, too bad.'' The mayors didn't like it. ``The cities are in desperate need,'' said Atlanta's Maynard Jackson. ``I have heard your calls for strong leadership but what we need are strong answers.'' When Madison, Wis., Mayor Paul Songlin challenged Rostenkowski and fellow Democrats to tell President Bush that Congress was giving billions to cities and that money to bail out failing savings and loans would have to be found elsewhere, the congressman was characteristically blunt. ``We haven't got the votes,'' he said. Rostenkowski said he believed taxpayers would support new taxes for the environment and perhaps for basic services. But he said they were ``very suspicious'' about higher taxes to help cities and their needy residents because of perceived abuses of past programs, including those at the Reagan-era Department of Housing and Urban Development. As for raising taxes to slash the deficit, Rostenkowski said taxpayers ``get downright surly when we say we have to raise taxes to pay for the past before we can even think about the future.'' Still, he said some new taxes were inevitable, and likely to be included in a deficit-cutting pact Congress is trying to negotiate with the White House. ``We need to slash spending and raise taxes merely to reach ground zero,'' Rostenkowski said. ``Until then we will be fiddling at the margins.'' Rostenkowski said housing, education and racial problems in the nation's cities were greatly exacerbated because ``in the last administration there was ignorance and indifference to America's cities.'' In Bush, Rostenkowski said cities have a president whose rhetoric is full of support but whose programs are little different from his predecessor. ``Unfortunately, will without wallet doesn't yield much of a result,'' he said. Rostenkowski said he and other big-city Democrats in Congress fail to win more federal support for cities because of powerful rural lobbies that back huge farm subsidies _ ``even for millionaires'' _ and rural health care. The result, he said, is cities get no help to combat drugs and violence at the root of so many other urban problems. ``Political turf wars can be equally destructive, even if they are less bloody,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Plans Live Coverage of Most Mandela Events
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network plans live broadcasts of most events during Nelson Mandela's visit to eight U.S. cities beginning this week, but other networks will limit most coverage to regular news programs. CNN spokesman John Bianchi said CNN would report live on the South African black nationalist leader's visits to New York, Boston, Washington, Atlanta, Miami, Detroit, Los Angeles and Oakland, June 20-July 1. He said separate scheduled events involving Winnie Mandela would be taped for showing on regular news programs. Mandela is to be guest at a special ``Town Meeting'' to be taped Thursday at City College of New York for broadcast that evening on ABC, and also will appear on the network that night as a guest on Ted Koppel's ``Nightline.'' ABC was undecided on further live coverage as of Monday noon, according to spokesman Arnot Walker. CBS spokesman Tom Goodman said CBS would cover the Mandela visit ``if news warrants'' but planned no prior announcement. NBC planned regular coverage and was undecided whether to cover live the African leader's scheduled address to a joint session of Congress next week, said network spokeswoman Catherine McQuay. His arrival in New York on Wednesday will be broadcast live on the NBC ``Today'' show, she said. Mandela is scheduled for two appearances Friday on PBS, a live 15-minute interview with co-host Robert MacNeil on ``The MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour'' at 7 p.m. and an interview with Charlayne Hunter-Gault, taped earlier that day for showing at 10 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists To Gather Data on Climate Changes in Forests
