DOC.TEXT: Fourteen scientists from the United States and the Soviet Union will spend the summer camping in the backcountry of Siberia to study climate changes, the Agriculture Department said Monday. The joint team will then collect similar information in the United States. Officials said the objective is to examine the possible effects of climate change on forests. The project is sponsored by the department's Forest Service and Moscow's State Forest Committee and organized by the Institute for Resource Management, a non-profit environmental group founded by actor Robert Redford. Field research will be coordinated by the University of California at Santa Barbara under the direction of Daniel B. Botkin and the Soviet Union's All-Union Scientific Research Center of the State Forest Committee, directed by Anatoly Z. Shvidenko. Patricia Kearney, acting assistant secretary for natural resources and environment, said in a statement that the venture is ``a unique opportunity to work cooperatively with the Soviet Union'' toward improved management of natural resources. Kearney and Terrell Minger, president of the institute, are in Moscow attending a climate change workshop to coordinate procedures and plans for the project. The Soviet research sites are in Yakutsk, in eastern Siberia, and in the Komi region in western Russia. After two months, the team will collect similar information at U.S. sites in Caribou Creek, Alaska, appoximately 40 miles north of Fairbanks, and the Boundary Waters Canoe Area in the Superior National Forest, Minnesota. The department did not name the U.S. scientists participating in the joint research project.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials Say Gadhafi May Be Building New Chemical Weapons Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs `The officials ...' with 3 grafs to ADD quote. Picks up 3rd graf pvs `Even so, ...'
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi may be building a second chemical weapons factory at a remote underground location hundreds of miles south of Tripoli, Bush administration officials disclosed Monday. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in interviews with The Associated Press that it's not clear whether construction is complete. ``We're not sure until then'' what exactly the facility will be, one official said. However, the officials declined to say how the activity that points to work on a second plant was detected or to pinpoint the exact location. Even so, the State Department publicly registered concern. ``It's dangerous for the entire region, and for the entire world, you could say,'' said spokesman Richard Boucher. ``There are reports that Libya has already used a weapon of mass destruction _ chemical weapons _ in combat and because of the Gadhafi regime's support for terrorism,'' Boucher said. He referred to allegations that Libya used chemical weapons in an invasion of Chad, a neighboring African country, several years ago. U.S. intelligence, with assistance from such friendly countries as France and Israel, keeps watch over Gadhafi's military activities. ``We don't comment on intelligence matters generally,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said when asked about a report in Monday's Washington Times that Libya as building a second plant. ``On the other hand we are making an assessment. We just don't have any conclusions to give,'' he said. The officials said Gadhafi's purpose in building a second plant would be to divert some poison gas production from Rabta even though the purported March fire at the factory, about 40 miles south of Tripoli, evidently was a hoax. ``There was little damage, and we're still talking about the possibility of a hoax,'' an official said. ``In fact, that's the only possibility under consideration.'' Fitzwater also said the Rabta fire apparently was a hoax _ and also ``a pretty clear indication of intentions and willingness to deceive the world in order to further their own intents on this issue,'' ``We're prepared to believe the worst,'' Fitzwater said. Gadhafi says the Rabta plant is a pharmaceutical production factory. However, U.S. and West German officials have said it was producing small amounts of chemical weapons and that Libya was on the verge of bringing production up to full capacity. Boucher called Rabta a dangerous facility. ``We're very seriously concerned about it,'' he said. ``Were reports of a second chemical weapons production facility to prove true, our concern would be that much greater. Our position remains that any chemical weapons facility in Libya must be dismantled.'' Boucher said Rabta was still capable of producing chemical weapons. ``We've spoken with many countries capable of supplying manpower, expertise or equipment to a Libyan chemical weapons facility,'' he said. ``We have urged them, of course, not to do so. Last week, West German businessman Jurgen Hippenstiel-Imhausen confessed in a regional court in Mannheim that he was responsible for secretly selling a chemical production plant to Libya for $150 million. Meanwhile, the Libyan news agency JANA, monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp., quoted Gadhafi as urging scientists Sunday to ``work day and night'' to build a nuclear weapon ``in defiance of America.'' He also called for development of Libyan space technology. ``America manufactures missiles and puts above our heads satellites,'' Gadhafi was quoted as saying. ``This provokes you and ignites in you the spirit of defiance and revolution to reach space and manufacture the atom.'' He blamed the United States for withholding technology Libya needs. Gadhafi also accused Israel of aiming nuclear weapons at Arab cities.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Hear Opening Statements in Third Bensonhurst Trial
DOC.TEXT: The third defendant in the Bensonhurst racial slaying played a key role in assembling the white mob that attacked and killed a black teen-ager last summer, a prosector said Monday in her opening argument. The 21-year-old defendant, John Vento, also heard Joseph Fama, convicted of murder in the ase, say he was going to shoot one of the blacks and knew Fama was carrying a pistol, Assistant District Attorney Pamela Hayes told the jury. The attack, Ms. Hayes said, ``was to be a group project. One for all and all for one.'' Vento, she said, was as guilty of the killing as the trigger man. ``John Vento was no mere follower,'' she said. Defense lawyer Gerald DiChiara maintained that Fama, who prosecutors said was the triggerman, acted independently in shooting Yusuf Hawkins in the chest. Vento was present and ready to fight if necessary, DiChiara acknowledged, but neither hurt nor threatened anyone. ``Nobody saw Joey Fama with a gun that night until it was too late,'' the lawyer said. Fama, he said, acted alone and without warning when he pulled an automatic pistol and shot the 16-year-old Hawkins. ``Yusuf Hawkins was not kicked to death. Yusuf Hawkins was not beaten to death. It was not a mob that caused Yusuf Hawkins to die,'' DiChiara said. DiChiara also cited the deal Vento struck with prosecutors after fleeing New York following the Aug. 23 slaying. In September, Vento called prosecutors and said he had taken part in the attack in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section. In exchange for immunity from prosecution, Vento agreed to testify before a grand jury and said he would take the stand against his friends. But around Christmas, Vento again fled New York. ``If he was this evil kid they just described in their opening statement, do you think they would have considered that deal?'' DiChiara asked of the pact Vento made with prosecutors in the weeks after the slaying. In March, Vento surrendered to federal law enforcers in Ohio, but said he would no longer honor his agreement to cooperate. He was indicted by a grand jury. He was charged with two counts of second-degree murder, riot, assault, unlawful imprisonment, menacing, aggravated harassment, discrimination and criminal possession of a weapon, and is being held without bail. Vento faces 25 years to life in prison if convicted of murder. Fama was convicted May 17 of murdering Hawkins. The following day, co-defendant Keith Mondello was acquitted of murder and manslaughter charges, but was found guilty of several lesser crimes. Both 19-year-olds were given the maximum sentences _ 32 and two-third years to life for Fama, and five and one-third to 16 years in prison for Mondello.

DOC.HEAD: Kashmiri Secessionists form Provisional Government
DOC.TEXT: Militant Kashmiris declared a government-in-exile Monday to advance their Moslem secessionist movement in the disputed region between India and Pakistan. The move complicates already tense relations between the two countries. Their governments agreed Monday to talks aimed at easing the threat of war ovr Kashmir. Amanullah Khan, chairman of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, announced the government-in-exile at a news conference in Muzzaffarabad, capital of Pakistan-held Kashmir. His front is one of the key groups behind the uprising in India's Jammu-Kashmir state. A former Indian ambassador to the United States, Karan Singh, was named a member of the 24-seat Cabinet, said Liberation Front spokesman Raja Muzzafar. Khan's organization wants the former princely state of Kashmir, now split between India and Pakistan, to be reunited and granted independence. Clashes during the 6-month-old uprising, mostly in India, have left more than 550 people dead. Monday's announcement by the secessionists came shortly before India formally agreed to high-level talks with Pakistan to defuse tension along their common border. Indian officials said delegates from the two nations will meet early next month but a date and site has not been set. In Islamabad, Pakistan's foreign secretary, Tanvir Ahmed Khan, confirmed the proposed meeting. ``I think this is a welcome development,'' he said. ``This could be a good beginning.'' India and Pakistan both claim Kashmir, a predominately Moslem state that joined mainly Hindu India when Britain partitioned the subcontinent along religious lines in 1947. India and Pakistan fought wars over Kashmir in 1948 and 1965. The territory is now divided by a cease-fire line, and the armies of both countries have massed troops and artillery along the border. India accuses Pakistan of arming and training Moslem Kashmiri militants who are fighting for independence from India. Pakistan denies the charges but supports the uprising on the Indian side of the cease-fire line, calling it a movement for self-determination. An Indian official said the new government-in-exile could endanger the planned talks. ``It is certainly not going to help Pakistan or ... relations, and I hope it has not derailed this process of opening talks,'' said one senior official at the Indian High Commission, the embassy in Islamabad. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Militant members of Khan's group have warned the uprising could spill into Pakistan if it refuses demands for independence. But Tanvir Ahmed Khan, Pakistan's foreign secretary, rejected Khan's government and the group's demands for independence. Pakistan has instead called for a plebiscite that would allow Kashmiris to decide whether to join Pakistan or India. ``There was no question of a third choice,'' Ahmed Khan said Monday. Muzzaffar refused to identify the headquarters of his new government. The Indian embassy official warned that peace talks with Pakistan would be ``very difficult'' if Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government allows Khan's provisional government to establish its headquarters in Pakistan. The newly elected president of Pakistan-controlled Azad (Free) Kashmir, Sultan Mahmood, also rejected Khan's government. ``There is already a government; there is no need for his,'' Mahmood said. ``I don't think of myself as only the president of Azad Kashmir, but also of Indian-occupied Kashmir.'' Most of India's 880 million people are Hindus. Kashmir is the country's only Moslem majority state.

DOC.HEAD: Tilt-Rotor V-22 Osprey Makes Emergency Landing
DOC.TEXT: An experimental tilt-rotor aircraft designed to hover like a helicopter and fly like an airplane made an emergency landing Monday after one of two engines failed, a spokesman said. The V-22 Osprey lost power in its left engine, but was able to return safely to Arlington Municipal Airport, said Terry Arnold, spokesman for Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. No injuries or damage to the prototype aircraft were reported after the 10 a.m. malfunction in the skies about 40 miles southwest of downtown Dallas, Arnold said. ``Actually, we're pleased, because the aircraft did what it was supposed to do,'' Arnold said. ``The other engine engaged the shaft and drove both rotor systems and we landed without incident. It was designed to do just that.'' Arnold said it was the first emergency landing on record for the V-22. The cause of the malfunction was not immediately known. The Osprey can hover and land like a helicopter but also flies at up to 340 mph as a fixed-wing airplane _ much faster than a helicopter. Large rotors on the ends of the wings tilt up for vertical flight and rotate forward for the long haul. Arnold said the aircraft, one of four Osprey prototypes, was in ``airplane mode'' when the engine failed. It flew in ``airplane mode'' back to the airport, where it swooped down and landed like a helicopter, said Bob Leder, another Bell Helicopter Textron spokesman. The four prototypes are among six Ospreys for which the Pentagon has contracted. The Defense Department has spent $2 billion to develop the V-22 Osprey and its predecessor, the XV-15, for military use. But Defense Secretary Dick Cheney wants to end funding in favor of conventional helicopter development.

DOC.HEAD: `Mr. Potato' Wins $200,000 World Food Prize
DOC.TEXT: John S. Niederhauser, dubbed ``Mr. Potato'' for his work developing a blight-resistant strain of spuds, won the $200,000 World Food Prize on Monday. Niederhauser's work increased potato harvests and helped prevent famine in developing nations, said Norman Borlaug, founder of the prize. ``His achievements toward developing a blight-resistant potato variety have affected countries from Mexico to Bangladesh,'' Borlaug said. ``Without a doubt, Dr. Niederhauser's discoveries have had a dramatic impact on the food-deficient regions of the world.'' The World Food Prize rewards research in production or distribution of food. Niederhauser is the fourth recipient. Niederhauser worked for a private agricultural research foundation in Mexico and by 1982 was working with a similar group in Poland. He developed a strain of potato resistant to late blight disease, the disease blamed for the great potato famine that devastated Ireland and other European countries about a century ago. Niederhauser also works as a consultant for Biosphere II, a research program developing a sealed food production environment that could be self-sustaining. ``The challenge is enormous,'' Niederhauser said. ``By 2010, if there is a trip to Mars, the crew, using some of the technology developed in the Biosphere II, could produce their own food en route and eliminate one of the major limiting factors of such a trip.'' Borlaug won the 1970 Nobel Peace Prize for his research fostering the ``green revolution'' in developing nations. The World Food Prize is funded by private donors.

DOC.HEAD: Journalist's Body Mistakenly Cremated
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines is investigating a ``paperwork mix-up'' that led to the accidental cremation of the body of a California newspaper executive. A spokesman for the airline said Sunday that the mix-up took place at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport after a plane arrived from California carrying John P. Brownell's body and the body of a South Dakotan. Brownell, 33, was a deputy managing editor of the Los Angeles Times. He was a native of Minnesota. His body had been scheduled to be put on a flight to Rochester, en route to his home town of St. Charles. But the South Dakotan's body was sent instead, and Brownell's body was taken to a crematory in Mound, just outside Minneapolis. ``It was a paperwork mix-up,'' Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons said. He added that the airline is trying to find out exactly what went wrong. Brownell's family learned last Wednesday that he had been cremated. Funeral services were held as scheduled the next day in St. Charles. Brownell's father, Melvin, said a Northwest Airlines representative called him and said the airline ``knew what had occurred, but didn't know how it had occurred.'' The family will continue to look into the incident, he said. Brownell, who died of AIDS complications June 9 at a hospital in Sherman Oaks, Calif., was the youngest journalist to become a top news executive at the Times.

DOC.HEAD: Panel of 18 Picked in Mayor's Drug and Perjury Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf with occupations of some panel members
DOC.TEXT: A panel of 18 people was chosen Monday to weigh the cocaine and perjury charges against Mayor Marion Barry, including one who opposes police undercover operations. Another says she believes race may have played a role in Barry's prosecution. A third says she's reluctant to judge a fellow human being. Twelve of the 18 will be designated as jurors when deliberations begin. The other six will be dismissed. The panel will be sworn in Tuesday, then hear opening statements. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ordered the 18 _ picked from 81 District of Columbia residents _ to be sequestered for the duration of the trial. Jackson did not say why he would wait to announce which six of the 18 are alternates. Barry, who announced last week that he wouldn't seek re-election, sat facing the jury box during Monday's hour-long court session. The panel includes 13 blacks and five whites. Under court rules, the prosecution was permitted to dismiss a maximum of nine prospective jurors, the defense 13. The prosecution dismissed seven, all of them black. The defense dismissed a dozen, 10 of them white. Barry, 54, is black, and a number of prospective jurors questioned over the last two weeks said they thought race and politics had played a role in the investigation and prosecution of the three-term mayor. Many of the 18 expressed reluctance to be jurors and said they already have formed opinions about the investigation and prosecution of Barry. But all said, in questioning as prospective jurors, that they would set aside their personal views if called to deliberate the mayor's fate. One member of the panel, Harriedell Jones, said she regards the undercover operation against Barry as unfair and added that she felt race had played a role in the case. ``If his race was different, they would go about'' investigating and prosecuting Barry ``differently,'' she said. Barry was arrested at a hotel in January after the FBI videotaped him allegedly smoking crack cocaine. Barry had been persuaded to come to the room by ex-model Rasheeda Moore, who was cooperating with the government. Another prospective juror, Marsena Hall, said during questioning that ``I don't want to be put'' in a situation of having to sit in judgment of Barry or anyone else. ``I really don't feel like I can'' judge a fellow human being, Hall said when questioned by assistant U.S. attorney Judith Retchin. She told R. Kenneth Mundy, Barry's lawyer, that she could be fair and impartial regarding the evidence in the mayor's case. Another panel member, Joyce Hines, said ``I think anything done undercover is wrong. ``I think everything should be done out in the open,'' Hines said at one point in her questioning as a prospective juror. But Hines said she would follow the court's instructions. The judge will instruct the panel that the FBI sting operation was legal. Another prospective juror, Valerie Jackson-Warren, called undercover operations ``a little sneaky'' and said the ``sting'' against Barry was unfair. The FBI videotape is the heart of the government's case. Barry is charged with 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, one misdemeanor count of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his alleged involvement with drugs. Jones expressed an opinion about Barry's grand jury testimony. ``I think he might'' have lied to the grand jury, she said. The panel members include a high school history teacher, a courier for a local messenger service, an unemployed school crossing guard and an accounting assistant at the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.

DOC.HEAD: New Swedish Law to Give Homosexuals Rights of Married People
DOC.TEXT: The government proposed Monday to give gay couples many of the same rights as married people in areas such as taxation, inheritance and divorce. If the proposal is passed by parliament, Sweden will be the second country after Denmark to introduce a kind of marriage for homosexuals. No U.S. state has such a law. In Sweden, the legal union for male and female homosexuals would be called ``partnership.'' It would include the same rules on taxation, inheritance, divorce and taking a spouse's last name as for married heterosexual couples. However, it would not let gay couples adopt children. Swedish television said that if passed, the measure would take effect next year. ``We will be the second country in the world that in this way not only legalizes that homosexuals live together, but also gives the society's blessing through registration and in the form of legal rights,'' said Carl-Anders Ifvarsson, a director at the National Health Board. His agency presented the proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Ask Administration to Help Phase Out Damaging Chemical
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf: ``Thomas Snead,'' with two new grafs State Dept. comment
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group called on the Bush administration Monday to participate in an international effort to phase out a commonly used chemical that is depleting the ozone layer. The Natural Resources Defense Council also urged consumers to avoid buying 141 products, ranging from artists' varnishes to hornet-killing sprays, that contain the chemical 1,1,1-trichloroethane. Chloroflourocarbons, or CFCs, have been singled out as the most potent ozone-destroying substances. But the council said 1,1,1, as it is known for short, is responsible for a large share of ozone depletion because it is produced in such large quantities. Approximately 724 million pounds of 1,1,1 were produced in 1988 by DOW Chemical, PPG Industries, and Vulcan Chemical, according to the NRDC. The group said 90 percent of the chemical is used in industrial solvents. Consumer goods that contain it include Scotchgard fabric protectors manufactured by 3M Products of St. Paul. ``For most applications, there are alternative products on the market that serve the same purpose'' both in industry and individual homes, the NRDC said. Representatives of 70 nations will open a 10-day meeting in London on Wednesday to consider revisions to an international agreement that freezes production and consumption of CFCs at their 1986 level. The pact, known as the Montreal Protocol, also calls for a 50 percent reduction in CFCs by 1998. ``The most difficult decisions remaining relate to 1,1,1-trichloroethane,'' said David D. Doniger, director of the NRDC's ozone protection project. He said options under consideration range from a 25 percent rollback to a complete phase-out in the next 10 years. Doniger said Japan, the United States and the European Community are balking at going further than 50 percent. But he said that would not be sufficient to prevent serious damage to the ozone layer. ``So we call on the nations represented in London _ and particularly on the United States _ to do all that is needed to protect the ozone layer,'' the NRDC attorney said. ``Let's not settle for another treaty that goes only part way.'' Thomas Snead, special assistant for public affairs in the State Department's office of environmental affairs, said he was not able to say what the U.S. proposal would be because it was ``part of the negotiating position.'' ``Evidently it will be one of the things that they will be discussing at the meetings of the parties,'' Snead said. The NRDC and other environmental groups have argued that man-made chemicals are stripping away the Earth's ozone layer, permitting more of the sun's ultraviolet rays to slip through and increasing the danger of cancer and environmental damage. Rick Renner, a spokesman for 3M, said the company is working on replacements for 1,1,1. ``I have to say that this is not easy,'' Renner said. ``At this point, the available substitutes tend to be flammable, contribute to global warming and contribute to smog and are toxic, and we are not using them.'' Four varnishes and fixatives marketed by M. Grumbacher Inc., a Cranbury, N.J.-based art supply firm, were on the NRDC list of consumer products containing 1,1,1. Godfrey Chambers, technical services manager for Grumbacher, said the four products _ Damar varnish, Myston, Retouch varnish and Tuffilm fixative - are manufactured by a supplier and purchased by Grumbacher for resale. ``The person we purchase it from is continuing research in this matter to try and eliminate it,'' Chambers said. He said the company has already removed 1,1,1 from some of its other aerosols.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Pilot Flies 12-Seater to Turkey, Requests Asylum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details, attribution. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet pilot landed a passenger plane on a beach on Turkey's Black Sea coast Monday and asked for political asylum. Officials quoted him as saying he wanted to flee the ``undemocratic regime'' in Moscow. A government announcement said the pilot was alone in the Antonov-2 plane when it landed near Kumcagiz, a village in Kocaeli province. The official Soviet news agency Tass said the 12-seat plane was seized in Izmail, near the Ukrainian port of Odessa. The report offered few details. The Turkish statement identified the pilot as Valeri Yuricevic. Kocaeli Gov. Ihsan Dede said Yuricevic was married and had a child. He said the pilot recently separated from his wife. Tass said the pilot resigned several months ago from his job with an Odessa air crew. Officials quoted Yuricevic as saying during an interrogation that he escaped ``the undemocratic regime'' in his country and wanted to live in Turkey. Dede told The Associated Press that Yuricevic, 29, complained about harsh living conditions in the Soviet Union, where shortages are widespread and economic problems continue. He said the pilot did not elaborate. Dede said Yuricevic's request for political asylum was being examined. State TV showed the plane near the coastline. A village girl interviewed on television said residents watched the plane land. She said the pilot approached her after he got out of the plane and spoke to her in Russian. Another villager said the pilot was shaking and looked nervous. Villagers brought the pilot to the police station, Dede said. The plane, flying at low altitude, made the trip in two hours. Turkey's announcement said the plane was tracked immediately after it entered Turkish airspace and military planes were put on alert. However, the plane was allowed to land safely when authorities determined it posed no threat. There are no airports in the province. A government official, who requested anoynmity, said the Soviets immediately asked Turkey to return the plane and the pilot. Dede said local officials were waiting for a team of technical experts to move the plane, which sunk into the sand on the beach. When a Soviet air force captain defected to this country in a MIG-29 jet a year ago, Turkey allowed the plane to be flown back to the Soviet Union but sent the pilot to the United States upon his request.

DOC.HEAD: Volunteers Prepare for Wave of Tar Balls
DOC.TEXT: Volunteers gathered on a beach Monday to begin searching for a wave of tar balls expected to come ashore this week from the wrecked super tanker Mega Borg. A Mexican vessel continued to skim oil off the Gulf of Mexico. Although hundreds of volunteers were expected, only about 60 showed up Monday morning at Sea Rim State Park between High Island and Sabine Pass for the first beach sweep. They walked the sandy shoreline picking up seaweed, trash and tar balls from smaller oil spills to make it easier to clean up any oil from the Norweigan-owned tanker. Small amounts of tar frequently wash up on the beach here. ``They said they needed volunteers and I said, `Does that mean me?' And I said, `Why not me?''' said Jo Krose, who drove two hours from Kirbyville to participate in the beach cleanup. ```They need some help and nobody's depending on me today, so I came down,'' she said. State officials expect several hundred more volunteers to help in the cleanup this week, said Andy Mangan, deputy Texas land commissioner. Tar balls are predicted to begin washing ashore on Tuesday somewhere along a 45-mile stretch northeast of Galveston. The area predicted to be hit is between High Island and Sabine Pass, a town near the Texas-Louisiana line. The 30-mile oil slick was about seven miles offshore Monday and had been moving about two miles a day, the Coast Guard said. Officials hoped the oil would hit the sandy beaches rather than the marshes, where wildlife refuges are located. Sandy beaches are easier to clean. ``The major part of the toxicity has gone (dissipated from the oil),'' said Sharon Christopherson of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Adminstration. ``The longer it stays out there, the less oil you'll see come ashore.'' Although Coast Guard officials said most of the 3.9 million gallons of oil that has leaked from the vessel has either burned off or been collected, they conceded they were not sure how much remained on the water. ``It's really hard. I keep telling you 12,000 to 40,000 gallons and now we've picked up 250,000, and my credibility is waning here,'' said Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene. He said 250,000 gallons had been collected d3of Sunday, but the figure is rising. A 200-foot-long skimming vessel owned by Pemex, the national oil company of Mexico, was being used to suck oil off the water. The vessel was first used Sunday to suck about 63,000 gallons of mostly oil and water from the Gulf. About 12 skimmers have been used during the past week to get more oil off the water. The Mexican vessel works by opening its front end, sucking up the oil and water and filtering it so the oil can be reused. This is the first time it has been used on open waters, said Armando Espinola, a vice admiral with the Mexican Navy. The vessel can suction up to 1,000 gallons an hour. ``It exceeded my expectations,'' Greene said. ``I had no idea what it could do.'' Professional cleanup crews also laid booms Monday to help protect the shore from oil that leaked from the tanker, now crippled some 57 miles off Galveston. Salvage crews also continued to pump water from the five-ravaged pump and engine rooms and a cargo tank that spilled the oil. They also poured more firefighting foam on the cargo tank to keep it from reigniting. Coast Guard Cmdr. Michael Slack said crews plan to begin transferring oil from the tanker to a smaller vessel on Tuesday. The 886-foot Mega Borg was carrying 38 million gallons of light Angolan crude oil when it was rocked by an explosion June 8. Two crew members died and two are missing and presumed dead.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria Elects Parliament Dominated by ex-Communists
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria on Monday became the first East European nation to freely elect a Parliament dominated by the former Communist Party, opting for a slow changeover to a market economy. While Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years ends the Communists' rubber-stamp domination of politics, it also ensures a sizeable opposition with enough votes to veto constitutional proposals. ``We will resolutely ... move in the direction of a democratic European leftist party,'' Premier Andrei Lukanov said, expressing confidence he could form a government of consensus. But the leader of the main opposition alliance rejected any deal with the former Communists. According to official results of Sunday's runoff elections, the ruling Socialist Party, which until April was the Communist Party, clinched an absolute majority with 211 seats in the 400-seat Parliament. The main opposition Union of Democratic Forces (UDF), a 16-party alliance, captured 144 seats, the ethnic Turkish Rights and Freedoms Movement won 23 seats, and the mainstream Agrarian Party 16. Smaller parties and independents won six seats. The capital Sofia, going against the nationwide trend, voted overwhelmingly for the opposition, electing UDF candidates for 24 of 26 available seats. Analysts say the Socialists represent stability for many who feared the loss of jobs and social upheaval in a quick switch to private ownership favored by the UDF. The Socialists favor leaving some industry state-run for now. Bulgaria has a nearly century-old Communist tradition, more deeply rooted than elsewhere in Eastern Europe, and the current Socialist leadership scored points for ousting hard-liner Todor Zhivkov in November and initiating gradual reforms. The Socialist leaders were also seen as more charismatic and their campaign more professional than the seven-month-old UDF. Apart from Bulgaria, non-Communist parties have triumphed in this year's round of national elections in East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Hungary following last year's regional revolutions. In Romania, the National Salvation Front that won a landslide victory includes many ex-Communists. The new government must tackle the country's $10 billion foreign debt, rising inflation and shortages of basic goods. The newly elected unicameral Grand National Assembly must also write a constitution, which requires two-thirds approval for adoption. Victorious Socialist Party leaders, many carrying red carnations, were applauded and kissed by cheering supporters. In an interview with The Associated Press, Lukanov reiterated his refusal to head a Cabinet composed only of members of his own Socialist party. He welcomed remarks made by UDF chairman Zhelyu Zhelev about the possibility of what Lukanov described as ``a government of responsible and competent personalities.'' ``This does not mean I accept his idea. I note with great interest his recognition that a government ... if it is to be successful has to be supported by all political forces,'' Lukanov declared. But Zhelev told The AP the UDF would not be part of a Socialist government though another senior UDF official, Petar Beron, said a government of experts remained a possible consideration. The UDF Coordinating Council, the alliance's executive organ, was scheduled to meet Tuesday to hammer out a joint stand, and informed sources said heated discussions were expected. Zhelev described the outcome of the elections ``means we are a strong constructive opposition, and the BSP (Socialists) will be a weak one-party government.'' He said the idea of a government of non-political professionals was made when there was a real likelihood of a hung Parliament. ``In such a situation, as is usual in theory and practice in the world, they have to form their own government,'' Zhelev explained. ``If they don't like that, they can form a government of experts of their own, but we will not be part of it.'' Lukanov, 51, a multilingual economics expert, suggested a split in his party _ possibly at a new party congress this fall _ and in the UDF could change Bulgaria's political landscape and ensure ultimate stability. ``The present distribution of forces is rather artificial,'' the premier noted. ``It hides the diversity of views, nuances, ideologies ...'' The Socialists gained 172 seats in first-round voting June 10 and needed to capture only 29 of the 81 seats at stake in Sunday's runoff to win a majority. According to the official results released by the Central Electoral Commission, the Socialists won 39 and the UDF won 37. The remainder went to independents and smaller parties. State television reported some voting irregularities in the runoff. Dimiter Ivanov, an activist from the Association of Fair Elections, said in some cases the number of people voting exceeded the number of people registered in the respective precincts.

DOC.HEAD: Big Thunderstorms Rattle Northeast, Unseasonable Heat Simmers Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Severe thunderstorms rattled parts of the Northeast on Monday, with severe wind damage reported in upstate New York and heavy rains, flooding and hail reported in northern Pennsyvlania. Elsewhere in the nation, unseasonably hot weather baked the lower middle South. An elderly West Point, Neb., man was found dead Monday, killed in floods that continued to plague northeast Nebraska. Showers and thunderstorms extended by noon over western Maine, across western New England, much of the southeast half of New York state, and northeast through north-central and central Pennsylvania. A woman in Brownville, N.Y., was injured when thunderstorm-spawned winds overturned her mobile home. The fast-moving storms left fires, blackouts and houses crushed by toppled trees in their wake. Mayor Charles Brennan declared a state of emergency after falling trees crushed houses and blocked streets in Brownville, a village about 60 miles north of Syracuse. Firefighters were treated for minor injuries after battling a lightning-caused fire at a chemical plant in the Buffalo suburb of Tonawanda. In Buffalo, Niagara Mohawk Power Corp. reported power knocked out for about 35,000 customers in the region, but said most service had been restored by afternoon. Thunderstorm wind gusts also caused damage over northeast Pennsylvania. Winds gusted to 52 mph at Erie and }-inch hail fell at Foster Brook and near Coudersport. There was flooding from heavy rain at Bradford and Lobanton, Pa., where 3 inches of rain fell in one hour. Morning thunderstorms also produced golf ball-size hail in and around Sand Springs, Okla. Showers and storms reached from southeastern West Virginia into northwestern Virginia, as well as in central Florida, southwest Georgia, northern Alabama, southern Tennessee, east-central Mississippi, the lower Texas Gulf Coast, and northeast Nevada. The heat was on for the southern Plains, parts of the lower Mississippi Valley, Mississippi and western Tennessee, where afternoon highs were expected to reach 115 degrees through Tuesday afternoon. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 31 degrees at Truckee, Calif. At 3 p.m. EDT, temperatures around the nation ranged from 48 degrees at Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to 104 degrees at Tucson, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Disputes Newsweek Report on Panama Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. soldiers, possibly three, were accidentally killed by their comrades during the Panama invasion, the Pentagon said Monday in disputing a Newsweek report that nine were killed that way. The Defense Department also disputed the magazine's contention that as many as 60 percent of the more than 300 U.S. soldiers wounded in the Dec. 20 invasion were hit by so-called ``friendly fire.'' ``Of the 324 American servicemen wounded in action during Operation Just Cause, 19 were definitely the result of friendly fire,'' said the statement. The statement added that an additional 21 soldiers were injured during intense fighting in the vincinity of the Commandancia, the headquarters of Gen. Manuel Noriega's headquarters, ``by either friendly or enemy fire.'' ``We cannot distinguish which of the 21 were hit by friendly or enemy fire,'' the Pentagon statement said. If all 21 in the uncertain category were hit by friendly fire, the total of 40 wounded that way would be 12 percent of the wounded. The statement said that the two soldiers killed as a result of friendly fire died during the battle at Rio Hato, where U.S. Rangers were dropped as part of Task Force Red southwest of Panama City. ``In the case of one additional serviceman killed in action, it has not been determined if his death was a direct result of friendly or enemy fire. The circumstances of his death are under investigation,'' the statement said. The other 20 servicemen who were killed died as a result of enemy fire, said Pentagon spokeswoman Maj. Kathy Wood. The statement amounted to one of the most detailed reports on the deaths of U.S. servicemen that has been issued in the six months since the invasion. Normally, very detailed ``after action'' reports are compiled in the wake of any military action, but they are usually very closely held. In its statement, the Pentagon said it ``has been investigating every report of injury to U.S. personnel caused by friendly fire during Operation Just Cause.'' Pentagon sources, who spoke on condition of not being identified by name, said confusion over the deaths could have arisen because Noriega's troops used U.S.-supplied bullets and weapons. Given the sensitivity of the issue, the response to the Newsweek report was approved by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, before being released to reporters, the sources said. The Newsweek report, published in the issued dated June 25, quoted unidentified military officials as the source of its information.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Spokesman: Administration Encouraged on Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 5 grafs at end with Senate action on Baltics
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Monday it was heartened by recent conciliatory gestures by the Kremlin toward Lithuania but cautioned that ``there's still much more to be done.'' ``We're encouraged that both sides have taken some steps to try to solve the problem, that a dialogue has taken place,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Legislators in Vilnius, the capital of the rebellious Baltic republic, were to vote this week on a plan to break the deadlock with Moscow. Last week, Lithuanian Prime Minister Vytautas Landsbergis met with Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to discuss the impasse. After the meeting, Moscow restored some natural gas supplies to Lithuania. ``We're encouraged that there's been some lifting of the economic embargo,'' Fitzwater said. ``But it is still in the first-steps category. There's still much more to be done, and we wouldn't want to jump to a conclusion in terms of how it's going to end up yet.'' Meanwhile, 23 senators urged Bush to consider taking steps to normalize economic relations with Lithuania and the other renegade Baltic republics. ``We believe that such actions would enhance our 50-year policy of supporting independence for the people of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia,'' the senators wrote Monday in a letter to Bush. Signers included Sens. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, and Jesse Helms, R-N.C., the ranking GOP member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Earlier in the day, the Senate reiterated its views on the U.S.-Soviet trade agreement that was signed earlier this month during the superpower summit. Senators voted 74-24 for a resolution asking Bush not to approve the pact until the Soviet Union lifts its economic embargo on Lithuania. ``We again urge you not to send the trade agreement to the Congress until these conditions are met,'' the resolution said.

DOC.HEAD: Michigander Wins Citizen Bee
DOC.TEXT: Jofi Joseph of Muskegon, Mich., won the fifth annual Citizen Bee on Monday after correctly outlining the constitutional provision governing letters of marque and reprisal. Joseph, who graduated this month from Muskegon Catholic High School, plans to enroll this fall at Georgetown University in Washington, where he will attend the school of foreign service. He received a $7,000 scholarship as first prize in the contest, sponsored by the Close Up Foundation in cooperation with the Smithsonian Institution's Office of Elementary and Secondary Education. Close Up is a nonprofit organization that provides educational programs on government and citizenship. Second prize, which carries a scholarship of $5,000, went to Derek Baxter, who will be a senior in the fall at W.T. Woodson High School in Fairfax, Va. Gautam Dutta, a graduate of Cistercian Prep in Irving, Texas, who plans to go to Yale, won third prize, with a $3,000 scholarship. Joseph had a final score of 143 points, based on written and oral answers. Baxter had a score of 136 and Dutta of 133. The final question to Joseph, which was good for 12 points, was to define letters of marque and reprisal and say what branch of government the Constitution empowered to grant them. The Constitution empowered Congress to grant such letters, authorizing private ships to attack enemy vessels in wartime. Joseph also answered correctly that Puerto Ricans became American citizens under the Jones Act, passed in 1917 when Woodrow Wilson was president, and that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev visited Minnesota to encourage people to invest in the Soviet Union. He slipped up when asked what states, other than Wyoming and Illinois, you would pass through if you traveled in a straight line from Cheyenne, Wyo., to Chicago. He said Colorado and Iowa. The correct answer is Nebraska and Iowa. Joseph answered correctly that the river you would cross is the Mississippi.

DOC.HEAD: Gunshots Send Golfers Scrambling For Cover
DOC.TEXT: Rifle shots rang out along the back nine of a golf course, sending about 100 golfers scrambling for cover, but police don't think the shooter was after people. ``It appears someone was shooting at targets or birds or squirrels or something and the shots went over into the golf course,'' Camillus Police Sgt. Lloyd Perkins said Monday. ``We do not believe it was a sniper.'' Dave Rustay and his friends were teeing off on the Westvale Golf Club's 16th hole at about 2:30 p.m. Sunday when someone on the 13th green shouted a warning. ``We thought he said, `Nice shot,''' recounted Rustay, 26. ``But he was really saying they were shooting at us. We didn't really know what was going on. That's why it was so frightening.'' An estimated 20 shots were fired. Rustay and his friends took cover, then raced to a nearby pro shop to summon help. The Onondaga Sheriff's Department searched for the shooter by helicopter but found nothing.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Urges More Action Against Windshear Danger
DOC.TEXT: The National Transportation Safety Board said Monday that federal authorities aren't doing enough to protect airliners from dangerous winds during takeoff and landing at major airports. The board, which has no regulatory power, recommended that the Federal Aviation Administration buy additional ground-based equipment to warn planes of sudden changes of wind speed and direction known as windshear. At least eight passenger plane accidents in the last 17 years have been blamed at least in part on wind hazards. The four-member board noted that the FAA has taken several steps to protect airplanes against windshear, including future required installation of detection equipment aboard airliners. ``However, the board believes that additional actions are required by the FAA for maximum protection against this hazard in the national airspace system,'' said a board announcement. Board recommendations were outlined in a 11-page letter to FAA Administrator James Busey. The board called for appointment of an FAA meteorologist at major airports and purchase of sophisticated weather radar systems at all airports determined to be susceptible to low-altitude windshear conditions. The invisible hazard, which occurs under thunderstorms or in connection with weather fronts, is considered most dangerous near the ground at airports where it can affect planes during takeoff or landing. The board also called for interim improvements at airports where installation of windshear detection equipment might take some time to install or where the weather radar systems aren't planned. The board said its recommendations were based on a review of more than 40 safety recommendations it has issued to the FAA over the past 16 years. The safety board, which operates independently from the FAA or the Transportation Department, investigates accidents and regularly makes recommendations for safety improvements in transportation systems. It gave the FAA 90 days to respond.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor, Citizen Education Strategies Against AIDS Announced
DOC.TEXT: With an estimated one million Americans infected with the AIDS virus, the American Medical Association on Monday announced plans to teach the public and front-line physicians about the deadly disease. ``Virtually every physician will see AIDS or HIV disease firsthand within the next 10 years,'' Dr. Roy M. Schwarz, the AMA's top executive for Medical Education, said in opening the second annual American Medical Association HIV conference. ``The AMA's posture is that every (physician) has to be prepared to treat cases,'' he said. Schwarz estimated that five percent of doctors and nurses refuse to treat AIDS patients. ``The ethics of the situation are patently clear. You cannot, according to any ethical code ... refuse to treat anybody solely on the basis of (positive HIV test), lifestyle, or frank HIV disease,'' he said. The two-day AMA onference, combined with a campaign by the Centers for Disease Control, came on the eve of the Sixth International Conference on AIDS in San Francisco, which begins Wednesday. Although ``getting Americans to realize what human immunodeficiency virus is and the risks involved'' is crucial, said Schwarz, the goal of the AMA is to instruct the physician to assume leadership in providing patient counseling, specifically on the HIV test. Schwarz displayed guidelines designed to teach doctors about blood testing and counseling patients whose behavior may put them at risk for the disease. Schwarz said an estimated million Americans are HIV-infected, and that 15 million to 20 million people may be infected globally by 2000. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring. The scientific name for the virus is human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV. The guidelines for physicians are frank. One section discusses the physician's responsibility to learn beforehand whether a patient might commit suicide if a blood test turns out positive. Dr. Gary Noble, CDC deputy director in charge of the HIV program and assistant surgeon general of the U.S. Public Health Service, told plans for a nationwide media blitz to get the AIDS story to every American. Key to the program, dubbed ``Phase 5,'' are public service ads on television, radio and in print. Four of the ads will be in Spanish. ``We have two main goals in this phase. First, to familiarize the public with HIV, since we want people to understand that HIV infection can occur without symptoms and (the patient) can remain relatively well for years...without developing AIDS,'' he said. ``The second goal is to get every American to think about how much danger of HIV infection they may be at because of their own behavior ... having sex with someone who has shared a needle with an infected person,'' he said. Noble went on, ``We would hope that each individual would decide if there is any danger that they have been infected and that urges them to seek counseling and an appropriate evaluation. ... HIV can happen to anyone.''

DOC.HEAD: Satellite Woes Trouble Hurricane Specialists
DOC.TEXT: As hurricane season begins, burned-out light bulbs have forced storm specialists to rely on one, instead of two, high-orbit weather satellites for the fifth time in seven years. Only one high-orbit U.S. weather satellite is watching U.S. coastlines, meaning that this year again, hurricane specialists won't get a full picture of the Atlantic Ocean's hurricane breeding grounds. Efforts to keep two satellites going haven't worked. So the working one, being nudged into hurricane-season position at a mere \ mph to save fuel, will have to get through the 1991 season alone. If this satellite, GOES 7, fails like three predecessors, forecasters lose one of their best tools for monitoring everything from hurricanes threatening the East Coast to typhoons off Hawaii. The problem is the satellites' $1,000 light bulbs, which create the photographic images forecasters use to watch weather systems. Only one satellite has outlived its five-year design life before its light bulbs burned out, and then by just seven months. Two others lasted only three years before their $1,000 light bulbs failed. A fourth satellite was lost in 1986 when the Delta rocket carrying it had to be destroyed in flight. To solve the light bulb problem, GOES 7 also was equipped with light-emitting diodes _ similar to what's used in calculators _ that should be more durable, said Gary Davis, NOAA's chief of satellite operations. The Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite, placed in orbit 22,300 miles above Earth, has a speed matching Earth's rotation, so it appears parked above a particular spot. When two GOES satellites work in tandem, forecasters can see from the coast of Africa out into the Pacific Ocean beyond the Hawaiian Islands. But NOAA has had trouble keeping two working at once. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says the $50 million GOES 7 is the sturdiest of its series. For two years, GOES 7 has bounced back and forth across the sky, spending the hurricane season at 98 degrees longitude, above the Galapagos Islands, and the rest of the year 611 miles to the west, at 108 degrees longitude, where there's a better view of the Pacific Ocean beyond the Hawaiian Islands. GOES 7 should be in hurricane position by Aug. 21. The season runs June 1 to Nov. 30, but historically the worst storms are born in September and October. The satellite's position is a compromise. GOES 7 will not be able to see all the way to the Cape Verde Islands off the coast of Africa, where killer hurricanes tend to form. But if it was moved farther east, it couldn't be used to monitor Pacific Ocean storms. If GOES 7 fails, the National Hurricane Center still will be able to get pictures four times a day from two polar-orbiting weather satellites. And as a storm approaches land, hurricane-hunter airplanes could provide updates. GOES has a tremendous public relations value, Lawrence said. ``All the news programs show the satellite pictures _ it's such an excellent way to get people to respond to the threat,'' he said. Next summer, NOAA plans to launch the first of a new generation of more powerful satellites called GOES Next. But that satellite won't be ready for hurricane duty until 1992. Ground controllers hope they can keep GOES 7's fuel burning slowly enough to keep its lights on until both GOES Next satellites are up and running.

DOC.HEAD: Another Suspected Red Army Terrorist Arrested in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: East German officials on Monday arrested another Red Army Faction suspect, the eighth fugitive of the terrorist organization taken into custody in 12 days. The official news agency ADN reported Silke Maier-Witt, one of 24 remaining top Red Army Faction suspects wanted by West Germany, was arrested Monday afternoon without resistance. Ms. Maier-Witt, 40, is wanted in connection with the kidnap-slaying of West German industry chief Hans-Martin Schleyer in October 1977, and an attempted rocket attack against West Germany's federal prosecutor's office in August 1977. ADN, quoting a statement from the East German Interior Ministry, did not say where in East Germany that the woman's arrest occurred. Interior Minister Peter Michael Diestel, in a statement said he plans to hold a news conference on Ms. Maier-Witt's arrest Tuesday, ADN said in the short report. No one from the West German Federal Prosecutor's office could be immediately reached late Monday for comment. The Red Army Faction has been waging attacks against NATO, U.S. and West German industrial targets since the early 1970s. Among those killed were a U.S. Army officer and leading West German bankers and industrialists. The first of the recent arrests took place June 6, when East German officials announced the apprehension in East Berlin of Sussanne Albrecht. The 39-year-old suspect is also wanted in the Schleyer case and for killing prominent Dresdner bank chief Juergen Ponto in July 1977. A week later, officials arrested Inge Viett, 46, in the East German city of Magdeburg. Ms. Viett has been linked to the murder of prominent West Berlin Judge Guenter von Drenkmann in 1974, and the shooting death of a French policeman in 1981. On June 15, authorities announced the arrest of four more suspected terrorists in the East German cities of Frnkfurt an der Oder and Cottbus. They have been identified as Monika Helbing, 36, Ekkehard von Seckendorff-Gudent, 39, Werner Lotze, 38, and Christine Duemlein, 41. Ms. Helbing and Lotze have also been linked to the Schleyer case. Seckendorff-Gudent, a doctor, who had a permanent visitor's pass to a Hamburg prison, is accused of supporting the gang by providing his pass to other terrorists to visit their jailed comrades. Ms. Duemlein was released shortly after her arrest because the warrant against her, issued in 1980 for being a suspected terrorist group member, expired in 1985. West German officials said the warrant will not be renewed. On June 16, officials arrested Red Army Faction suspect, Sigrid Sternebeck, 40, who is wanted in the shooting death of U.S. Army Spec. 4 Edward Pimental in August 1985. Sternebeck allegedly lured the soldier out of a discotheque near Wiesbaden to steal his identification card. The identification card was used the next day to plant a car bomb at the headquarters building of the U.S. Air Force's Rhine-Main Air Base. Two more Americans were killed in the Aug. 8, 1985, blast and 20 people were injured. West Germany have been infuriated by revelations that some of its top fugitives were sheltered by the now ousted Communists. Both Sternebeck and Albrecht have told investigators they were provided help and new identification by East German secret police, ADN reported. Eduard Lintner, a leading conservative lawmaker in Bonn, has called for former East German leader Erich Honecker and his top lieutenants to be extradited to West Germany to face possible charges of aiding the terrorists. But early Monday, West German Chief Federal Prosecutor, Alexander von Stahl, said in an interview with Deutschlandfunk radio in Cologne that ``until now there are only vague indications'' of official support for West German terrorists during the Honecker era. ``Simply providing the Red Army Faction members with shelter is insufficient for an indictment against the former leaders of the German Democratic Republic for supporting a criminal organization,'' von Stahl said.

DOC.HEAD: Authority Over Non-Indian Employer Upheld
DOC.TEXT: An Indian tribe can enforce its own hiring and promotion laws against a non-Indian employer operating within the reservation, a federal appeals court ruled Monday. Reversing a lower-court decision, the panel of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 3-0 that the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes on the Fort Hall Reservation in southeastern Idaho could regulate employment practices at a phosphorus plant owned by FMC Corp. on private land inside the reservation borders. The tribes said FMC, the largest employer on the reservation, with 600 workers, had violated a 1981 agreement requiring it to hire and promote more Indians. The tribes' suit sought enforcement of their ordinance requiring preferential hiring and promotion of Indians by all employers on the reservation. ``This is an extremely important case to Indian tribes,'' said Melody McCoy, lawyer for the Native American Rights Fund, which filed papers siding with the Shoshone-Bannocks. She said several other cases pending in the court raise the same issue of tribal authority over non-Indian employers. ``Most reservations suffer from severe unemployment and Sho-Ban is no exception,'' McCoy said. ``When there are big employers like FMC, they are trying to say, `You're on our reservation, taking tribal resources and making a profit. How about cutting us some of the pie?''' FMC's lawyer in the case did not return telephone calls. The company could appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court. The tribes, dissatisfied in late 1986 with FMC's performance under the 1981 agreement, sued the company in Tribal Court. FMC's employment record is ``very bleak,'' the tribes' general counsel, Jeanette Wolfley, said Monday. ``They only employ a handful of Indians.'' She said the company also fell far short of the required standards for promotions and contracting with Indian-owned firms. The Tribal Appellate Court ordered FMC to choose qualified Indians for 75 percent of new jobs and all new promotions, give local Indians one-third of all training opportunities, and pay a $100,000 annual fee. FMC went to federal court and won a ruling in April 1988 from U.S. District Judge Marion Callister that it was not governed by the tribal ordinance. But the appeals court disagreed. The court said the phosphorus plant, though on privately owned land within the reservation borders, uses minerals from tribal land under leases with the Indians and is subject to tribal taxation. ``FMC actively engaged in commerce with the tribes and so has subjected itself to the civil jurisdiction of the tribes,'' said the opinion by Judge Jerome Farris. The court did not order immediate enforcement of the tribal hiring plan, however. Instead, the case was returned to the Tribal Appellate Court to consider any claims by FMC that its rights would be violated by the application of the tribal ordinance.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Lets Ruling Against Boston University Stand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf, `Silber opposed ...' with comment from Silber, picks up 7th graf pvs, `Silber is...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday let stand a decision that granted a lifetime professorship to a woman whose sexual bias lawsuit alleged that Boston University President John Silber harbored sexist attitudes. The court, without comment, rejected arguments that the lower court decision interfered with the school's academic freedom. The decision required the university to grant tenure to Julia Prewitt Brown. ``I am glad that the Supreme Court has affirmed the longstanding authority of college faculties to judge scholarship and teaching, an authority that has been undermined of late by the impositions of college administrators,'' Ms. Brown said in a statement released by her attorney. Ms. Brown, who now teaches at Providence College, intends to return to Boston University, said Dahlia Rudavsky, her lawyer. ``She wants to go back. Now that we're at a logical place between semesters, she'll be back soon.'' Ms. Brown had been teaching at Boston for six years when she became eligible for tenure in 1979. An English department committee voted 22-0 that she receive tenure, and its recommendation was supported 9-2 by a university committee. Silber opposed tenure and recommended instead that she remain on probation for three more years. Silber relied in part on a report by the university provost questioning Ms. Brown's scholarly credentials. Silber on Monday said the issue was settled and he wished Ms. Brown ``all the best.'' He also defended himself against accusations that he was biased against women, saying that 25 percent of the full-time faculty at Boston University are women and that 28 percent of the women have tenure, figures that compare favorably with many other universities. Silber is on leave from the university to run for governor of Massachusetts as a Democrat. His campaign spokeswoman, Michal Regunberg, said she was not familiar with the Supreme Court action and could not comment. Ms. Brown had published a book of criticism on Jane Austen's novels that generally was well reviewed by other scholars. But the provost said the university should await further evidence of Ms. Brown's abilities before awarding tenure. After Ms. Brown rejected the offer of three more years on probation, the university board of trustees denied her tenure. The university argued that evidence of Silber's alleged sexism should not have been presented to a federal jury that awarded Ms. Brown $200,000. A judge added $15,000 to compensate her for emotional distress, and ordered the university to reinstate her with lifetime tenure. As evidence of Silber's alleged sexism, Ms. Brown introduced several statements made by Silber. One included a remark he made describing the English department as ``a damn matriarchy'' at a time when the department was headed by a woman and included six female and 20 male faculty members. Silber also had told another woman on the faculty that she should not be worried about job security since ``your husband is a parachute,'' an apparent reference to the fact her husband was employed. The jury also heard a portion of an old speech by Silber in which he lamented the lack of parental supervision in families in which both husbands and wives work outside the home. The 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in ruling last year for Ms. Brown, refused to order a new trial in which the Silber remarks would be excluded. The appeals court also rejected the university's arguments that awarding Ms. Brown a lifetime job interfered with its academic freedom. ``Academic freedom does not include the freedom to discriminate against tenure candidates on the basis of sex or other impermissible grounds,'' the appeals court said. ``Awarding (Ms. Brown) tenure is the only way to provide her the most complete relief possible.''

DOC.HEAD: West German Prosecutor: No Charges Against Honecker for Now
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's chief prosecutor said Monday there is insufficient evidence for bringing criminal charges against former East German leader Erich Honecker, despite claims his regime harbored leftist terrorists. However, he indicated that charges could be brought in the future. West Germans have been infuriated by revelations that some of their most wanted fugitives were once sheltered by the East German Communists who were ousted in last year's democratic revolution. Those disclosures came to light with the recent capture of seven suspected members of the Red Army Faction terrorist group. Eduard Lintner, a member Helmut Kohl's governing coalition in West Germany, has called for Honecker's extradition to face terrorist-related charges in West Germany. This weekend, chief West German prosecutor Alexander von Stahl was quoted by a newspaper as saying he was investigating whether there was evidence to bring charges against Honecker and his ousted deputies. However, in a radio interview Monday, von Stahl said that ``until now there are only vague indications'' of official support for West German terrorists during the Honecker era. Von Stahl told Deutschlandfunk Radio of Cologne that he was ruling out for the time being bringing charges against Honecker, his security chief Erich Mielke and legendary former spy chief Markus Wolf. The ex-spy has denied any contacts with Red Army Faction terrorists. ``Simply providing the Red Army Faction members with shelter is insufficient for an indictment against the former leaders of the German Democratic Republic for supporting a criminal organization,'' von Stahl said. ``A criminal probe against Honecker, Mielke and their accomplices could only be started if it can be proved they knowingly or intentionally provided Red Army Faction members with active help,'' von Stahl said. Honecker, Mielke and other members his regime are already targets of probes by East German prosecutors investigating charges of corruption. It is uncertain whether any trials will result, however.

DOC.HEAD: Government Inquiry in Zaire Confirms Massacre of Students
DOC.TEXT: Local authorities approved a nighttime raid by masked commandos who infiltrated a southern university and reportedly massacred up to 150 students, a parliamentary panel said Monday. The panel report said the commandos entered Lubumubashi University, in that city near the Zambian border, the night of May 11 after power was cut off. Earlier news reports said the attackers slit the students' throats with knives and bayonets. Monday's parliament report said the attack was ``premeditated and meticulously prepared.'' The report said three student informers, all from President Mobutu Sese Seko's home province of Equateur, persuaded local officials to launch the attack in revenge because the informers had been discovered by students and beaten. Students have been at the vanguard of opposition to one-party rule in this central African country. Although Mobutu said this year he will allow other parties, he remains in complete control of the government. The governor of Shaba Province, Koyagialo Ngbase, ordered the university campus surrounded by the military to prevent students from escaping during the attack, the report said. Mobutu appoints all governors, and Ngbase is also from Mobutu's home province. The governor has been transferred to another province but remains free. The report by members of parliament said the exact number of deaths is unknown but may be as high as 150. The parliamentarians criticized the local military commander, saying he made no effort to stop the recruitment of a commando unit for the attack. The report also says he refused to help students when they were attacked. Members of the committee that wrote the report, speaking during a parliamentary debate, vowed those responsible will be brought to justice. Until now, the only people detained are six accused of spreading rumors about the attack. The government ordered the report. In the past, the parliament has backed the decisions of Mobutu, who has ruled since 1965. Angry about the massacres, Belgium, the former colony power, has frozen all new aid to Zaire. The U.S. State Department said in its annual human rights report that security organizations in Zaire regularly harass, detain and brutalize citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Body of Widow of West German IRA Victim Found
DOC.TEXT: The body of the wife of a West German industrialist who died in a 1973 IRA kidnapping has washed up on a beach south of the Irish capital, police said Monday. Authorities said there were no indications of foul play. The Irish Times said the fully clothed body of Ingeborg Niedermayer was found on a beach at Greystones, 18 miles south of Dublin, on Friday afternoon. The newspaper said Mrs. Niedermayer, 62, had booked into a hotel at nearby Bray last week after arriving on a visit from West Germany. A police spokesman confirmed the body was that of Mrs. Niedermayer. In December 1973, Thomas Niedermayer, then 45, was kidnapped from his home in Belfast, Northern Ireland. Niedermayer was the honorary West German consul in Belfast and head of the Grundig electronic company's plant in the British province. Despite repeated pleas from his family, there was no word of his fate until 1980, when his body was found buried in a garbage dump near his home. A member of the Irish Republican Army, John Bradley, confessed to taking part in the kidnapping. Police accepted Bradley's testimony that Niedermayer died of a heart attack during a struggle soon after being seized. Bradley is serving a 20-year jail term for manslaughter. The IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the province with the Catholic Republic of Ireland. In London, the Daily Telegraph said Mrs. Niedermayer apparently walked into the sea. It didn't say whether she died from an accident or suicide.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk, Homeland Leaders Agree on Need for New Constitution
With AM-Mandela
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk and the leaders of six black tribal homelands agreed Monday that talks on ending apartheid should begin as soon as possible. South African newspapers said de Klerk met the homeland leaders in a bid to find allies prior to opening formal constitutional negotiations with black opposition groups such as the African National Congress. De Klerk and the homeland leaders met at the president's office in Cape Town to discuss prospects for negotiations on the new constitution that will include the country's 28 million black majority. All parties at the meeting agreed that ``negotiations for a new constitution should be the highest priority and should start as soon as possible,'' according to a statement by de Klerk's office. De Klerk says he wants to end racial discrimination and bring blacks into the national government. But he opposes the one-man, one-vote, majority-rule system that black leaders such as ANC leader Nelson Mandela have been demanding, saying it will replace white domination with black domination. He envisions a mechanism that will give the 5 million whites veto power on major policy decisions. De Klerk arranged a meeting with homeland leaders earlier this year, but most canceled at the last moment, reportedly under pressure from the ANC. South Africa has 10 black homelands. None is recognized abroad. The ANC considers the homelands part of the country's apartheid system of racial segregation. De Klerk met Monday with the leaders of the six ``self-governing'' territories. The leaders of the four homelands the South African government considers independent were not present. The president has made clear that homeland leaders would be welcome to participate in negotiations on a new constitution. Several homeland leaders, such as KwaZulu Chief Minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi, are relatively conservative and considered potential government allies. In other developments Monday: _ The leader of the ANC's military wing, Chris Hani, returned to South Africa from the group's exile headquarters in Zambia. Most of the ANC leadership now is inside South Africa for the first time since the group was banned in 1960, forcing leaders to go underground or into exile. De Klerk legalized the ANC in February. _ A black man was killed when a grenade he was carrying exploded prematurely, said police in the black homeland of Bophuthatswana. The man and two accomplices were confronted by police at a railway station when the grenade went off, police said. A second suspect killed himself with a gun and a third suspect escaped, police said. Mandela is currently in Canada on a 14-nation tour that will take him on Wednesday to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Funerals Held for Flood Victims; Death Toll Increases to 21
LaserPhotos XBLR4 and XBLR5
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with death toll rising to 22, 13 still missing; CORRECTS spelling of Isaiah; quotes local weather service official on why flood warning not issued; DELETES 12th graf, `In Ohio, the body ..., to conform; picks up 10h graf pvs: `On Monday ...; edits to tighten
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Worst Weather
DOC.TEXT: Townspeople on Monday began burying victims of flash floods that ravaged a rural area near this Appalachian village, and the death toll rose to 22. Searchers looking for 14 people still listed as missing turned their attention to the debris-clogged Ohio River and found the body of a 13-year-old girl who was swept away by flood waters while playing at a friend's house. The body of Kerri Polivka, 13, was found in the river about 3 miles below the mouth of Wegee Creek. Kerri was at the home of a friend, 9-year-old Amber Colvin, when the storm struck the one-story house Thursday. The two girls jumped into a bathtub for safety, but it was washed into Wegee Creek. Flood waters carried Amber about seven miles into the Ohio River, but she survived by clinging to logs for 7{ hours before reaching shore. Thirteen people still were listed as missing Monday night. The first funeral for a flood victim was held in a funeral home that was used as a temporary morgue. About 100 people crowded into three rooms to mourn the death of Roger DeNoon Sr., 51. ``It rained and it thundered this morning. And they say when it rains on the morning of the funeral, the dead go to heaven,'' said DeNoon's daughter, Kimberly. ``That was his way of saying goodbye, because he didn't get a chance to say goodbye.'' ``I'm not sure any of us can prepare for this type of a tragedy,'' said Capt. Tim Muir, a Salvation Army chaplain who delivered the eulogy. ``The thing we have to look at is found in Isaiah 38:1 _ `Thus saith the Lord: ``Set thy house in order, for thou shalt die and not live.''' DeNoon's body was carried out of the Bauknecht Funeral Home in a casket draped with an American flag. He was to be buried in Cambridge, about 50 miles west of Shadyside. Funerals also were held for John and Edna Andrecht of Shadyside and for 6-year-old Timmy Gatten in Jacobsburg. The Ohio flash flood Thursday night was the most serious in a series of severe storms that have hit parts of the Midwest and East. The National Weather Service meteorologist in charge of the station responsible for Belmont County said Monday that the storm developed so rapidly a flood warning would not have helped. ``We're dealing with God Almighty here, nature itself. Sometimes nature just isn't predictable,'' Ed Heath said at a news conference in Shadyside. But the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which oversees the weather service, planned to investigate why a flood warning _ which alerts that flooding has occurred or is imminent _ was not issued. On Monday, a fast-moving line of thunderstorms whipped across large portions of New York state, leaving fires, blackouts and homes crushed by trees. In Iowa, a second day of sunshine allowed floodwaters to recede. At least three deaths were blamed on the storm. Fifteen more Iowa counties were declared disaster areas, bringing the total to 22. Divers on Monday began probing rubble on the bottom of the river near the mouths of the Wegee and Pipe creeks as well as floating debris that accumulated at the Hannibal, Ohio, lock and dam, about 25 miles south of Shadyside. Automobiles had been pushed down the creek valleys and into the river by a 25-foot-high wall of water that surged from the highlands, wiping out homes, bridges, trees and utility poles, officials said. Floating debris such as tree limbs, furniture, natural gas tanks and toys began to clog the locks and dam, and the Army Corps of Engineers was asked to help remove it, said Capt. Jim Boling of the Ohio National Guard. Federal officials were trying to assess whether river barge traffic was impeded by the debris, he said. At least 18 divers from West Virginia arrived Monday to help Ohio divers search for additional bodies. Nine horseback officers were brought in from Coshocton County in east-central Ohio in the search for the first time, according to Belmont County Sheriff Tom McCort. The horses allow officers search more of the rugged terrain more quickly, he said. Federal Emergency Management Agency officials said a preliminary estimate showed that 700 homes in Belmont and neighboring Jefferson and Harrison counties were destroyed or damaged from the deluge, 5{ inches of rain within 3{ hours. People whose homes and belongings were swept away say they will have to begin putting their lives back together largely without the benefit of insurance. Few residents in this eastern Ohio coal-mining and steel-making area along the Wegee and Pipe creeks felt the need to carry flood insurance, and homeowners' insurance will not cover damage, residents and local insurers said. ``We didn't think we needed to have flood insurance. For what? That creek never flooded. Then this. Everybody just got wiped out,'' said Julia Kulazenka, 62.
