DOC.HEAD: 21-Year-old Charged With Murder of Seven Arabs That Set Off Riots
DOC.TEXT: A 21-year-old Israeli on Monday was charged with the murder of seven Palestinians in an attack that set off unrest in which 20 other people died. A five-man psychiatric panel rejected a claim that the suspect, Ami Popper, was unfit to stand trial, officials said. Prosecutor Nurit Smith said Popper would face a mandatory life sentence if convicted by a Tel Aviv court of slaying the seven Arab laborers and wounding 10. In the May 20 killings, a gunman ordered about 50 Palestinians to sit in rows as they waited for day jobs in the Tel Aviv suburb of Rishon Letzion. He then fired an assault rifle on the unarmed laborers. The attack sparked riots in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in which 18 Palestinians were killed, most by army gunfire. Two Israelis also died in what authorities said were revenge attacks. Authorities said at the time that Popper, who was discharged early from the Israeli army for disciplinary problems, was deranged and upset by an uphappy love affair. His lawyer, David Ofek, claimed Popper tried to hang himself in jail.

DOC.HEAD: Cease-fire Collapses, 100s Reportedly Killed in Sri Lanka Battles
DOC.TEXT: Tamil guerrillas withdrew into the jungles and pledged to continue their violent civil war after a 2-day-old cease-fire broke down Monday. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne told Parliament that security forces killed 600 fighters of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in three days of battles. He gave no information on government casualties. An additional 378 people, including 137 disarmed policemen massacred by the Tigers, are reported to have been killed since June 11, when the rebels ended a 13-month-old truce. The death toll was compiled from reports by witnesses, military officials and Tiger sources. Tamil rebels took up arms against the Sinhalese-dominated government in 1983 in a quest for a separate homeland for the country's Tamil minority. More than 11,000 people have died in the insurrection. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, have long accused the Sinhalese majority of discriminating against them. The cease-fire, which started at sundown Saturday, had been marred by minor attacks over the weekend. By midday Monday, both sides reported exchanges of fire along the east coast and in the north. A spokesman for the Tamil Tigers, contacted by telephone in the eastern town of Batticaloa, said ``we continue our retreat into the jungles. We will fight from there.'' Batticaloa, 136 miles from Colombo on the east coast, and Jaffna, 186 miles northeast of the capital, have been the major flashpoints in the fighting. A defense ministry statement said ``since the cease-fire has been violated by the LTTE (Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam), security forces are taking all action to restore law and order in the affected areas.'' The statement added that military area commanders have been appointed to ``act resolutely against terrorism.'' On Monday morning, Tiger fighters in Batticaloa set fire to a police station they captured a week ago and streamed out of town toward the jungle in at least 100 jeeps, vans and small trucks, a local journalist said. In reaction, Wijeratne said ``unless they stop this nonsense, we won't talk to them, we will push them all into the Indian Ocean.'' Justice Minister Shahul Hameed, who negotiated the truce on Saturday, told parliament his efforts to bring peace have failed. ``My genuine efforts to bring about an end to this carnage have failed. I appeal to everybody to help restore sanity in this country,'' Hameed said. Since the fighting started, the Tigers have taken over about 20 police stations. At least 850 policemen, ordered by their government not to return fire, surrendered to the Tigers last week. The fate of most of them is unknown but a lone policeman who escaped and military sources said at least 137 of the captive policemen were killed by the militants hours after they surrendered.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Dead, Five Wounded in Gunman's Rampage at Auto Loan Company
LaserPhotos; LaserGraphic
With AM-Massacre-List
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to reflect that Sunday shootings may not have been random, moves up details of earlier arrests, shows how Pough could legally own weapons despite felony plea, other details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A gunman ``loaded for war'' Monday stalked through an auto loan company that had repossessed his car, firing at customers, shooting under desks at hiding employees and leaving eight dead before killing himself. Five others victims were listed in critical but stable condition after the late morning shootings by semiautomatic gunfire at the General Motors Acceptance Corp. office south of downtown. The gunman also killed two people on the streets near his Jacksonville home Sunday, authorities said. Richard Langille, a GMAC employee, said office workers dived under desks when the first of about 50 shots rang out in Monday's attack. ``And then we realized the guy was pointing his gun underneath people's desks and killing them one by one,'' said Langille. ``I just saw the bottom of the carpet and just prayed.'' Some of the wounded were shot seven or eight times each, hospital spokesmen said. ``The suspect apparently went in the front door and shot a couple of customers,'' said Sheriff James McMillan. ``Then he went right through the office indiscriminately shooting employees, then turned the weapon on himself.'' The gunman, James Edward Pough, 42, a day laborer from Jacksonville, had recently had a vehicle repossessed by GMAC, the sheriff said. McMillan said it was not known if that was the sole motive. The company said the car was a 1988 Pontiac Grand Am repossessed in January. Pough began firing almost as soon as he walked through the door, McMillan said. After shooting two customers, one fatally, he methodically went from desk to desk firing his rifle, witnesses said. The gunman used a .30-caliber, clip-fed semiautomatic rifle for most of the shooting, but also had a .38-caliber revolver, authorities said. Police found several rifle clips, some empty and some full, inside the office. ``There's numerous magazines, plus numerous rounds in his pockets,'' said Deputy Ken Bozeman. ``He was loaded for war.'' A 9mm semiautomatic pistol was found in Pough's car parked outside of the building, McMillan said. He also had a .357-caliber Magnum registered to his name, but no information was given on that weapon's location. The .38-caliber revolver used in the shootings was registered June 4, 1979, McMillan said. Agents from the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms were checking whether the rifle was registered. Pough was arrested in 1971 in Duval County on a charge of homicide, but was never convicted. In July 1971, he was given five years probation on a charge of aggravated assault, according to Florida Department of Corrections records. The 1971 court records show that adjudication would be withheld after his probation period, meaning that Pough would not have a record in that case if he obeyed the terms of probation. That would mean he could legally possess a gun. The sheriff said that Pough also was arrested in 1968 ``for dangerously displaying a weapon.'' McMillan said Pough has also been ``positively identified'' by witnesses as the killer of a man and woman in separate shootings early Sunday. Louis Carl Bacon, 39, and Doretta Drake, 30, were walking through a northwest section of Jacksonville, near where Pough lived, and were killed with the same .30-caliber rifle used in the Monday massacre, McMillan said. McMillan said at least one of the Sunday shootings stemmed from arguments over ``services of a prostitute.'' He did not elaborate. Records show that Pough was married, but neighbors told reporters they had not seen his wife for some time. At the GMAC, five employees, a customer and the gunman died at the scene at the Baymeadows office complex, said John Andrews, a company spokesman in Detroit. Two other employees died at hospitals. The wounded were airlifted or taken by ambulance to University Hospital, Baptist Medical Center and St. Luke's Hospital, where they were in critical but stable condition. Jay Edelberg, of Baptist Medical, said the three wounded brought there had been shot repeatedly. One man had gunshot wounds on both sides of his chest and in his abdomen, Edelberg said. A woman was shot eight times, including both sides of her chest and her abdomen. ``The third one, who is the most stable, probably had the worst injuries because she got hit about seven times, hitting her arms, her legs, shattering bones and severing nerves and arteries,'' the Baptist spokesman said. A special crisis team was at the shooting scene and police set up a counseling center in a building next door. Investigators were trying to interview witnesses but McMillan said ``the are all in a state of shock, understandably.'' Pough was arrested in 1971 in Duval County on a charge of homicide, but was never convicted. In July 1971, he was given probation on a charge of aggravated assault, according to Florida Department of Corrections records. In addition to Pough, the dead were identified as Drew Woods, Denise Highfill, Janice David, Sharon Louise Hall, Barbara Duckwall Holland, Julia White Burgess, Lee Simonton, and Cynthia Perry. The wounded were Ron Ecchevaria, Jewel Belote, Nancy Dill, Phyllis Griggs and David Hendrix. The death total matched the worst single-day episode in Florida, a 1982 massacre at a Miami machine shop where nine died and three were wounded.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador Criticizes New York City for Honor to IRA Convict
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Ambassador to Britain Henry Catto wrote to the mayor of New York on Monday to express shock that the city named a street corner after an IRA member convicted of killing a British soldier. Mayor David Dinkins approved the honor Friday for Joseph Doherty, who was convicted in the 1980 killing of a British soldier in Belfast, Northern Ireland. The proposal to name the corner after Doherty was championed by his supporters, some of whom are politically influential in New York. When Dinkins signed the bill, he pointed out that Doherty has not been charged with any crime in the United States. ``Mr. Doherty is no hero,'' Catto said in a letter to Dinkins released to the news media. ``The IRA is a gang of murderers, which deserves New York City's condemnation _ not its commemoration.'' ``Terrorism is contemptible, regardless of any claimed justification,'' Catto wrote. ``The IRA is a terrorist organization whose latest victims have included women, infants and tourists.'' The outlawed organization, in its latest offensive, has been aiming mainly at British targets outside Northern Ireland. Seven people have been killed in those attacks the past few weeks. The predominantly Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the 60 percent Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Irish Republic. About 900 members of the British security forces have been killed in IRA attacks since sectarian and political fighting erupted in Northern Ireland in 1969. Several hundred civilians have also died in IRA attacks over the same period. Doherty escaped from prison in 1983 and fled to the United States, where he has spent seven years behind bars awaiting an appeal against extradition. In New York, a spokeswoman for Dinkins' office said the bill proposing the renaming of the street corner after Doherty was put forward by two city council members and backed by 13 others. ``As part of the process, we ask people to speak in favor and against a bill,'' she said. ``Nobody spoke against this one.'' About 1,500 of Doherty's supporters rallied in Manhattan on Saturday to demand his freedom. The demonstrators marched past Park Row and Pearl streets, where a green sign now marks ``Joe Doherty Corner.'' The Metropolitan Correction Center, at the corner, is where Doherty is held.

DOC.HEAD: About 1,500 Evacuated After Plant Releases Vapor Cloud
DOC.TEXT: A cloud of irritating vapor escaped from a chemical plant early Monday, forcing the six-hour evacuation of about 1,500 people and sending 29 to a hospital for treatment. No one was seriously hurt. Authorities sounded sirens and knocked on doors in three small towns and in part of this western Missouri city to alert people to the emergency at the Alcolac Inc. chemical plant, at about 2 a.m. At about 8 a.m., officials determined the leak from a 10,000-gallon tank of allyl methacrylate no longer posed health risks and allowed residents to return home. The chemical is used in coatings for electronic printed circuit boards. In vapor form it can irritate the skin, nose, throat and lungs, officials said. ``It's got a very low odor threshold, so you'd smell it a lot sooner than it would have any health effects,'' said Richard Faulkner, plant manager at Alcolac, which makes soap, cleaning materials and specialty chemicals. Fire Chief Mike Ditzfeld said the vapor release was caused by a chemical reaction in a storage tank.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Pay Tribute to Leader on Anniversary of Anti-Nazi Appeal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with show on the Seine, CORRECT spelling of first name of Philippe De Gaulle, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAR4
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of former resistance fighters joined political and church leaders Monday at a tribute to Charles De Gaulle on the 50th anniversary of his historic radio appeal for armed struggle against the Nazis. Notre Dame Cathedral was filled with an audience that included Premier Michel Rocard, Paris Mayor Jacques Chirac and British Ambassador Sir Ewen Fergusson. De Gaulle's son, Philippe, also was there. Roman Catholic Cardinal Jean-Marie Lustiger of Paris praised De Gaulle's crucial role in the struggle ``for the dignity of all men aganst inhuman and totalitarian ambition.'' Later, many dignitaries and resistance veterans looked on as President Francois Mitterrand unveiled a plaque at the Arc de Triomphe inscribed with the text of De Gaulle's appeal. Church bells throughout France chimed to mark the occasion. Thousands of tourists and Parisians flocked Monday to the Place de la Concorde, where a 115-foot-high replica of a 1940s radio re-broadcast the June 18 call from London and other well-known De Gaulle speeches. Few of De Gaulle's countrymen actually heard his dramatic appeal, in a voice edged with tension: ``Has the last word been said? Must we abandon all hope? Is our defeat final? No! ... France is not alone ... the flame of the resistance must not and shall not die.'' Many of those who did manage to tune in the BBC to hear it knew little about the general claiming to represent France. Instead, they preferred the grandfatherly reassurances of Philippe Petain, a World War I field marshal, who urged surrender to the Germans. Petain became the head of the collaborationist Vichy regime. De Gaulle's fervent, four-minute speech helped change the course of French history. The resistance movement played a critical role in the Allied victory. After the war, De Gaulle founded a political party and served as president from 1959 to 1969. He died a year later. Daylong celebrations of De Gaulle's broadcast culminated Monday night with a sound and light extravaganza on the Seine River. More than 100,000 spectators crowded onto river banks and bridges to watch as scores of barges floated down the Seine carrying torches, flags and hundreds of performers in period costume reenacting the German invasion of France, De Gaulle's flight to London, D-Day and the liberation. The show included simulations of the bombings raids that terrified civilians when France fell. At that time, three-fifths of the population took to the roads in cars, wagons, bicycles and even wheelbarrows to escape the German onslaught. The show, which also celebrates the centenary of De Gaulle's birth, cost $5.7 million, raised from private sources by De Gaulle Centenary Association. Early Monday, vandals demaged and defaced De Gaulle memorials in three communities on the northern outskirts of Paris, police said. No arrests were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Three Found Guilty Of Making Weapons For IRA
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury on Monday convicted two men and a woman of conspiring to supply the Irish Republican Army with sophisticated anti-helicopter missiles and other weapons. U.S. District Judge David A. Mazzone scheduled an Aug. 20 sentencing for Richard C. Johnson, 41, of Nashua, N.H.; Martin Quigley, 27, of Dundalk, Ireland, and Christina L. Reid, 25, a computer technician from Sunnyvale, Calif. The trio was convicted on a range of charges including conspiracy to violate the federal Arms Export Act and to injure or destroy property belonging to the United Kingdom; possessing property to aid foreign insurgents; and aiding an insurgent group in violation of U.S. laws, said Mazzone's clerk, Deborah Whitney. A fourth defendant, Gerald Hoy, of Easton, Pa., pleaded guilty last week. A fifth, Peter E. MaGuire, is a fugitive believed to be in Ireland. Johnson faces a maximum sentence of 28 years, Quigley 18 years, and Reid and Hoy 8 years apiece. The trial, which began May 1, featured testimony by Irish nationalist Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, a former member of the British Parliament. Prosecutors introduced secretly taped conversations in which the defendants allegedly discussed developing a system to shoot down low-flying helicopters. The FBI began watching Johnson in 1983, when the radar specialist bought detonator switches. ``I just got some diodes and I'm going to start experimenting ... and see what kind of range I can get out of them,'' Johnson told Quigley as they sat in a McDonald's parking lot, according to the government. FBI agents arrested the group in July after Johnson, an engineer with top-secret security clearance at the Mitre Corp., surprised federal agents placing a bug in his car as it was parked in the Bedford company's lot. Johnson allegedly used his parents' basement on Cape Cod as an experimental laboratory in which he made explosive fuses for anti-helicopter missiles. Defense attorneys dismissed such claims and claimed their clients merely shared an interest in high-technology electronics. Quigley's lawyer Richard Bachman told the jurors the case was like ``16 of you getting together and building a nuclear submarine in somebody's cellar.'' McAliskey, who appeared in court Wednesday as the last defense witness, testified the IRA could not be considered an insurgent group, because it seeks to overthrow a government imposed by force, not by democratic vote.

DOC.HEAD: Doe Lifts Ban on Opposition Parties, Declares Amnesty
DOC.TEXT: President Samuel Doe, in a bid to bring anti-government rebels into the political system, lifted a ban on opposition parties Monday and declared an amnesty for all his regime's opponents. Doe said he hoped rebel forces, who have been observing an informal cease-fire with government soldiers, would accept the amnesty and form a political party. There was no immediate response from rebels who have waged a war since late December to topple Doe. But rebel leader Charles Taylor refused similar offers from Doe earlier this month. Opposition parties say Doe, with his back to the wall and an army too weak to defeat the rebels, is offering too little, too late. The president said Monday he was granting a general and unconditional amnesty to all members of the rebel's National Patriotic Front, as well as all others living at home and abroad who have been implicated in anti-government activities since 1980. A statement from Doe's executive mansion said he was lifting bans on the Liberian Unification Party and the Liberian People's Party in ``a further move to heal ... wounds, restore peace and ensure the full participation of all Liberians in the political process.'' The move was ``a further demonstration of the seriousness government attaches to the ongoing peace process,'' it said. Rebels and government troops confronting each other near a U.S.-managed Firestone rubber plantation 35 miles from Monrovia have held off fighting since peace talks opens a week ago in Freetown, Sierra Leone. The two sides adjourned talks Saturday for a week after they were able to agree only to exercise restraint in the fighting. The insurgency began with a rebel invasion from the neighboring West African nation of Ivory Coast and has since escalated into a tribal conflict. Both groups have murdered thousands of civilians in attacks on suspected supporters of the other side. Rebels accuse Doe of corruption and rights abuses. They say he should resign. Internal and external government opponents back the rebel call. The Liberian leader announced two weeks ago he would not stand for re-election. But he has refused to resign immediately, saying it would leave a dangerous power vacuum in this West African country during the conflict. Doe took power in a violent 1980 coup that ousted descendants of the freed American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847. They historically monopolized power and discriminated against indigenous Liberians in this country of 2.5 million residents. It was not clear whether Doe's amnesty includes hundreds of government soldiers from the Gio and Mano tribes detained in Monrovia for more than a week. The government has refused to comment on reports that some of them have been killed. Most rebels come from the two tribes.

DOC.HEAD: California Biker Launches Last Leg of Trip Across Great Wall
LaserPhoto BEJ1
DOC.TEXT: A California man who has become the first person to bicycle any substantial distance along the Great Wall set out Monday for the final leg of his 1,255-mile journey. Kevin Foster, 30, has already peddled 1,065 miles and said he's having ``the best time I ever had.'' Foster left Monday from Mutianyu, northeast of Beijing, for the final 190 miles of his adventure. Mutianyu, about 42 miles from the capital, is marked by steep mountains and rugged terrain. Foster said he plans to reach the eastern end of the Great Wall, which China's emperors originally built more than 2,000 years ago to keep out foreigners, at Shanhaiguan Pass on the Bohai Sea, by about June 27. It took Foster, a part-time actor from Ojai, Calif., years of effort to win Chinese government approval for his trip, which began May 11 at the wall's westernmost pass, Jiayuguan, about 950 miles from Beijing. The project bogged down for more than a week when the jeep that was to accompany him failed to show up and he was forced to fly back to the capital. He started again on May 28 and cycled until June 8, when he had to travel by jeep and train to Beijing to avoid passing through a closed military area. Foster said of the 1,065 miles he's ridden in 19 days, three-fourths of that has been on top of the wall. In some places the wall disintegrated into rubble or disappeared altogether, and he bicycled in its traces. He has been accompanied by a driver and jeep carrying supplies and two young Chinese staffers from his host organization, the Institute of Geography, who have taken turns cyling with him. The group spent some nights in small towns that hundreds of years ago housed soldiers guarding the frontier. Other nights they slept on the wall, sometimes finding families living in the towers of the wall. He said the best part was watching the sun set on the Gobi Desert after a day's cycling. ``The sand, the stars, the cool breeze on a tower that's over 1,000 years old _ that's what it's all about.''

DOC.HEAD: Multi-Million Dollar Pollution Suit Filed Against Eight California Corporations
DOC.TEXT: State and federal officials filed a lawsuit Monday against eight firms that allegedly dumped cancer-causing DDT and PCB along the Southern California coast since the 1950s. The unprecedented suit, filed in U.S. District Court, is an attempt to enforce federal provisions requiring polluting companies to restore damaged marine environments, State Controller Gray Davis said. Damages are estimated to range from $50 to $100 million, said Michael R. Valentine, an attorney for the state Lands Commission. ``Cease and desist orders are no longer enough. Mere cleanup will no longer be enough. Polluters must now restore the marine life and habitat they have contaminated,'' Davis said at a news conference in his Los Angeles office. State and federal governments agencies claim the toxic dumping and discharges have caused serious damage to reproductive health of the bald eagle, peregrine falcon and sea lion. Recreational and commercial fisheries have also been harmed, the suit claims. ``In the past, the state recovered funds for cleanup of ocean dumping but there's never been an attempt to collect money to restore the marine habitat,'' Valentine said. The targets of the lawsuit were Montrose Chemical Corp., Atkemix 37 Inc., Stauffer Management Co., ICI American Holdings, Inc., Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., Westinghouse Electric Corp., Potlatch Corp. and Simpson Paper Co. ``I have no knowledge on this suit,'' said Maureen Frisch, a spokeswoman at Simpson's headquarters in San Francisco. Unidentified officials at Potlatch in Pomona referred calls to their San Francisco headquarters where no one was available in a call made after business hours. Officials for the other firms named in the suit could not be reached in calls made to the East Coast after business hours. The suit was filed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, a federal agency that oversees research services that monitor the nation's atmosphere and seas. The suit seeks restoration of offshore environments along an approximately 20-mile stretch of coast from the northern tip Santa Monica Bay south to Palos Verdes. The action alleges the companies discharged DDT, polychlorinated biphenyls and other toxic chemicals into the Southern California coastal marine environment during the last 40 years. The insecticide DDT and the PCBs, used in electrical transformers, are associated with skin diseases and genetic abnormalities, including diminished reproduction capacity. The NOAA is joined by the state Lands Commission, Department of Fish and Game and the Department of Parks and Recreation. The complaint cites the companies for natural resource damages under a provision in the 1980 Superfund law. Under this law, the government must first conduct a study to assess the full extent of environmental damage before they can present their case in court. ``There are regulations set up by the NOAA to come up with these dollar figures. We have set up a combined agency task force to assess those damages,'' Valentine said. Under the Reagan administration, the Superfund law was restricted to ``human health concerns'' and officials were barred from invoking it in resource-damage cases. The Bush administration has restored $2.5 million cut from the budget during the Reagan administration to pursue litigation that would force polluters to restore land and wildlife. ``We all pay when the environment is damaged. We should all be likewise concerned in trying to restore the national marine habitat,'' Davis said.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Slayer Also Killed 2 Others Sunday; Neighbors Say He Was `Nice'
With AM-Office Shooting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The gunman who strode into an auto financing company and killed eight people and himself Monday owned a number of registered weapons and has been linked to two slayings the day before, police said. James Edward Pough, 42, entered the GMAC office in an upscale office park just south of downtown Monday and began ``indiscriminately shooting employees,'' then turned the weapon on himself, said Sheriff James McMillan. Police said witnesses also identified Pough as the person who killed a man and a woman in separate shootings early Sunday near Pough's home here. Police said the Sunday killings were done with the same rifle as that used Monday. In 1971, Pough was charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of a man; he pleaded guilty to aggravated assault and was sentenced to five years' probation, court records show. The court records show that if Pough obeyed the terms of his probation, he would not have a criminal record in that case. McMillan also said Pough had been arrested in 1968 ``for dangerously displaying a weapon.'' Besides the rifle, Pough, an unskilled construction laborer, also fired a .38-caliber revolver at least once in the Monday killings. ``We also found a 9mm pistol in his car and he has other weapons that are registered in his name,'' McMillan told reporters. Asked where and how Pough got his guns, the sheriff said, ``We're trying to find the answer to that right now. And it's somewhat ironic since he is a convicted felon.'' Records show that Pough was married, but neighbors said they had not seen his wife for some time. ``He was a nice person, he came in his house, minded his own business,'' said Lonnie Webster, who lives nearby. Another neighbor who refused to give her name said Pough was ``a nice guy. There were no misunderstandings, no trouble.'' Police searched Pough's apartment and emerged with a brown bag, but refused to say what it contained or whether other weapons were found. Pough had several rifle clips and ammunition for the handgun in his pockets when he walked into the GMAC office just before 11 a.m., police said. GMAC had repossessed Pough's 1988 Pontiac Grand Am in January. The sheriff said the repossession may not have been the sole motive for the Monday shootings but offered no further suggestions. The Sunday shootings took place near Pough's apartment in the northwest section of the city. Louis Carl Bacon, 39, was shot twice in the chest as he stood on a corner at 12:50 a.m.; the gunman approached on foot, fired two shots and fled, said police spokesman Steve Weintraub. Doretta Drake, 30, was shot in the head as she walked along a street at about 1 a.m. Weintrub said the gunman drove by, fired a shot from his car and drove off. The sheriff said at least one of the Sunday shootings stemmed from arguments over ``services of a prostitute,'' but he did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Says Not Sure Inspections Would Catch Crak that Caused Iowa Crash
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety investigators said Monday current inspection methods might not detect a crack in a jet engine part like the one that caused last summer's air crash in Iowa that killed 112 people. The National Transportation Safety Board, in formal recommendations to the Federal Aviation Administration, called for the FAA and the engine manufacturer, General Electric Co., to develop new inspection methods to detect cracks before they reach dangerous size. The middle, tail-mounted engine of a United Air Lines DC-10 exploded in flight on July 19, 1989, cutting all hydraulic lines of the aircraft control system. The pilots tried to make an emergency landing at Sioux City Iowa, but the plane crashed during the attempt, killing 111 or 296 people on board. One of the injured later died. According to the board, the engine exploded because a crack in the inner bore of the first-stage rotor disk grew so large that the rapidly spinning 270-pound disk broke apart, spewing shrapnel-like pieces throughout the tail area of the aircraft. The disk carries the 38 blades of the fan on the GE CF6-6 engine. The flaw that led to the crack could have been detected if the final surface inspection by chemical etching had been done on the rotor in its final shape, rather than an intermediate shape as was done, the board concluded. It recommended that the FAA require this etching inspection on the final part shape of all rotating parts made of titanium. The FAA has 90 days to respond to the board's recommendations. Following the accident, the FAA ordered the six remaining disks made from the same ingot of titanium removed from service, leaving 55 made from the same raw material and 165 made before the manufacturing process was changed in 1971. Ultrasonic inspections were ordered for the remaining disks, including those made by the new process. But computer models developed by GE show that a surface crack in the forward area of the inner bore of the rotor disk ``could propagate from a size just below the level of detectability to a critical size in significantly fewer that 500'' flights, using one ultrasonic inspection method, and the second method ordered to be used ``may not be any more capable'' of catching those cracks, the board said. The manufacturer calls on users to inspect rotor surfaces under ultraviolet light after a special wash whenever engines are taken apart. The board said it was concerned that United's engine passed such an inspection 760 flight before the accident, and was concerned that there are no requirements for such inspections at intervals based on expected crack growth rates. The board has not determined why the crack was not discovered at the ultraviolet inspection. The board said it concluded that the FAA's post-crash orders ``taken alone, are inadequate to detect these potentially critical cracks.'' It called on the FAA to require an alternate inspection method, such as the use of electrical eddy currents in the part being inspected. The board also called on the FAA to adopt for engines the assumption now used for aircraft structures when calculating inspection intervals _ not that the part is flawless originally, but that it contains a flaw just below the level of detectability.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors of Gunman's Attack `Running For Their Lives'
With AM-Office Shooting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some employees dashed through a back door and ducked into neighboring buildings after a gunman walked into their auto loan office and opened fire, killing eight people before he committed suicide. ``They were running literally for their lives,'' said Heather McRae, a worker at American Transtech, near the General Motors Acceptance Corp., scene of Monday's carnage. Police, GMAC employees and emergency workers described a scene of horrible violence inside the building, with many of the victims shot as many as eight times. ``It was the worst scene I've seen since I've been in the police department in terms of gruesomeness,'' said Sgt. Steve Weintraub, a police spokesman with the department for 16 years. James Edward Pough, 42, entered the one-story white stone building about 10:45 a.m. EDT, shot two customers and then began firing on employees. More than 80 employees worked in the 11,000-square-foot GMAC office, part of a pine-tree laden office park that also houses several AT&T subsidiaries, State Farm Insurance and a variety of small businesses. GMAC officials would not allow reporters into the office, but it was described as having several rows of desks laid out in one large room _ offering few obstacles to the gunman. GMAC employee Richard Langille said office workers dived under desks when the shooting began. ``And then we realized the guy was pointing his gun underneath people's desk and killing them one by one,'' said Langille. ``I just saw the bottom of the carpet and just prayed.'' ``He just shot until he saw no one else to shoot,'' said Sheriff James McMillan said. In addition to the dead, five people were injured and remained hospitalized late Monday with multiple gunshot wounds. ``I had to keep stepping over bodies to give victims CPR,'' said Sheriff's Office patrolman Steve Dubberly, the second officer on the scene. ``It's the worst slaughter I've ever seen in my life.'' The gunman carried a .30-caliber, clip-fed semiautomatic rifle and a .38-caliber pistol. Most of the shots were fired from the rifle. Daniel Mulvaney, an AT&T worker, was outside on a break when he heard several gunshots. ``We saw people running from the building. One had blood on his leg and another had blood all over his back,'' Mulvaney said. As helicopters and ambulances ferried victims to three local hospitals, office workers from nearby building stood and watched from the lawns and parking lots of the well-manicured office park. At a building next door to GMAC, police counselors consoled survivors of the attack and the families of those gunned down.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas' Executes First Prisoner in 26 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with final Swindler comment read by priest; comment from widow's daughter, edits throughout to conform. Shanon cq in 14th graf.
DOC.TEXT: John Edward Swindler was electrocuted Monday night for the 1976 murder of a patrolman, becoming the first Arkansas inmate to be executed since 1964. Swindler, 46, was declared dead at 9:05 p.m by Lincoln County Coroner Keith Griffin. On Saturday, the Supreme Court had denied Swindler's final request for a stay of execution. The inmate spent his final hours at the penitentiary in southeast Arkansas with one of his lawyers and his spiritual adviser, Monsignor James O'Donnell of the Immaculate Conception Church in North Little Rock. After the execution, O'Donnell read a statement from Swindler: ``I have no animosity toward anyone. No grudges. I appreciate the care and love others have shown me and other people on death row. I hope this brings to light the injustice of capital punishment and the need to abolish it.'' Swindler was the 130th inmate put to death in the United States since 1976, when the U.S. Supreme Court let states resume capital punishment. Arkansas became the 14th state to carry out an execution since the high court ruling. The last person executed in Arkansas was Charles Franklin Fields, electrocuted in 1964 for rape. Swindler calmly spent his final day in a cell adjoining the death chamber at Cummins Maximum Security Unit, said prison spokesman David White. Swindler was sentenced to die for the Sept. 24, 1976, murder of Fort Smith police officer Randy Basnett, who was shot to death at a filling station when he recognized Swindler, a fugitive from a double murder in South Carolina. ``All I can say is justice has been done,'' said Shanon Howard, daughter of Basnett's widow, Cindy. ``As far as I'm concerned, it's over and done and let it lie at that.'' Swindler, sentenced before Arkansas changed its method of execution from electrocution to injection, left the choice of method to prison officials, who opted for the means originally specified in his sentence, electrocution. At the time of Basnett's death, Swindler was wanted for killing a teen-age couple in South Carolina three days after his release from the federal prison at Leavenworth, Kan. While awaiting execution in Arkansas, he was convicted of those killings and sentenced to four life terms. Arkansas plans another execution soon. Ronald Gene Simmons is scheduled to die by injection on June 25 for the 1987 killings of 16 people, including 14 of his relatives.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of June 11-18:
DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislature Passes Country's First Press Freedom Law
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet legislature on June 12 passed the country's first law guaranteeing freedom of the press and creating broad rights for journalists and publishers. The measure, which was passed unanimously by the Supreme Soviet legislature, also gives any citizen the right to start a media outlet. ``The press and other mass media are free,'' the law begins bluntly, and ``censorship of the mass media is forbidden.'' After President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985 and introduced the policy of glasnost, or openness, political pressure on the Soviet media began to lighten, but there was still no legal protection from interference. Technically, freedom of the press is guaranteed by a declaration in the Soviet Constitution, but the new measure was the first law laying out detailed guarantees of press freedoms, the Tass news agency reported. The law establishes procedures for creating media outlets and specifies journalists' rights. They include the right to attend meetings and be present at the scene of disasters, the right to refuse to prepare reports that go against personal convictions and the right to hold interviews with officials. The provision giving any individual the right to establish a media outlet created the sharpest debate in the Supreme Soviet, Tass reported. The new law forbids publication of state secrets, but Tass said penalties would be imposed on the official who leaked them rather than the journalist who reported them. It also forbids slander and ``use of the mass media to interfere in citizens' private lives, infringement on their honor and dignity.''
DOC.HEAD: Publisher Says New Paper Making Profit
DOC.TEXT: Kansas City's new evening newspaper is making money after only a month of publication and will begin limited home delivery in the suburbs, the tabloid's owner said June 14. The Kansas City Evening News, published Monday through Friday, is selling an average of about 15,000 copies at 50 cents each, said owner Steve Rose. ``That's about what I had projected for circulation _ I would have been very disappointed if we hadn't made money off of that,'' said Rose, president of Sun Publications, a family-owned string of suburban weekly newspapers. He did not disclose how much money the newspaper was making. When he launched the tabloid May 14, with startup costs he said were just $1 million, Rose estimated that a combination of small staff, relatively small circulation and no home delivery would keep costs low. But he said June 14 he will start limited home delivery in two suburbs, Overland Park and Leawood, Kan. City ordinances prevent the Evening News from being sold on street corners in those towns, he said. Rather than go to court, he decided to begin home delivery there later this month. In other parts of the Kansas City area, the Evening News will continue to be sold only at street corners, newsracks and stores, said Rose, who spoke in a telephone interview from San Antonio, where he was attending a newspaper conference. Analysts had predicted the paper would have a difficult time in a city dominated by a morning paper, The Kansas City Star, with circulation of about 300,000. Last March, The Kansas City Times was merged with The Kansas City Star because of declining circulation. Rose said low costs would help him survive. ``We could still sell down to as little as 10,000 (copies) and make a profit,'' he said. ``Of course, I hope we don't do that.'' The paper, which averages about 32 pages a day, contains mostly wire service reports on national and international news and sports. It has four editorial employees and shares a building, printing press and advertising and circulation staff with Sun Publications.
DOC.HEAD: Changing Technology a Topic at Vegas Convention
DOC.TEXT: About 14,000 newspaper executives were on hand for a look at changing newspaper technology at the 62nd annual American Newspaper Publishers Association Technical Exposition and Conference. The show, June 18-20, includes 350 exhibitors. General sessions were scheduled on such topics as recycling, desktop publishing and telephone technology. The show provides an opportunity for manufacturers and suppliers to present their products and services to an international audience of top newspaper executives.

DOC.HEAD: PBS Considering Free Air Time for 1992 Presidential Candidates
DOC.TEXT: The Public Broadcasting Service is looking at ways to provide 1992 presidential candidates and the major political parties free air time beyond the normal news coverage to present their views, PBS President Bruce Christensen said June 17. ``What we're looking for is the way to increase the political dialogue,'' Christensen said in a telephone interview from Dallas, where the PBS board of directors was meeting. Christensen said specifics had not been worked out, though possibilities include several ideas recommended June 15 to top PBS officials by the John and Mary Markle Foundation of New York. The foundation has offered to contribute $5 million of the estimated $15 million to $20 million that the project would cost. Developed by Alvin H. Perlmutter, an independent television producer, the Markle study recommends that PBS offer free air time in blocks ranging from 2{ minutes to 15 minutes to the presidential candidates or the political parties. Perlmutter, who has worked for PBS and NBC, recommended creating a ``Voters Channel'' production company to prepare expanded political programming for PBS stations that also would include ``character and competence'' profiles of presidential candidates and an exploration of their debates. Regularly scheduled one-hour programs would be broadcast during September and October 1992, with half-hour programs airing daily the week before the November general election. The report also recommended that the programs include segments examining political ads and party activities in the campaign and the media's coverage of it. And it called for a segment in which voters could voice their views on the candidates and the issues.
DOC.HEAD: Journalists Name Computer Maker in Injury Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Eight journalists filed a $270 million lawsuit against a computer maker on June 15, contending they suffered disabling injuries from using the company's word processors in newsrooms. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, charged that Atex Publishing Systems, a subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Co., was negligent in marketing the computers and had failed to warn users of the dangers or to develop substitute systems. It also alleged that the company ``ignored, suppressed or disregarded'' medical studies about ``the causal relationship between the repetitive use of computer systems and cumulative trauma disorders.'' The journalists, each seeking $20 million in punitive damages and $10 million in compensatory damages, included two from Newsday, two from American Banker and individual staffers at The Associated Press, New York Newsday, The Village Voice and Discount Store News. Three spouses also asked $10 million each for loss of companionship, bringing the total number of plaintiffs to 11. None of the employers were named as defendants. Ruth Marcus, an attorney for the plaintiffs, said New York state law provides that workers cannot sue employers for work-related injuries but must pursue such claims through workmen's compensation. Eastman Kodak spokesman John Labella said the company had no comment because its lawyers had not seen the suit. It was the second lawsuit filed in New York in less than a month against the company, which manufactures computer systems designed for use in newsrooms. Three reporters and an editor at New York Newsday demanded $40 million in a negligence suit filed June 4 in Manhattan Supreme Court. The most recent filing alleged the eight journalists ``developed and suffered severe, permanent and disabling cumulative trauma disorders, as well as psychological injuries,'' from repeated use of the Atex video display terminals. It said cumulative trauma disorders included ``repetitive strain injuries, musculoskeletal and nerve disorders, upper extremity pain syndrome, carpal tunnel syndrome, tendinitis and other injuries to the upper extremities.'' The eight journalists named as plaintiffs are: Susan Harrigan of New York Newsday, Laurie Garrett and Sandra Peddie of Newsday, Martha Gioumousis of Discount Store News, Kathy Silberger of The Village Voice, Wendy Grover and David Neustadt of American Banker and Anne Buckley of The Associated Press. The other plaintiffs are Harrigan's husband, Peter Benjaminson; Peddie's husband, Brian Quinn, and Neustadt's wife, Maisie McAdoo.

DOC.HEAD: Media Duped by Bogus Elizabeth Taylor Story
DOC.TEXT: A hoaxer tricked the news media into running a bogus story about Elizabeth Taylor on June 10 by gaining access to messages left with a public relations company's answering service. The story, distributed worldwide by The Associated Press and United Press International, said Miss Taylor was romantically involved with a 23-year-old man and had just undergone surgery. ``It is a hoax,'' said Miss Taylor's publicist, Chen Sam. ``I have contacted Miss Taylor's attorneys and we are going to conduct an investigation. It is apparently somebody using my (telephone) service.'' Ms. Sam's New York City public relations firm was the sole media link during Miss Taylor's nine-week hospitalization for pneumonia at St. John's Hospital and Health Center in Santa Monica. The Sam organization discouraged reporters from calling St. John's about Miss Taylor and instructed the hospital's public relations staff not to answer reporters' questions. Under California privacy law, hospitals must abide by the wishes of patients who don't want information released about them. The AP office in Los Angeles had placed calls to the hospital and to Chen Sam and Associates after receiving a message Sunday from an AP affiliate in England, the Press Association. Editors at the British domestic news agency had heard Miss Taylor had undergone another operation and wanted a story. The hoaxer said Miss Taylor underwent an abdominal biopsy and was expected to be released from the hospital within two weeks on the arm of Julian Lee Hobbs of Lake Orion, Mich., described as Miss Taylor's boyfriend. The hospital spokeswoman was unavailable for comment. When the reporter called New York, he was connected to Ms. Sam's answering service and left a message. A short time later, a woman returned the call, saying she was Lisa Flowers from Chen Sam and Associates. She then gave the reporter the bogus information about Miss Taylor's romantic involvement and the surgery. The hoaxer also provided the same story to UPI and City News Service, a metropolitan Los Angeles wire service. The AP reporter, in an effort to verify the authenticity of the source, later placed a second call to Ms. Sam's answering service, leaving a message for Lisa Flowers. The answering service operator accepted that message without question. Later, an AP reporter placed a third call to Ms. Sam's answering service. A woman identifying herself as Ms. Sam returned that call and verified the identity of ``Ms. Flowers'' and the story she had told. Ms. Sam said no one from her organization had talked to reporters. She said a woman involved in the hoax had telephoned her answering service and was given the publicist's messages after somehow providing proper coded identification to the switchboard. ``It was all very cleverly done,'' Ms. Sam said. ``It was done on a Sunday when we weren't around. I can't understand how they got the code. I've had to change the entire system here.''
DOC.HEAD: Times of London Reluctantly Enters Modern Era With Style Changes
DOC.TEXT: The venerable Times of London has revised its Victorian-era style guide to include such brash and contemporary language as the title ``Ms.'' Editor Simon Jenkins tried to break the news gently to readers of the 205-year-old newspaper, who tend to regard its eccentricities as a national treasure on the order of Big Ben. ``The mirror that a newspaper holds up to the world is constantly smudged with jargon, bad usage and verbosity,'' Jenkins wrote June 12. ``A style guide is a periodic cleansing of that mirror.'' The Times style guide, introduced at the turn of the century, was last revamped in the mid-1960s. There were regular updates but the guide remained ``terribly restrictive and quite Victorian,'' said literary editor Philip Howard, who helped write the new one. The old style guide was replete with arcane treasures such as The Times' singular spelling of Mikhail S. ``Gorbachov.'' Its rendering of the Soviet leader's name was based on its transliteration of the Cyrillic letters. ``Our Russian specialists know that our spelling is better, but if the rest of the world spells it another way, ours looks very odd,'' Howard said. ``We're right, but we're wrong.'' So from now on, it's Gorbachev. Under the old style, The Times referred to Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece as the ``Monna Lisa,'' to show it was derived from ``Madonna.'' It will now be ``Mona Lisa.'' From now on, ``Ms.'' will be automatically used in Times news columns for American women, and for others if they request it. The Times is also dropping courtesy titles on first reference _ something certain to disappoint readers who enjoyed such prim designations as Mr. Ringo Starr. On subsequent reference, most people continue to get a title, except criminals, artists, athletes and the long dead. The new guide also has a blacklist _ words that ``slip into journalese as a form of obfuscation and circumlocution and gobbledygook,'' Howard said. These include: problem, provision, very, issue, accommodate, crisis, interesting, and situation. Especially ``crisis situation.'' And ``probe.'' ``Words like probe should be confined to stories about surgeons,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Media Lawyers Say Release of Outtakes Would Threaten News Gathering
DOC.TEXT: Media lawyers told Maine's highest court June 14 that the release of unaired portions of a videotaped interview would threaten news gathering. A prosecutor who wants the tape said she is not trying to restrict press freedom. The Maine Supreme Judicial Court heard arguments on an appeal by WCSH-TV of Portland, which is challenging an order to surrender tapes of its 12-minute interview last February with Biddeford Police Commissioner Denis Letellier. Only about 2{ minutes of the tape was broadcast. York County District Attorney Mary Tousignant wants to present the remaining footage to the grand jury. That panel is looking into complaints that Letellier used his position to try to get a motor vehicle charge against his son reduced. Attorney John Paterson, representing the station, argued that the Superior Court erred when it refused to quash the subpoena without considering the constitutional issues. Those included fears that release of the tapes could inhibit potential news sources and have a chilling effect on the way news is gathered and edited. ``The news gathering process itself is a part of the very freedom of the press that the First Amendment protects,'' said Paterson. He asserted there was a ``qualified privilege'' protecting unpublished material. Tousignant said there was no basis to withhold the tapes because Letellier's statement was made in public and without any claim to confidentiality.

DOC.HEAD: Feminist Groups Angered Over Current Issue of Esquire Magazine
DOC.TEXT: Feminist groups announced a boycott June 13 against Esquire magazine, saying they're outraged by an article in the latest issue titled ``Your Wife: An Owner's Manual.'' ``We find it to be literally an expression of the degradation of women,'' said Tammy Bruce, president of the local chapter of the National Organization for Women. ``It puts us into a subhuman level, places women into a thing mode,'' Bruce said in a telephone interview. The June edition of Esquire devotes several articles to wives and lists ``The Twelve Virtues of the Perfect Wife,'' which describes the ideal woman as obedient, thrifty and reverent. NOW and The Feminist Majority urged members and supporters to mount a letter-writing and telephone campaign against Esquire. The groups also urged subscribers to cancel and advertisers to withdraw their ads. Calls to the New York-based magazine seeking comment were met with busy signals after the campaign was announced.
DOC.HEAD: Sun-Times Drops Columnist for Use of Previously Published Material
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Sun-Times announced June 12 it was dropping a California-based columnist on aging because portions of two columns were taken almost verbatim from articles in The New York Times. In a bylined, Page 3 article headlined ``An apology to our readers,'' Sun-Times Editor Dennis A. Britton wrote that he had the ``embarrassing and sad duty'' of disclosing that portions of two weekly ``Age Wave'' columns by Ken Dychtwald had not been original. In a statement that appeared in the same edition, Dychtwald said the material was used accidentally. ``I deeply regret these two errors and am appreciative of your calling them to my attention so that I might publicly offer these apologies and corrections,'' Dychtwald wrote. A portion of his Feb. 11 column was subtitled ``Growing Old Happily'' and contained eight paragraphs taken almost verbatim from a Jan. 16 article in The New York Times by Daniel Goleman headlined ``Men at 65: New Findings on Well-Being,'' Britton said. The second questioned column was published in the Sunday Sun-Times on April 22, and was headlined ```Wrongful life' lawsuit raises painful, complex questions.'' Britton wrote that substantial portions of the five-paragraph item appeared March 1 in The New York Times in an article by David Margolick. That front-page story ran under the headline ``Patient's Lawsuit Says Saving Life Ruined It,'' according to Britton. Dychtwald wrote that in the Feb. 11 column, he ``mistakenly believed it was appropriate to cite only the original source'' of publicly circulated information included in The New York Times article. Dychtwald said he was on leave after the birth of his son when his staff ``inadvertently failed to credit The New York Times as the primary source'' for some of the material in the April 22 column. The Sun-Times investigation was prompted by a reader who noticed the similarities between the April 22 Dychtwald column and the Margolick piece, Britton said, adding that a library search revealed the other problem. The Sun-Times purchased the column directly from Age Wave Inc., Emeryville, Calif., said Penny Williams-Martin, Britton's secretary. Hearst Entertainment King Features Syndicate also distributes a column under the ``Age Wave'' name, but it is not the same column supplied to the Sun-Times, said Merry Clark, director of editorial projects for the New York-based syndicate. The King-distributed column is produced by a ghost writer under Dychtwald's byline, Clark said. The column Dychtwald has long written for the Sun-Times was too Chicago-oriented for a national audience, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Reporter Sues Oregonian
DOC.TEXT: A former sports reporter and columnist filed suit against The Oregonian on June 12, claiming the newspaper broke his employment contract by firing him last year. David B. Kahn, who covered professional basketball, is seeking $200,000 in lost wages and benefits and $10,000 for costs incurred finding other work. He also is asking for $29,869 in overtime pay, and wants to recover attorney fees and court costs. In his five-page lawsuit, Kahn claimed he received no warning of any improper conduct before he was fired in October 1989 after five years at the paper. The suit also claims he was not paid for overtime work. Fred A. Stickel, president and publisher of the Oregonian Publishing Co., said he could not comment specifically on Kahn's allegations. ``The only comment I have with regard to this since it's in litigation is we don't have many discharges around here,'' Stickel said. ``The few that we do have are generally for gross misconduct.'' Kahn now writes a sports column for the Willamette Week newspaper in Portland and hosts a local radio sports call-in show.
DOC.HEAD: Editor Says Report of His Quitting Was Wrong
DOC.TEXT: The founder and editor of Street News, the newspaper sold by the homeless, said June 12 that reports of his quitting stemmed from a misunderstanding. ``I was just taking a few days off. I was burned out,'' said Hutchinson Persons, citing an 80-hour work week and other pressures of the job. He said he returned to work on June 11, two days after newspaper spokesman Jeffrey Sussman reported his departure. Sussman has since said he got the information from ``people who in his absence said he resigned. I think they thought he really had quit.'' Asked about a state investigation of his newspaper's finances, Persons said he had provided the attorney general's office with information it had requested, but he knew nothing about the status of the inquiry. Press reports have quoted unnamed sources as saying Street News employees told the attorney general that as much as $250,000 was unaccounted for. Accountings of Street News' income and spending have been printed in the last two editions of the bimonthly newspaper, Persons said.
DOC.HEAD: Guild Approves 3-Year Contract With Sunpapers
DOC.TEXT: The Washington-Baltimore Newspaper Guild Local 35 has ratified a new three-year contract with The Baltimore Sun Co. that calls for weekly wage increases ranging from $20 to $36 in each year for 875 employees. The vote June 14 was 290-69 in favor of the contract that covers employees in the news, commercial, clerical and building departments. The guild was the sixth and final union representing employees at The Sun and The Evening Sun to approve new labor agreements. Top minimum paid to reporters _ the minimum salary paid to the most experienced reporters _ would rise from the current contract's $790 a week to $826 a week this month, and to $898 a week in June 1993.
DOC.HEAD: Journal-American Employees Ratify New Contract
DOC.TEXT: Employees of the Bellevue Journal-American newspaper reluctantly accepted a new contract offering annual pay raises of about 2.5 percent through 1993. ``It wasn't a happy vote. People just felt they had no choice but to take it,'' said Art Joyner, administrative officer for the Pacific Northwest Newspaper Guild. The contract was accepted June 14 on a 23-18 vote, which also ended a lawsuit stemming from the old contract, the newspaper said. The guild had filed a federal lawsuit in April charging that the paper was not deducting union dues from employee paychecks. Basic pay increases will be in steps, starting with 2 percent on July 1, followed by 1 percent Jan. 1, and continuing on that schedule until April 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Historical Society Begins Computer News Index Project
DOC.TEXT: The Omaha World-Herald is donating $150,000 to help start an electronic index of its clip files to be made available to the public. The Douglas County Historical Society installed eight computers on June 13 for its ``Living Morgue.'' Roger Reeves, curator of the historical society, said the clips, which fill three rooms, will first have to be preserved. ``When we first got them, they were crunched into small envelopes. We'll unfold them and put them into acid-free files to deter any more aging. Those that are too delicate will be photocopied on acid-free paper.'' During the second phase, Reeves and a staff of five will enter brief summaries of each story into the computers, which will be accessible to colleges and public libraries statewide for a fee.
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Closes in Nyssa
DOC.TEXT: Publication of the monthly Nyssa Gate City Journal has been suspended, general manager Jim Allison said. Owners Ted and Kay Grossman, now living in Washington's Puget Sound area, had tried to sell the paper for about five years, Allison said. Allison said the paper, with a monthly circulation of 1,500, lost money for several years. The last issue was published May 23.
DOC.HEAD: Striking Journalists Publish Own Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Journalists stood on street corners hawking a newspaper they published on their own after launching Norway's first newspaper strike in 44 years. The 32-page tabloid Avisa, the Norwegian word for newspaper, appeared on June 11, a day after wage negotiations collapsed. It competed with regular newspapers that succeeded in publishing thin editions that day. The Norwegian Union of Journalists had ordered strikes at eight major newspapers and the national news service NTB. Norway's publishers association responded by locking out reporters from 57 other newspapers. In all, about 2,000 journalists were on strike or locked out. Employers offered less than half the journalists' demand of a 4.57 percent increase on their $34,460 average annual salary, reports said.
DOC.HEAD: Serbian Journalists Complain of Bias in Belgrade TV News
DOC.TEXT: Independent journalists' groups in Serbia complained of bias in Belgrade TV coverage of an anti-Communist rally and demanded criminal charges be brought against the Communist director. ``We consider that television reports before, during and after the opposition rally ... represent a drastic violation of journalistic ethics,'' said a statement released June 15 by Belgrade Television's independent employees union. More than 30,000 people from the one-party state of Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, demonstrated in Belgrade on June 13 demanding free elections and an end to Communist rule in their state. The main rally ended peacefully, but police later used clubs to disperse demonstrators who went to the TV station to demand coverage of their demands and the resignation of Dusan Mitevic, a Communist official appointed to head the state-run TV last year. Belgrade TV and Serbia's state-run press have described the rally as ``a betrayal of Serbia'' and its participants as ``fascist hooligans.'' They demand a purge of reporters from Belgrade's independent radio station, which gave comprehensive coverage to the event. A similar protest about coverage was made against the newspaper Politika, an outlet of Serbia's ruling Communists, by 37 Politika reporters. Its story June 14 on the rally was headlined, ``The Anti-Serbian Gathering Was Unsuccessful.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. Lags in Development of High-Definition TV
DOC.TEXT: The United States could be damaging its world position in high technology by falling behind in development of high-definition television, congressmen say. ``The message is clear: Congress and the administration, get moving,'' said Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif. ``We must recognize the huge significance of HDTV to our economy.'' A report issued June 12 by the Office of Technology Assessment, a research arm of Congress, said the United States lags behind Japan in development of HDTV. ``Japan considers HDTV to be an important step into the future information society,'' it said. High-definition television promises motion picture-quality images and compact disc-quality sound. Proponents say its development could help re-energize the U.S. electronics and computer industries.
DOC.HEAD: Study Says Cable TV Rates Rising at Twice the Inflation Rate
DOC.TEXT: Basic cable television rates climbed at twice the rate of inflation last year, according to a report released June 14. The prices for the lowest-cost basic service and most popular cable services in 1989 increased an average of 10 percent, from $14.50 to $15.95, the congressional General Accounting Office said. The total average cable bill went up 5 percent, from $25 to $26.36. The inflation rate was 4 percent to 5 percent for the year, said GAO, the investigative arm of Congress. Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., who requested the GAO survey, said the results showed that Congress ``must consider legislation that will rein in the renegade operators'' in the cable industry. The National Cable Television Association said the GAO report ``reconfirms that the average cable subscriber's monthly bill increased at about the rate of inflation in 1989, and is still further evidence that cable rate increases have leveled off.'' It said cable ``is still a very good buy.''
DOC.HEAD: Turner Apologizes for Religion Remark
DOC.TEXT: Ted Turner apologized on his own Cable News Network for calling Christianity ``a religion for losers.'' Turner, appearing on CNN's ``Crossfire'' program June 12, said he was speaking off the top of his head when he made the comment. ``I want to officially apologize to all the Christians for saying that,'' Turner said. ``That was a very uncalled-for statement. At one time or another, I've offended just about everybody. I was making a talk off the cuff when that just popped out, and I feel very sorry for it.'' Turner met earlier in the day with Chinese student leader Shen Tong, 21, who was offended by something Turner said last month. Shen said he was unable to persuade Turner to lend support to his country's democracy movement. ``He don't want to be involved. He don't want to contribute,'' Shen said. Shen sought the meeting after Turner said the Chinese government ``felt forced'' to quell democracy protests with military strength that left hundreds of demonstrators dead.
DOC.HEAD: NBC Plans To Implement Union-Rejected Contract
DOC.TEXT: NBC said June 11 it will implement a proposed four-year contract rejected in May by members of the network's major union. John Krieger, a spokesman for the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, said the union still hoped to get changes in the contract before the network puts it into effect June 20. The union, which says it has 2,373 members at NBC and NBC-owned operations, struck NBC in 1987 in a bitter walkout that lasted 17 weeks. No walkout is imminent in the current dispute. Union members have not taken a strike authorization vote and are continuing to work. The main issues are job security and jurisdiction, Krieger said. The majority of NABET's 1,300 members are engineers and technicians. The union also represents newswriters, couriers, building maintenance employees and operations directors. NBC says its offer establishes parity with union contracts in force at CBS and ABC.
DOC.HEAD: ABC, Soviet and Japanese Broadcasters To Create World Pictorial History
DOC.TEXT: ABC News is working with Soviet and Japanese TV companies to create a televised history of the 20th century. The network said June 11 it had an agreement with Gostelradio, the Soviet Union's state-run broadcast company, and NHK-Japan Broadcast Corp. A New York-based company, tentatively called The Twentieth Century, will be formed by the three organizations to oversee the history project, ABC said. The three broadcast giants will share their film and tape libraries, along with production facilities to compile the history series. Beside the series for broadcast, the agreement also provides for separate programs to develop a cable television series, interactive video discs, videocassettes and books, ABC said. No completion date or possible broadcast times were given.
DOC.HEAD: Reagan Pays Surprise Visit to ABC Affiliate Meeting
DOC.TEXT: ABC opened its annual affiliates' convention June 13 with a surprise appearance by former President Reagan. Before a packed ballroom of about 1,000 people at the Century Plaza Hotel, Reagan sat on stage with celebrity interviewer Barbara Walters for an impromptu chat that ranged from the upheaval in Eastern Europe to Reagan's views on Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Of the latter, Reagan said, ``From the first time I met him, I felt he was different from all his other predecessors. We could debate and argue and discuss _ all the things that go on in the meetings _ but when the meeting was over, we could walk out of the room arm and arm together.''
DOC.HEAD: Navy Confiscates Video from `Inside Edition' Crew
DOC.TEXT: Military police confiscated video from an ``Inside Edition'' television crew taping penned dolphins at a base where the mammals are trained as guards for nuclear submarines, the Navy said June 13. Reporter Craig Rivera, brother of talk-show host Geraldo Rivera, two other crew members and Richard O'Barry, best known as a trainer for the ``Flipper'' television series, were detained briefly June 12 for allegedly crossing into a restricted zone at Key West Naval Station. ``They were warned off and in fact crossed the lines anyway,'' Ensign Robin Perkins said. ``They were apprehended because they were in a restricted naval area.'' No charges were filed, but she said a report on the incident will be referred to the U.S. attorney's office for review. O'Barry said there were no signs saying the area was off-limits. ``We were told to get out of there and then ordered to hand over the film. We were surrounded by 15 Navy frogmen.'' He said the same thing happened last week to a crew for ABC's ``20@20'' newsmagazine show. Marcy Baron, a publicist for the show in New York, said Rivera was obeying the law and did not violate journalistic ethics.

DOC.HEAD: Schile Promoted to Lee Group Leader
DOC.TEXT: Wayne Schile, publisher of The Billings Gazette, has been promoted to a group leader in Lee Enterprises Inc. Schile will continue as publisher of The Gazette, and will assume additional responsibility for the Wisconsin State Journal in Madison, the Journal-Star Printing Co. in Lincoln, Neb., and the Quad-City Times in Davenport, Iowa, the four largest newspapers in Lee. The announcement, part of a reorganization of Lee's newspapers operations, was made June 12 by Ronald L. Rickman, vice president-newspapers for Lee Enterprises Inc., which publishes 19 daily newspapers directly or through its affiliates. Schile joined Lee Enterprises in 1968. He was named publisher of The Gazette in 1985 and previously was publisher of the Herald & Review in Decatur, Ill. Rickman also announced that Sanders Hook, publisher of the La Crosse, (Wis.) Tribune, has been named a group leader with additional responsibility for the Muscatine (Iowa) Journal, The Ottumwa (Iowa) Courier, the Globe-Gazette in Mason City, Iowa, and the Winona (Minn.) Daily News.
DOC.HEAD: Susan Miller Promoted to Scripps Howard VP
DOC.TEXT: Susan H. Miller has been promoted to vice president-editorial for Scripps Howard's newspaper and publishing division. The announcement was made June 15 by William R. Burleigh, executive vice president. Ms. Miller has been director of editorial development for the 19 Scripps Howard newspapers since 1985. In her new position, she will assume the duties of former assistant general editorial manager David F. Stolberg, who retired May 31. Ms. Miller, 45, joined Scripps Howard in 1985. She is a director of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, the Associated Press Managing Editors, the Washington Journalism Center and New Directions for News.
DOC.HEAD: Horne Named Publisher in Charleston
DOC.TEXT: John F. McGee, publisher of the Charleston Daily Mail, is retiring but will remain a director and a consultant to Thomson Newspapers Inc. An announcement June 11 named Terry L. Horne, publisher of the Bluefield (W.Va.) Daily Telegraph, his successor. Thomson owns both newspapers. Horne, 39, had been publisher at Bluefield since January 1988. He was formerly co-owner, editor and publisher of the Atchison (Kan.) Daily Globe. He also worked for the Phillips County Review in Phillipsburg, Kan., and The Wichita Eagle-Beacon. McGee, 67, is a former director of The Associated Press, the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association and the American Newspaper Publishers Association. He was an executive of the News & Courier-Post of Charleston, S.C., before becoming president and chief operating officer of the State-Record Co. of Columbia, S.C. After a brief period as a general executive of Knight Newspapers in Miami, Fla., McGee became president of Clay Communications of Charleston, which then owned the Daily Mail. In 1987, Clay Communications sold its newspapers to Lincoln Publishing Inc. of Des Plaines, Ill., a subsidiary of Thomson.
DOC.HEAD: DiMatteo Announces Early Retirement
DOC.TEXT: John R. DiMatteo, president of Guy Gannett Publishing Co., plans to take early retirement in September 1991, the company says. DiMatteo, 58, joined Guy Gannett in 1972 as executive vice president and was promoted to general manager in 1973 and president in 1978. The retirement was announced in the Portland Press Herald on June 12. No successor had been chosen yet, said Jean Gannett Hawley, publisher and board chairman of the family-owned company. Besides the Press Herald, the company's holdings in Maine include the Evening Express and Maine Sunday Telegram in Portland; the Kennebec Journal in Augusta; the Central Maine Morning Sentinel in Waterville and WGME-TV, Portland. It also owns television stations in Massachusetts, Iowa and Illinois, radio stations in Miami and Orlando, Fla., and weekly newspapers in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area.
DOC.HEAD: Lewis Named Senior Columnist
DOC.TEXT: Flora Lewis, foreign affairs columnist at The New York Times, was named the newspaper's senior columnist June 12. Lewis will be succeeded by Leslie H. Gelb, deputy editorial page editor and Op-Ed page editor. Michael R. Levitas, a senior editor of The Times, will replace Gelb. The recipient of numerous awards for foreign and diplomatic reporting, Lewis, 67, started at The Times in 1972 after writing about Europe for The Associated Press and The Washington Post. Gelb, 53, has been a diplomatic correspondent and a national security correspondent for the Times. In 1987, he was a member of the team that won the Pulitzer Prize for explanatory journalism. Levitas, 60, was editor of The New York Times Book Review from 1983 to 1989. Before that, he was metropolitan editor and editor of The Week in Review section.
DOC.HEAD: Foote Takes ASNE Post
DOC.TEXT: Cornelius F. Foote Jr., a former reporter for The Washington Post and The Miami Herald, was named minority affairs director for the American Society of Newspaper Editors on June 5. Foote, 30, is a regional director for the National Association of Black Journalists. He succeeds Mireille Grangenois, who resigned to become marketing manager with Philadelphia Newspapers Inc. Foote worked in the Post's Loudoun County bureau and covered real estate development in the Washington area for two years. He previously was a reporter for The Miami Herald for five years.
DOC.HEAD: Seymore Becomes Managing Editor of Entertainment Weekly
DOC.TEXT: James W. Seymore Jr., executive editor of People magazine, was named managing editor of Entertainment Weekly on June 11. Seymore replaces Jeff Jarvis, who resigned, citing creative differences. Both magazines are owned by Time Warner Inc. Entertainment Weekly, launched in February, provides reviews and information on television, movies, books, music and other forms of entertainment. Seymore joined Time in 1977 as an assistant editor of People. He became executive editor in 1988.
DOC.HEAD: Smith Appointed AP Special Projects Coordinator
DOC.TEXT: Victoria Smith, a promotions specialist for Arbitron Ratings, has been named special projects coordinator for the Corporate Communications division of The Associated Press. The news cooperative announced the appointment June 15. Ms. Smith, 23, replaces Janet Cappiello, who was earlier named correspondent in Stamford, Conn. Smith also has worked as an anchor, reporter and production assistant for radio stations in New York state. In her new position she will contribute to a variety of in-house AP publications.

Bettie Sue Cleveland, station manager of KOBF and the first woman to manage a TV station in New Mexico, died June 16 of cancer at San Juan Hospital. She was 55. Mrs. Cleveland also was the first woman to be president of the New Mexico Broadcasters Association and of the Farmington Chamber of Commerce. She also served on the advisory council of the New Mexico State University Department of Journalism. She is survived by her mother and two sons.

Leslie V. Hall, a 30-year newspaper veteran who worked 10 years on the Baltimore Sun copy desk, died June 11 of heart failure at age 50. Hall began his career after high school as a 17-year-old stringer for the Birmingham Post-Herald in Birmingham, Ala. He continued in newspaper work _ with stints in New Orleans and Charlotte, N.C., and for United Press International _ until 1987, when he retired from The Sun. He was business editor of The Charlotte Observer in the early 1970s. He is survived by a stepson, a stepdaughter, his mother, a brother and a sister.

Sports writer and editor Don McLeod, whose byline appeared in The Oregonian for 62 years, died June 15. He was 83.
