DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Art from Cuba is exempt from the trade embargo, say artists, galleries, scholars and a civil liberties group who are suing the Bush administration for banning it. The lawsuit filed June 5 charged that the Treasury Department is violating a 1988 law that excludes paintings, sculpture and drawings by Cubans from the 27-year-old U.S. embargo against Cuba's goods. The suit said the department has infringing on the First Amendment. ``Paintings are as much a part of the First Amendment as books. They are not, as the administration would have it, commodities like Cuban sugar or tobacco,'' said Michael Krinsky, a lawyer for the National Emergency Civil Liberties Committee. Joining with the NECLC in the legal action were the New York-based Center for Cuban Studies, several artists, art scholars, galleries and private collectors. Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses also joined as ``friends of the court'' in support of the plaintiffs. The complaint, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, asked that the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control be required to permit Cuban art works to be brought into the country under the ``free trade in ideas'' act, adopted by Congress in 1988.

``The Godfather, Part III,'' one of the most talked about movies of the year, has finished principal photography in Italy, New York and Atlantic City. The last in a trilogy about the fictional Corleone family poses a challenge for filmmaker Francis Ford Coppola since both ``The Godfather'' (1972) and ``The Godfather, Part II'' (1974) won best picture Academy Awards. But Paramount Pictures thinks it might have yet another winner. ``We are excited by the incredible look, texture and intrigue of the continuing saga,'' said Sidney Ganis, president of Paramount's Motion Picture Group. ``The Godfather, Part III,'' which is scheduled for release at Christmas, begins in 1979. Michael Corleone (Al Pacino) is trying to legitimize the family's dirty money. He's moved from gambling and casino operations to real estate and media. The film began shooting in Rome on Nov. 27, 1989. It ended May 25.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Freshman Lawmaker Sparks Bailout as Political Issue
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The nation's savings and loan disaster finally exploded on Capitol Hill as a political issue after a freshman Republican lawmaker provided the spark. Congress has been wrestling with the problem since the S&L industry's government-backed insurance fund went belly up at the end of the Reagan administration. Tens of billions of dollars are being spent to bail out, close down and sell off thrift institutions. Though costly, it seemed for the longest time that President Bush's effort to keep the issue quiet was the best strategy. Oh sure, it's expensive, the White House said. But let's keep it off the books, not count it against our deficit-reduction efforts, remember that a lot of it is just ``working capital.'' Congress, unable to find a good alternative, went along, although trouble flared up sporadically for some lawmakers. A handful of senators _ the so-called Keating Five _ are under investigation because of their extraordinary efforts on behalf of one spectacularly failed thrift. Some House members seeking re-election his year are under attack for their ties to financial institutions. But for the most part, lawmakers who weren't personally involved in the issue appeared to be standing back. Then this spring something changed, and the issue seemed to reach critical mass. Perhaps it was the nearness of the elections. There's a chance it was the cumulative effect of never-ending bad news and escalating costs. And just maybe the public began to catch on that, whatever the bookkeeping tricks, more of their federal tax dollars would be going to bail out inept or crooked thrift operations than, say, to education. Enter Peter Smith, a first-term Republican congressman from Vermont who reached the House in a three-way race where the Democrat and a Socialist split the majority of the vote. ``I basically blew my stack,'' Smith says. Two weeks ago Smith introduced a resolution in the House calling for the appointment of a special prosecutor, known officially as an independent counsel, to go after the savings and loans. The measure would have no binding effect, and in some ways is flawed. An independent counsel can be requested simply by a majority of either the Republicans or the Democrats on the congressional judiciary committees. ``But a freshman doesn't move the committee structure,'' Smith said. And the purpose of the law is to address conflicts of interest the Justice Department would have investigating the Bush administration, not to balkanize federal enforcement efforts for every issue that comes along. ``When you're talking about Congress and high-ranking government officials, I think the conflict exists,'' Smith said. His resolution immediately touched off lawmakers starving for a way to look tough on the issue. By late last week, more than 170 House members were cosponsoring his resolution. Even though the resolution could rightly be seen as a vote of no confidence in the administration and especially Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, Republicans were embracing Smith as a hero. ``My sense is the Justice Department has moved slowly. ... If my resolution has something to do with (prodding) those people, then I think it's a good thing,'' Smith said. ``I'm just sorry it took so long.'' When Smith scheduled a news conference on his resolution last week, he expected three colleagues to join him. Instead 17 showed up, among them House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., a top backer of the Reagan administration's S&L deregulation that Democrats say led to the financial disaster. Whether or not a special prosecutor is appointed, it now appears clear that Congress will take some sort of action this year. Savings and loan operators now are rivaling drug dealers as Congress' glamour criminals. Top Democrats and Republicans on the House Banking Committee last week introduced legislation to bolster Justice Department enforcement and give the federal government new powers to chase down some of the money embezzled from the savings institutions. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., announced a crackdown bill of his own and attacked the administration for cutting back the FBI's budget request for hundreds of new agents for the crisis. ``I have succeeded beyond my wildest dreams,'' Smith said.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Steven Komarow is a congressional correspondent for The Associated Press.

Retail prices rose a modest 0.2 percent in May, easing the strain on consumers' budgets after a painful spurt in prices early in the year, the government said. The April and May moderation in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index curbed inflation for the first five months of the year to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.8 percent. That's up significantly from the 4.6 percent rate for all of last year, but down sharply from the worrisome 8.5 percent rate in the first quarter. The latest figures were released Friday.

Industrial production jumped 0.6 percent in May, but analysts said the sharp gain was due mainly to a temporary buildup in automobile inventories. Meanwhile, the Commerce Department reported Friday that exports helped shrink the U.S. trade deficit so far this year to an annual rate of $92.16 billion, compared to a deficit for all of 1989 of $108.99 billion.

Donald Trump has missed a payment on junk bonds used to finance one of his Atlantic City resorts, the harshest signal yet of the troubles plaguing his tottering real estate empire. Trump has a 10-day grace period from Friday to make the payment of an estimated $31 million in interest and principal on bonds used to finance his Trump Castle hotel-casino. But the failure to meet Friday's deadline nevertheless brought him a step closer to default, which theoretically could force a bankruptcy filing to defend the flamboyant developer from collateral-seeking creditors.

Martin A. Siegel, who allegedly took suitcases of cash from Ivan Boesky in exchange for inside information, has been sentenced to two months in prison. U.S. District Judge Robert J. Ward on Friday cited Siegel's contrition and cooperation with prosecutors in giving him one of the shortest prison terms meted out in Wall Street's insider trading scandals.

British stock market experts said they were puzzled by the New York Stock Exchange's plan to begin after-hours trading to an effort to recapture trading of U.S. stocks now conducted overseas. The experts said Friday such trading is relatively small in Europe, and it also is not clear that the business will grow much in coming years. NYSE Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. on Thursday unveiled a five-step plan to trade securities after the exchange's traditional daytime hours. The plan would culminate in 24-hour trading by the end of the decade.

Top Soviet leaders say they have won legislative support for a market economy, despite rejection of an immediate price increase for bread and demands for a more detailed blueprint of the transition. Yuri D. Maslyukov, the chairman of the State Planning Commission, told reporters Friday that the Supreme Soviet legislature was right to posptone the first phase of a bread price increase Ryzhkov proposed for July 1. Bread is the staple of the Soviet diet.

Iran has agreed to pay Amoco Corp. $600 million for facilities seized during the 1979 Islamic revolution, removing one of the biggest obstacles to renewed trade with the United States. Two claims totaling $600 million were awarded to the American oil giant, an official of the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal said Friday. It was the biggest settlement in the arbitration body's nine-year history.

The world's two largest gold producing companies say they plan to curtail their mining operations due to the plummeting price of gold. Anglo American Corp. of South Africa Ltd. said Friday that two of its mining companies, Free State State Consolidated Gold Mines Ltd. (Freegold) and Vaal Reefs Exploration and Mining Co. Ltd., would cut back on operations in moves that will cut at least 7,800 jobs. The price of gold reached a 4-year low of $346.25 per ounce in New York and London before recovering on Thursday. Gold is South Africa's major industry, earning more than half the country's foreign currency.

House Democrats have attacked savings and loan bailout agency officials for hiring high-paid consultants, keeping executives of failed thrifts on the job and continuing to pay others who perform no work. Congress is hearing growing reports of overpaid individuals running government-held institutions, and of officers from failed institutions staying on the government payroll with six-figure salaries, said Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of the House S&L bailout task force.

The Dow Jones industrial average churned ahead to a new closing high Friday, in what was otherwise a mixed session for stocks. The average of 30 industrials rose 7.67 points to 2,935.89, surpassing its previous closing peak of 2,935.19 reached on June 4. Bond prices tumbled on discouraging economic reports. Gold prices advanced, while the dollar lost ground. Gold and silver futures rebounded slightly. Livestock and energy futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans fell.

DOC.HEAD: A High-Tech Sense of Touch Promises Bright Future For Young Company
DOC.TEXT: Interlink Electronics, a young company with a high-tech sense of touch, has its fingers in everything from aerospace to computers, music and sports. Interlink's biggest problem, in fact, might be developing all the potential uses of its patented ``force sensing resistors,'' which translate touch into electronic signals. ``One of the things that's a plague to us as a small company is the sensors fit in so many markets that people don't know what to make of us,'' said Kathryn Stewart, vice president of sales and marketing of the 5-year-old, Santa Barbara-based company. Nicknamed ``the electronic gas pedal,'' a force sensing resistor is a tactile sensor that responds with variable resistance. The harder this thick polymer film is pressed, the more its resistance drops. Interlink on Friday introduced its first high-volume consumer product, an electronic keyboard foot-pedal that is part of the ``Miracle Piano Teaching System.'' The system combines a cartridge for the Nintendo Entertainment System with a keyboard and home television to create game-like video piano lessons. That modest step into consumer electronics is only a hint of Interlink's future. The privately held company also is targetting aerospace, where its sensors are used to determine whether the various layers of airplane composite materials are being joined evenly. Among the aerospace companies experimenting with the devices are Boeing Co., Northrop Corp. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. That business represents about one-fifth of Interlink's expected $2.7 million in sales this year, said President E. Michael Thoben III. Three other key markets for Interlink are computer input devices, such as a stationary mouse for Apple Computer Inc.'s MacIntosh Portable, sensing components on electronic drums and musical keyboards, and rugged keypads for automatic teller machines. Thoben told the company's shareholders at an annual meeting Thursday that Interlink will concentrate on those four markets to build up revenue over the next few years. ``We're in transition from a research and development concern to one driven by the market,'' said Thoben. Interlink also makes a touch interpreting sensor for a robot, a device that fits under the grip of a golf club to analyze a player's swing, footplates for medical analysis of podiatry problems, and bed or wheelchair position monitors. But even that array of products just hints at the applications that have been pursued by Interlink, which is backed by the funding of Grace Ventures Corp., a unit of W.R. Grace & Co. Imagine an electronic tennis referee so accurate it could shut up John McEnroe. Interlink began work on a system proposed by a customer, which got good reviews from the U.S. Tennis Association. But the project is on hold until the customer can raise enough money to fund further research. The biomedical industry is interested in Interlink sensors to provide feedback for dispensing diagnostic and rehabilitative functions. The sensors also can be applied to the automotive industry in window, mirror and audio controls, as well as tire, brake and fuel level sensors. The company, which has only 50 U.S. employees, grew out of an idea developed by inventor Franklin Eventoff in the 1970s. Eventoff was trying to make a musical toy for his daughter when he created a way to generate an electronic response when varying degrees of pressure were applied to a sensor. Eventoff patented the invention and formed a company, then sold off most of the company. He remains a major shareholder. Interlink has refined and improved the sensors and now holds 33 patents in 10 countries.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Lower at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were lower at midday Monday following the release of unexpectedly poor government borrowing figures for May. Dealers said the day's business was characterized by thin trading, lack of interest and little news to help the market find a direction. The midmorning release of the government figures discouraged buying. Shortly after midday in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 15.1 points, or 0.6 percent, at 2,377.2. Volume came to 273.1 million shares at midday, compared with 241.4 million shares at the same time Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Contract UAL Employees Unhappy With Participation in Buyout
DOC.TEXT: In a potential setback for a union group seeking to buy UAL Corp.'s United Airlines, a group of non-contract employees says time is running out for the buyout group to accept their proposals. The non-contract employees said in a news release Sunday they had developed a package of wage concessions, benefit modifications and other elements under which they could support the buyout plan. But the United Employee Acquisition Corp., the entity formed by the unions to handle the proposed $4.54 billion buyout, has not agreed to the package, a news release from System Roundtable said. System Roundtable is the top rung of a series of groups of non-contract employees which effectively has become the non-contract employees' bargaining agent in the buyout effort. Their support is not essential to the proposed deal but the opposition of non-contract employees could complicate the unions' attempts to raise financing. The buyout group's contract to buy UAL will lapse if financing is not obtained by Aug. 10. If financing is secured, the group would have until the end of the year to close the deal. Under the agreement approved April 6 by UAL's board, United's pilots would own 37.9 percent of the company's stock, machinists would own 35.7 percent, non-contract employees would get 14.3 percent and United flight attendants would own 12 percent. In the news release, System Roundtable said, ``We are very disappointed. We think it is particularly disturbing that UEAC has not yet been able to resolve the issues relating to the non-contract employees. ``It is also surprising that agreement on this package, which is a test of UEAC's check and balance governance system, has not yet been finalized,'' the release said. ``If this package is not agreed to very shortly by UEAC, it does not bode well for UEAC's ability to make the business judgments that it will certainly face in trying to finance the proposed leveraged buyout, and, if that transaction is completed, in running the airline,'' the release said. Hank Krakowski, a spokesman for the UEAC, declined to comment on System Roundtable's stance and said he was not familiar with the package of terms. Non-contract workers comprise over one-third of UAL's total work force of about 71,500 people. They include reservations and ticket agents, professional and technical staffers, and management and supervisors excluding Chairman Stephen Wolf and other top officers. The union group includes the Air Line Pilots Association, machinists and the Association of Flight Attendants. The union group has proposed overall employee wage and benefit cuts totaling $2 billion over five years to offset buyout costs. At UAL Corp.'s annual meeting April 26, Daryl Thorogood, a United reservations agent from San Francisco, said the exclusion of salaried and management employees from buyout negotiations was ``rude, illegal and undemocratic.'' Ms. Thorogood said the non-contract employees have had no voice in deciding how much they will give up.

DOC.HEAD: Daughter of Johnson & Johnson Co-Founder Dies
DOC.TEXT: Evangeline Johnson Merrill, the last surviving child of Johnson & Johnson co-founder Robert Wood Johnson, died at age 93 in North Carolina, the New York Times reported. Mrs. Merrill died Sunday at the Bryan Health Care Center in Hendersonville, N.C., as a result of injuries suffered in a fall earlier this year, the report said. She was born in New Brunswick, N.J. in 1897. In World War I, Mrs. Merrill worked in the Red Cross Ambulance Corps and was decorated by President Woodrow Wilson. She was also a prominent figure in the arts. In 1943, she was made a fellow in perpetuity at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and she was a patron of the Peabody Museum of Yale University. In the 1920s, Mrs. Merrill fought the town of Palm Beach, Fla., by protesting a ban on women wearing abbreviated bathing suits. Her method of protest included dropping handbills on the beach from a small plane she piloted, The Times said. Mrs. Merrill is survived by her third husband, Charles Merrill, two daughters and five grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Chief Warns of Serious Oil Price Slide if Output Not Cut
DOC.TEXT: OPEC President Sadek Boussena has warned the cartel that oil prices will collapse if the organization's members do not adhere to a production cutback agreement, the Middle East Economic Survey reported Monday. The oil industry newsletter, published in Nicosia, said that Boussena stressed in a June 11 letter to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' 13 members that if current over-production was not curbed, ``things may soon get out of control.'' Boussena, Algeria's Mines Minister, stressed that the current price slide stemming from over-production could lead ``to a serious price collapse akin to the one experienced in 1986, with its full consequences on member countries' revenues and economic prospects.'' Oil prices nosedived to below $10 a barrel in 1986, causing major economic convulsions for OPEC and other major producers. The cartel currently is seeking to maintain prices at around $18 a barrel but prices on world markets have fallen to about $15 a barrel. OPEC members agreed in Geneva on May 2 to trim production to 22.1-22.6 million barrels a day from the April daily level of 23.98 million barrels, far in excess of the ceiling agreed in December. But overall OPEC production last month was estimated at 23.68 million barrels a day because several members, particularly Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, were continuing to produce well above their quotas. The newsletter quoted Boussena as saying that ``the main driving factor'' behind the recent downturn in prices ``is undoubtedly the deep-rooted feeling of the market that the agreement reached in Geneva is not being implemented by OPEC.'' He said that this ``is fueling the extreme downward pressure on prices (and) is now substantiated by the publication of the major secondary sources' figures on OPEC production for May ... thus highlighting the fact that reduction pledges have not been effectively implemented, at least to the extent necessary for the market to build confidence in the agreement.'' He cautioned that if action was not taken swiftly to reduce production ``things may soon get out of control with all the damaging consequences on OPEC cohesion and credibility and our member countries' ability to continue working together for the benefit of all.'' According to the newsletter, Boussena plans to visit all OPEC members soon to take soundings on the prospect of working out a durable agreement on production and prices at the July conference. The weekly newsletter noted that despite ``considerable disquiet'' in OPEC about the production violations, there was no chance of an emergency OPEC meeting before the scheduled July 25 conference in Geneva. The survey reported last week that despite the over-production in May, output was expected to drop considerably in June.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Trump Loan in Jeopardy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `If he doesn't ...,' with one graf to CLARIFY that grace period given on Friday. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Banking sources ...'
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's tentative debt restructuring arrangement, which is needed to boltser his troubled real estate and casino empire, is being jeopardized by ongoing disputes among small and large creditor banks, a report published today said. The New York Times said negotiatons fell apart Saturday when the big lenders argued over the proposed terms of the loan package reached earlier this month. At the center of the dispute is how much each bank should contribute and the collateral to be used, the newspaper said, quoting unidentified sources. Trump's financial problems grew more precarious on Friday, after he missed the payment on an estimated $31 million in interest and principal on bonds used to finance his Trump's Castle hotel-casino in Atlantic City. Trump was given a 10-day grace period on Friday. If he doesn't come up with the money before the grace period expires, he could be in default, and that might place Trump in jeopardy of losing his New Jersey casino licenses. Banking sources familiar with the talks said last week that Trump's four major bank lenders _ Citibank, Bank Trust New York Corp., Chase Manhattan and Manufactueres Hanover _ agreed to provide an additional $60 million in loans and to temporarily suspend interest payments. The sources had said Citicorp and Bankers Trust would provide about two-thirds of the new loan. The big banks have been trying to persuade some of the smaller creditors, including some Japanese banks, to go along with the proposed restructuring, but some of those institutions have been opposed to the plan. First Fidelity Bancorp of Newark, N.J., and Midlantic Banks Inc. of Edison, N.J., reportedly were the main holdouts. The ongoing negotiations also have raised speculation that bankers want more authority over operation of Trump's properties. The Wall Street Journal reported today that the banks have been demanding that Trump appoint two top executives _ a chief executive officer and a chief financial officer _ to control the daily operations of the Trump Organization. Dan Klores, a spokesman for Trump, refused to comment on the negotiations or the reports. He said the banks resumed talks today after their meeting broke off on Saturday. Banks also have refused official comment. At his 44th birthday celebration at his Taj Mahal Casino Resort on Saturday, Trump told throngs of employees that he was confident he would rise above his financial problems. ``Over the years, I've surprised a lot of people. The largest surprise is yet to come,'' he said. The purpose behind the proposed debt restructuring plan was to give Trump time to wait for his assets to rise in value. Trump has been beset by a slumping real estate market in New York, and disappointing results from his three Atlantic City casinos and the Trump Shuttle airline. His real estate holdings, which also include New York's Plaza Hotel and Trump Tower, were built largely with the funds from bank loans and borrowed from junk bonds. Trump owes banks an estimated $2 billion and bondholders another $1 billion.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 464.44 down 3.11 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Good Crop Weather Pressures Futures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, pressured by forecasts for good crop weather this week in the Midwest. The predicted mild temperatures and scattered showers are considered friendly to the new corn and soybean crops. But selling pressure was limited by reports of weekend flood damage to fields in central Iowa, central Ilinois and parts of Nebraska. ``I've gotten probably 10 calls this morning from all over'' with reports of crop damage caused by severe weather, said William Biedermann, director of research for the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. The opening declines extended fairly steep losses registered last week in the corn and soybean markets. The Agriculture Department's weekly report on planting progress and crop conditions was due out after the close of trading. DOC.HEAD: National Rig Count Posts Modest Gain of Eight
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States increased by eight for the second consecutive week to total 999, Baker Hughes Inc. announced Monday. Last week, the rig count had risen by eight to total 991. A year ago, the count was 795. Baker Hughes' rig count reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. The Houston-based oil toolmaker has kept track of the rig count _ the widely watched index of drilling activity _ since 1940. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, Oklahoma's count was up by seven, Pennsylvania was up by five, New Mexico by four, Colorado by three and Louisiana by one. Texas sustained the greatest decline, losing 17 rigs. Ohio lost four and Kansas and Wyoming each lost three.

DOC.HEAD: CBOE, AMEX and Cincinnati Exchange Pursue After-Hours Trading Network
DOC.TEXT: Three equities markets announced this morning they have reached a definitive agreement to trade through the night using a computer network. The Chicago Board Options Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the Cincinnati Stock Exchange hope to capture some of the trading conducted abroad when it is nighttime in the United States. The computer network would be provided by Reuters Holdings PLC. The exchanges expect the system will begin working in two to three years, providing a market from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m., officials said at news conferences in New York and Chicago. The CBOE and AMEX would handle their stock options through the system and the Cincinnati Stock Exchange would offer U.S.-traded stocks. The specific number of issues involved in the system has not been decided, officials said. Many of the details of how the system will work have yet to be determined, officials of the exchanges said at the press conferences, which were linked via television. The CBOE would build and operate the main computer for the system and Reuters would build the network that provides traders access to the markets' computer. Other exchanges, specifically the New York Stock Exchange and the Tokyo Exchange, have been invited to join the system, officials said. Although the three exchanges will be cooperating in the electronic system, James R. Jones, chairman and chief executive of the American Stock Exchange, said there still will be competition. ``We will continue to have great competition in the daytime,'' he said. ``I think this will actually increase competition globally.'' The group's intention to work toward an automated after-hours trading system was first announced in March 1989. Officials said last week's announcement of plans for late-night trading by the NYSE did not prompt today's announcement, officials said. They added, however, they were aware the NYSE was considering after-hours trading. By 1991 the NYSE plans to hold three auctions through the night of each listed stock. Each stock would trade once at each auction with trades combined at a single price. The definitive agreement was reached about a month ago and the boards of the companies involved finished approving the plan late last week.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Calls For Overhaul of U.S. Job Skills System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th graf pvs, `It also...', to UPDATE with reaction from news conference. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The report...'. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Commission Members
DOC.TEXT: Most American workers ``will see their dreams slip away'' unless society invests far more in improving their skills in school and on the job, a commission led by two former labor secretaries warned today. The United States also will lose the economic race with other countries unless business, schools and government take radical steps to boost worker skills, concluded the report. ``Most workers receive no education or training beyond high school,'' the report said, adding that existing state and federal training programs are ``haphazard, incoherent and bureaucratic.'' ``What we are facing is an economic cliff of sorts. And the front line working people of America are about to fall off it,'' the report said. Front-line workers include clerks, secretaries, machinists, drivers, farm hands and others who are not usually college educated. The report offered a blueprint for changing the way schools, business and government prepare workers for an increasingly complex economy. Among its recommendations: a requirement that U.S. companies devote at least 1 percent of payroll to skills training and a mandate that no one under 18 be allowed to hold a job until earning a certificate proving mastery of basic academic skills and work qualities. It also recommended that states, with federal assistance, create ``local youth centers'' for ensuring that all dropouts ages 14-21 earn mastery certificates. The report estimated such centers would cost $8.2 billion a year. Teacher union leaders praised the commission's findings at a news conference today. American Federation of Teachers president Albert Shanker called the report ``the most significant in the whole reform movement in terms of substance.'' Commission member John Sculley, chairman of Apple Computer, Inc., added his support and told reporters, ``I believe America today is faced with a workforce crisis.'' The report warned that many with limited skills face the loss of jobs as U.S. businesses struggle to cut labor costs to stay competitive with foreign companies. ``Higher skills means the jobs stay at home,'' the report said. Seventy percent of U.S. workers ``will see their dreams slip away'' unless society increases the commitment to improved skills, the report said. The study was produced by the 34-member Commission on the Skills of the American Work Force. The panel included top business, education and labor executives. Its chairmen were former U.S. Labor Secretaries Bill Brock and Ray Marshall and Ira Magaziner, an international business authority. The report was based on about 2,000 interviews conducted at over 550 companies and agencies since last July in the United States, Germany, Sweden, Denmark, Ireland, Japan and Singapore. While U.S. businesses spend some $30 billion training workers, only one-third is spent on non-college educated employees. About 15,000 companies, less than 1 percent of the total, provide over 90 percent of corporate-based training in the U.S., the study said. By contrast, the report found foreign education systems far more committed than U.S. schools to preparing all students for successful careers, not just the college-bound. And the approximately 100 foreign corporations in the study were generally more inclined to avoid layoffs and provide worker training than U.S. companies. The study was funded with $500,000 in grants from the Carnegie Corporation of New York, New York state and Towers Perrin, a New York-based consulting firm. The commission was created by the National Center on Education and the Economy, a Rochester, N.Y.-based group whose president, Marc Tucker, was another principal author. The report's central theme was that U.S. schools and businesses should strive to ``professionalize'' front-line workers and bolster skills so they will need less supervision. In turn, companies will become more efficient, sell more, expand and employ more people at higher wages. In an interview last week, Magaziner expressed optimism that the recommendations would be realized, especially when Americans realize that other industrial nations have already adopted many of the steps. ``I think Americans are ultimately very pragmatic once they realize a problem exists. We operate on fads. When an idea gets momentum, I think we move pretty quickly,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: The Chairman's Anti-Inflation Campaign Continues
DOC.TEXT: Sixteen years ago the chairman tried to tame inflation once and for all with a whip. As a member of President Ford's administration, he helped launch a campaign to Whip Inflation Now. Now, critics say, he is using the same rope in another way: to tie up the economy. To a very limited extent in the 1970s, it might be claimed, the chairman succeeded. Whereas consumer prices had risen 11 percent in 1974, the increase had dropped to as low as 5.8 percent in 1976. Not everyone then was willing to credit the chairman with having succeeded because the campaign was atrociously planned. It was launched as the economy was plunging into a recession that would relieve pressure on prices. And critics today are wondering again if something of the sort might be occurring. Once again the enemy is inflation, or the threat of it; the goal is to destroy it; and the risk is a descent into recession. As before, the chairman is the same. In 1974, Alan Greenspan was chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. In 1990, he is chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, which seeks to control the money supply. Greenspan has a firm, almost unrelenting grip on it, and perhaps as a direct result _ you can't buy and spend if you haven't got access to funds _ there is growing evidence of an economy progressively weakening. Consumer demand has shrunk. Real estate sales and building have almost stopped in some areas. Small businesses, especially those related in any way to real estate, have trouble borrowing. Corporate profits are on the skids. The evidence shows up all over. Plans for investment in new plants and equipment have ceased to grow. And private-sector employment shows signs of shriveling, even when temporary Census Bureau jobs are included. Money is the raw material that powers economic activity, and when the Fed tightens the spigot, the wheels of commerce slows. Keep the spigot closed long enough and some of the wheels stop. Eventually, recession threatens. Some economists think that recession is closing in, and that statistics released over the next month might even show it. But there seems to be no letup in the chairman's resolve to lick this monster called inflation. Whether he has the right notion or is destined to badly damage the economy is up for debate. Greenspan has his supporters, even among business people, who say the nation can never embark on a real expansion until the job is done. That job, of course, is to bury inflation so deeply it cannot arise again for years. The chairman's first effort failed after a few years. After dropping to 5.8 percent in 1976, the consumer price index reached double digits in 1979 and helped bring on the deep recession of 1981 and 1982. Recovery followed, helped a great deal by a loosening of the money spigot. As most people know, because they benefited from it, the economy began a long expansion right through 1989, an expansion that might be about to end. Beginning late in the 1980s, the Fed once again began closing the spigot, not abruptly or completely, but enough to reduce the growth of bank reserves _ which govern lending _ and then to bring about an actual contraction. Now the signs of a economy on the edge are showing up everywhere, and from everywhere the cries for easier money will be heard. Not just from business either, but from elected officials who fear for their jobs. Greenspan's supporters, and probably the chairman himself, seem to think, however, that slow growth or even a recession might be the price to pay to bury inflation for years to come.

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Bentsen Urges Bush to Include Carla Hills in Summit Delegation. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills, who would like to be included in the U.S. delegation to next month's economic summit, got support Monday from an influential Democratic senator. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, urged President Bush to reconsider his decision excluding Hills from the summit of the world's seven largest industrial countries scheduled for July 9-11 in Houston. Traditionally, the only members of the president's Cabinet who attend the annual economic summits are the secretary of state and the treasury secretary. But Hills has made no secret of the fact that she would like to make an exception to that rule this year. Bentsen said Hills' presence was especially important this year because of the many unresolved issues in the current Uruguay Round of global free trade talks, being held under the auspices of the 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. ``Most of the issues of greatest importance to the United States _ investment, intellectual property, services trade _ have not been resolved,'' Bentsen wrote in a letter to Bush. ``Given Ambassador Hills' critical role in the negotiations, I believe that she should be part of the team that accompanies you to the summit,'' Bentsen said. Hills has said she hopes Bush and the leaders of Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada will use the summit to search for common ground to break the stalemate in the trade talks. The summit will come only a few weeks before a critical negotiating session in Geneva. The Bush administration has made achieving a new agreement its top trade priority this year. However, it has been unable to overcome resistance to a key plank in the U.S. proposal that would eliminate expensive trade-distorting farm subsidies over the next decade. Torie Clarke, Hills' press secretary, said that Hills ``certainly appreciated Chairman Bentsen's input, but now if she does get invited, it won't be because of her own charm and persuasiveness.''

DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Monday by the Supreme Court.
PENSIONS
The court spared the federal program protecting the pensions of 30 million American workers from a potential financial crisis. By an 8-1 vote, the court broadened the authority of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to order employers to restore terminated pension plans. The case is PBGC vs. LTV, 89-390.
PATENTS
The court ruled that a federal law reducing patent infringement protection for drug companies applies to medical devices. The court, by a 6-2 vote, refused to reinstate a $26.7 million award against Medtronic Inc. of Minneapolis. Eli Lilly and Co. of Indianapolis said Medtronic infringed patents on a device implanted in patients to correct potentially fatal heart rhythms. The case is Eli Lilly vs. Medtronic Inc., 89-243.
S&L
The court agreed to consider killing a lawsuit by a Texas businessman who says federal regulators caused the financial ruin of his failed savings and loan association. The court said it will review a ruling that revived part of Thomas M. Gaubert's negligence suit against the government. The suit alleges the federal regulators who assumed day-to-day operation of the Irving-based Independent American Savings Association ran it right out of business. The case is U.S. vs. Gaubert, 89-1793.
HANK WILLIAMS
The court refused to kill a lawsuit in which a woman who claims to be Hank Williams Sr.'s daughter seeks some of the late country music legend's copyright royalties. The justices, without comment, let stand a federal appeals court ruling that Cathy Yvonne Stone, 37, is entitled to have her legal fight put before a jury. The cases are Williams vs. Stone, 89-1538 and 89-1563.
TENURE
The court left intact a decision forcing Boston University to grant a lifetime professor's job to a woman found to have been a victim of sex bias. The court, without comment, rejected arguments that requiring the university to grant her tenure interferes with its academic freedom. A key issue in the case of English literature professor Julia Prewitt Brown was the admissibility of trial evidence allegedly showing university President John Silber harbored sexist attitudes. The case is Boston University vs. Brown, 89-1680.
SECURITIES
The court let the Commodity Futures Trading Commission regulate a new form of financial trading called index participations. The court, without comment, left intact a ruling that gives the CFTC, rather than the Securities and Exchange Commission, such regulatory power. Index participations are contracts of indefinite duration based on the value of a group of securities. The cases are Investment Company Institute vs. SEC, 89-1484; American Stock Exchange vs. Chicago Mercantile Exchange, 89-1502; Philadelphia Stock Exchange vs. Chicago Mercantile Exchange, 89-1503.
ANTITRUST
The court said it will use the case of an eye surgeon denied staff privileges at a Los Angeles hospital to study the scope of a key federal antitrust law. The justices agreed to hear an appeal by the hospital seeking to dismiss the doctor's antitrust suit. A ruling is not expected until next year. The case is Summith Health Ltd. vs. Pinhas, 89-1679.

DOC.HEAD: Sears to Open 198 Brand Central Stores This Week
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. this week will open 198 of its in-store, brand-name electronics and home appliance outlets in 16 states and Puerto Rico, the country's largest retailer said Monday. The introduction of more than 840 Brand Central outlets, which will be completed with the new additions this week, is the first step in Sears' strategy to become a ``store of superstores'' featuring brand name and private-label merchandise, said Michael Bozic, chairman and chief executive office of Sears Merchandising Group. The next phases will focus on the furniture, children's, men's and women's clothing, home and yard, and auto departments. Sears will open 37 brand-name furniture outlets this year, some in Sears stores and others free-standing. It will revise 300 auto centers, adding brand-name merchandise, and also open 50 brand-name outlets each in the apparel and home and yard departments, Bozic said. Chicago-based Sears is in the third year of overhauling its merchandising unit to better compete with discount and specialty retailers. DOC.HEAD: With AM-Work Skills, Bjt
High Court to Review Rulings on Union Election Issue
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court agreed Monday to resolve conflicting rulings over unions' legal duty to cooperate with candidates for union office who want to distribute campaign literature. The justices said they will decide whether a maritime industry union violated federal labor law when in 1988 it refused to give a membership mailing list to a candidate for the union's presidency. Labor law gives candidates for union office a right to have campaign literature distributed by the union. The court must decide whether that right is conditioned by the reasonableness of the request for distribution, or the reasonableness of a union rule restricting such requests. A decision is expected sometime next year. The appeal acted on today was filed by the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, a 7,500 national union representing ship officers, pilots and other merchant marine workers. The union, based in Baltimore, holds elections every four years. Prior to the nominating convention for the 1988 election, presidential candidate Timothy A. Brown, a ship captain from Tampa, Fla., asked the union for mailing labels containing the names and addresses of all voting union members. Brown wished to distribute literature at his own expense before the nominating convention. He said he sought to attract support from other members before they were likely to have committed their votes to other candidates. The early mailing also would help offset the advantage held by incumbent union officers who might seek re-election. Elwood Kyser, a union officer, turned down Brown's request because the union's constitution does not authorize distribution of campaign literature until after a nominating convention. Brown sued, and a federal judge in Baltimore ordered the union to furnish the mailing labels so that Brown's campaign literature could be distributed. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the order last Nov. 17 by an 8-2 vote. ``We believe the test to be not whether the union's rule was reasonable but whether the candidate's request was reasonable,'' the apeals court said. Another federal appeals court ruled otherwise. Asked for their views, Bush administration lawyers said the 4th Circuit court's ruling is correct but urged the high court to use the case to resolve the conflicting decisions. The case is International Organization of Masters, Mates & Pilots vs. Brown, 89-1330.

DOC.HEAD: Top Bank Regulator Tries To Reassure Northeast Bankers, Consumers
DOC.TEXT: The nation's chief federal bank regulator, watching credit across the Northeast dry up amid rising loan losses, tried to reassure jittery bankers and their customers Monday that the industry is sound. Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke told a group of Providence executives that the federal government has not toughened its regulations or its audits of banks. What it has done, he said, is reacted to changes in the economy and in the process has uncovered bad loans at many institutions. ``We're trying to make sure you have a safe and sound banking system, and at the same time not choke off the availability of credit,'' he said. Clarke conceded that a wave of examination of real estate-related bank credit have made it tougher get a loan. Although examiners ordered many of the Northeast's largest banks to increase their reserves to cover potentially bad loans, regulators did not advise against continuing to lend money, he said. ``I'm concerned about the misconceptions and misperceptions about what bank supervisors and the (Office of the Comptroller of the Currency) are doing,'' he said. ``There is no doubt confusion in the minds of bankers about what we're doing.'' The comptroller is focusing much of his attention on New England, where some business leaders say a regional economic slowdown is being compounded by their inability to get loans. Small businesses especially feel they are the victims of stricter bank lending policies, said James Hagan, president of the Greater Providence Chamber of Commerce. ``They are experiencing a great deal (more) of difficulty in gaining access to capital than they were a year or two ago,'' Hagan said. Walter McLaughlin, president of McLaughlin Automotive Stores in Providence, said although he had repaid his loans more quickly than required he was being hurt by the credit crunch. ``Now they want to charge me more money,'' he said. McLaughlin said he was especially perturbed because he anticipated the economic slowdown and cut back more than two years ago. ``Why wasn't the OCC advising bankers to do the same thing?'' he asked Clarke. ``If a little guy like me saw it coming, why didn't you?'' Clarke said regulators also saw that the economy _ especially in the robust Northeast _ could not sustain the strong growth of the mid-1980s. ``If anyone suggests that the OCC has just gotten religion ... that's just plain wrong,'' he said. ``We've been on this problem since 1987.'' Nevertheless, politicians are demanding election-year explanations for the regulators' tough examinations. Rep. Claudine Schneider, R-R.I., asked the General Accounting Office on Monday to investigate whether federal regulators deliberately are trying to stifle lending. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., whom Ms. Schneider is challenging in the fall election, told a meeting of the Rhode Island Bankers Association on Monday that Clarke ``needs to be made more aware of what is happening in Rhode Island and the rest of New England ... .'' Clarke said he was familiar with the situation but said lending changes likely were just a reflection of the slowing economy. ``There is understandably a constriction in the amount of credit and there understandably is a tightening of the terms and conditions on that credit,'' he said. But in the long run, he added, that should be good because in many cases, those terms and conditions ``were pretty loose.''

DOC.HEAD: FDA Issues Alert on Some Models of Baby Monitors
DOC.TEXT: Some models of a device designed to warn parents that an infant has stopped breathing may not work, the Food and Drug Administration said Monday. The device, also used to monitor adults who suffer apnea, is manufactured by Electronic Monitors Inc. of Euless, Texas, the FDA said. Those who suffer from apnea temporarily stop breathing during sleep. The models involved are RE-134B and Mon-A-Therm Respirate, for those older than 4 years old, and Models RE-134C and RE-134D for infants. ``Some models may fail to signal an alarm,'' the FDA said in issuing a first-class alert, its most serious health warning. The problem, the agency said, is with a defective time delay switch. FDA said the company was recalling the 1,583 monitors it distributed. Sixty percent went to hospitals and the rest were sent to home health care agencies that rent or distribute them to the public. The FDA said it did not know how many monitors were still being used by consumers.

DOC.HEAD: New Vehicle Locator Device Announced
DOC.TEXT: Code-Alarm Inc. on Monday announced a new stolen-vehicle locator system to compete against a system made by LoJack Corp. Code-Alarm's system, called Intercept, works with traditional anti-theft equipment, such as an audible alarm and an ignition cutoff switch. If a thief gets around the primary system, a cellular phone transmits the map coordinates of a stolen car. The system will retail for $1,495 including a cellular phone, with a monthly monitoring fee of $19.95. Without the phone, the system would cost $995. ``Unlike other trackers, Intercept does not need to have additional devices put in police cars,'' said Code-Alarm spokeswoman Suzanne Berschback, who said the product would be test marketed in Detroit before being introduced in other cities with high rates of auto theft. A company monitoring station tracks vehicles, and employees relay information to law enforcement agencies by telephone. A remote engine shutoff system can be used to disable a stolen car. LoJack, marketed by the Needham, Mass., company, costs $595 to install and uses devices in police cruisers to locate a stolen car.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Ministers Agree South African Sanctions Could Be Gradually Eased
DOC.TEXT: Foreign ministers of the European Community agreed Monday some economic sanctions against South Africa could be lifted before the government abolishes entirely its racial policy of apartheid. But the ministers of the 12-nation trading bloc did not announce the immediate easing of any bans imposed against the white-led government. ``There was not a majority in favor of the lifting of the sanctions,'' said Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins, whose government has opposed any change in the measures. Ireland currently holds the rotating presidency of the trading bloc. But he said the ministers did agree ``that something very important is happening in South Africa.'' In an effort to pressure the government to end its policy of racial segregation, the community decided in 1986 to halt imports of South African iron, steel and gold coins and to ban new investment in that country. It had previously prohibited the sales of military equipment. Britain has been pressing the community to ease the sanctions because of recent reform measures by South African President F.W. de Klerk. In February, Britain unilaterally lifted the ban on new investment. Black leader Nelson Mandela has urged the community to continue pressuring de Klerk's government. Douglas Hurd, Britain's foreign secretary, said all the community nations now have backed a step-by-step strategy under which the sanctions could be lifted gradually as progress was made on scrapping apartheid. He said the community's view was: ``You do not have to wait for apartheid to end before you begin to relax the pressures on the South African government.'' ``No one argued that the sanctions should remain until the complete dismantlement of apartheid,'' agreed a Dutch source, who demanded anonymity. But Hurd said there was no consensus on when the first step should be taken. Sources say only Ireland and Denmark have argued against any change in the sanctions. Hurd said some countries want to send a signal of encouragement to de Klerk, perhaps by lifting one of the bans next month. He said the ``logical first step'' would be to relax the prohibition on new investment in South Africa. But he said other countries ``were not so clear about that and were not really ready to go that far.'' ``There is a spectrum of opinion on that subject,'' he said. Collins noted that de Klerk had lifted the government's state of emergency in three of South Africa's four provinces. The decree had been in effect for four years. He said not all the country's political prisoners have been freed from prison, ``although the prospects seem to be good that they will be.'' The leaders of the trading bloc nations will discuss the issue when they gather next week in Dublin for their summer summit. Community members are Belgium, Britain, West Germany, Ireland, France, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Denmark, Spain, Portugal, Italy and Greece.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets CFTC Regulate New Form of Financial Trading
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday allowed the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to regulate a type of stock market investment called an index participation. The court, without comment, left intact an appeals court ruling that gives the CFTC, rather than the Securities and Exchange Commission, such regulatory power. An index participation is a contract of indefinite duration based on the value of a group of securities. The contract resembles a basket of stocks because its value is tied to a broad stock-market index, such as the Standard & Poor's 500 index. The appeals court held that such products come under the CFTC's supervision if they have any element of a futures contract. The SEC generally regulates securities, and the CFTC has jurisdiction over futures contracts. The Chicago-based 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said last year an index participation has elements of both a security and a futures contract. But the appeals court said the CFTC has exclusive jurisdiction over the investment instrument. The appeals court ruling was challenged by the American Stock Exchange, the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and the Options Clearing Corp. The American and The latter organization issues options that are traded on the exchanges. The president of the Philadelphia exchange, Nicholas A. Giordano, called the Supreme Court action ``a major step backward in the regulation and development of innovative new products.'' ``The real loser here is the individual investor for whom index participations were originally designed,'' he said in a statement. ``Lost in the debate over legislative authority on these products was the elemental fact that far fewer brokers are qualified to trade futures than are to trade securities.'' Bob Shabazian, a spokesman for the American Stock Exchange, said the Amex had no comment on the court's action, but added that the exchange supported a bill before Congress that would shift regulation of all stock index futures from the CFTC to the SEC. The Bush administration, which had urged the Supreme Court not to disturb the 7th Circuit court ruling, also supports the bill. But the proposal has received a cool reception on Capitol Hill, where some critics say the proposal could hinder passage of other measures designed to give the SEC more power to curb Wall Street volatility. The plan to reduce the CFTC's power was prompted by rulings by the 7th Circuit and other courts that give the CFTC exclusive regulatory authority over any financial product with even the slightest aspect of a futures contract. SEC and Treasury Department officials have complained those rulings have led to long legal battles over jurisdiction while innovative financial products are being developed or copied in overseas markets. Index participations, for example, are available only on the Toronto Stock Exchange and not on any U.S. exchange. The cases are Investment Company Institute vs. SEC, 89-1484; American Stock Exchange vs. Chicago Mercantile Exchange, 89-1502; Philadelphia Stock Exchange vs. Chicago Mercantile Exchange, 89-1503.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Contract UAL Employees Meet With Greenwald
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of UAL Corp.'s non-union employees met Monday with the chief of the union group trying to buy the airline company in hopes of avoiding a setback in the buyout effort. The meeting in Chicago between Gerald Greenwald and leaders of the non-contract group was their second within a week, said Stephen Fraidin, a lawyer for the non-union workers. It followed a stinging statement Sunday by the 26,000 non-contract workers expressing disappointment that the union group had not accepted proposed wage concessions and benefit modifications under which the non-contract workers could support the buyout plan. The unions do not consider the non-union group's support essential to the proposed $4.54 billion deal for the parent of United Airlines. But opposition by the non-contract group, which accounts for more than one-third of UAL's 71,500 employees, could complicate the unions' attempts to raise financing. The buyout group's contract to buy UAL will lapse if financing is not obtained by Aug. 10. If financing is secured, the group would have until the end of the year to close the deal. ``We continue to be hopeful that an agreement can be reached,'' Fraidin said in a telephone interview. Greenwald, formerly vice chairman of Chrysler Corp., agreed earlier this month to head the buyout group composed of United's pilots, flight attendants and Machinists unions. If they are successful, Greenwald would become chairman and chief executive of UAL, which is based near Chicago in Elk Grove Village. The non-contract employees said in a news release Sunday they had developed a package of wage concessions, benefit modifications and governance agreements during discussions with the United Employee Acquisition Corp. _ the entity formed by the unions to handle the proposed buyout. But the acquisition firm has not agreed to the package, a news release from System Roundtable said. System Roundtable is an organization of representatives from the different groups of non-contract employees. It effectively has become the non-contract employees' bargaining agent in the buyout plan. ``If this package is not agreed to very shortly by UEAC, it does not bode well for UEAC's ability to make the business judgments that it will certainly face in trying to finance the proposed leveraged buyout, and, if that transaction is completed, in running the airline,'' the release said. Among other things, the non-contract workers are looking for improved pensions and assurance that the agreement with the unions would be binding and not subject to change by a new UAL managment. The non-contract group includes reservations and ticket agents, professional and technical staffers, and management and supervisors excluding Chairman Stephen Wolf and other top officers.

DOC.HEAD: Company Enlarges Mortgage Service Portfolio
DOC.TEXT: NCNB Corp. plans to purchase a mortgage servicing portfolio that will triple the size of NCNB Mortgage Corp., making it one of the 15 largest mortgage companies in the country, company officials announced Monday. The expanded portfolio and the accompanying loan servicing facility, located in Louisville, Ky., position the Charlotte, N.C.-based NCNB to be a nationwide competitor in both mortgage lending and mortgage servicing, company officials said. NCNB said it plans to purchase mortgage servicing agreements of Fundamental Mortgage Corp. of Dallas and its 300-employee facility in Kentucky. NCNB Mortgage manages $4.8 billion in mortgage servicing. It has loan servicing centers in Charlotte and Lubbock, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Quick Test For HIV Antibody
DOC.TEXT: Bio-Rad Laboratories said the Food and Drug Admnistration has approved a test that confirms HIV-positive results and works nearly five times faster than any similar testing technique for the AIDS virus. Approval means the test can be used at blood banks and laboratories around the country, said Bio-Rad Treasurer Jim Viglienzone, who estimated the worldwide market for such tests at $18 million a year. Viglienzone said the FDA issued the approval Friday, culminating some five years of research. Bio-Rad is an international manufacturer and distributor of biologiocal research poducts, clinical diagnostics and analytical instruments.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Loan Talks Continue; Snags Reportedly Jeopardize Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, Meanwhile, the... to CORRECT bond payment amount to about $43 million sted $31 million. Picks up 4th graf, Trump also...
DOC.TEXT: An agreement among several major banks to loan $60 million to developer Donald Trump was in limbo Monday as the institutions, once close to a deal, continued haggling over its terms. The deal, aimed at helping the developer continue making payments to bankers while his $3 billion in bank and bond debts are restructured, was nearing completion late last week. But over the weekend, the deal fell into disarray as several banks jockeyed for a better position and no agreement could be reached. Meanwhile, the clock ticked away on the grace period for a roughly $43 million junk bond payment Trump missed on Friday. The payment was due on bonds used to finance the purchase of Trump's Castle, one of the developer's three Atlantic City hotel-casinos. Trump also did not make a $30 million payment due Manufacturers Hanover Corp. A Trump spokesman, Dan Klores, said talks among the banks and the Trump Organization continued Monday, but he refused to comment further and would not say whether the parties were close to a new agreement. Klores also refused to discuss any plans by Trump to make the missed payment. Spokesmen for the major banks _ Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover, Chase Manhattan Corp. and Bankers Trust Co. _ either refused to comment on the talks or did not return a reporter's repeated phone calls Monday. But investors, who have bid down the price of the Trump casino bonds on the news about his financial problems, did not appear unnerved by the latest development. Traders reported the bonds were little changed in extremely light volume Monday. The Trump Castle bonds were trading at about $56 per $100 face amount, down about $2 from Friday, in late afternoon transactions. The debt restructuring plan was aimed at helping Trump to keep making his debt payments while waiting for his assets to rise in value so some eventually could be sold. Trump's assets, which include hotels and office and apartment buildings in New York, have fallen in value due to the slumping real estate and casino markets. The casinos have been affected by the slowing Atlantic City resort market. The developer also owns the Trump shuttle, the Northeastern air service bought last year from Eastern Airlines. The New York Times, quoting unnamed sources, said negotiations fell apart over the weekend when the big lenders argued over the proposed terms of the loan package reached earlier this month. At the center of the dispute is how much each bank should contribute and the collateral to be used, the newspaper said. Banking sources familiar with the talks said last week the four major banks agreed to provide an additional $60 million in loans and to temporarily suspend interest payments. The sources had said Citicorp and Bankers Trust would provide about two-thirds of the new loan. The negotiations also have raised speculation that bankers want more authority over operation of Trump's properties. The Wall Street Journal reported Monday that the banks have been demanding Trump appoint two top executives _ a chief executive officer and a chief financial officer _ to control the daily operations of the Trump Organization. Although the payment missed on the Trump Castle bonds placed the developer in technical default, he had a 10-day grace period that started Friday during which he can still come up with the money. If Trump is unable to make the payment, bondholders could claim the property or Trump Castle could be forced into bankruptcy, said Michael Mulvaney, an analyst with Moody's Investors Service. However, he said, it was more likely that further negotiations would be held before the situation became that extreme. If Trump went into full default, he could run afoul of New Jersey gaming regulators and could lose his licenses to operate the casinos, which also include Trump Plaza and the Taj Mahal.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rally, Ending Three-Day Slide
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures rallied Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade, ending a three-day slide amid buying prompted in part by concerns about flood damage to corn and soybean crops. On other commodity markets, oil futures fell steeply; pork bellies extended their recent sharp losses while livestock futures were mixed; orange juice futures plunged again; copper futures rose; and precious metals were mixed. Wheat futures settled 2{ cents lower to 2 cents higher in Chicago with the contract for delivery in July at $3.30 a bushel; corn was 3{ cents to 6\ cents higher with July at $2.86{ a bushel; oats were 2} cents to 3} cents higher with July at $1.42\ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 11} cents higher with July at $5.96 a bushel. Most of the buying in the corn and soybean markets represented profit-taking by traders who sold contracts last week, establishing ``short positions,'' and bought them back Monday at lower prices, analysts said. Further buying after the mostly lower opening was prompted by reports that heavy weekend rains damaged newly planted corn and soybeans in low-lying areas of central Iowa, central Illinois and southern Ohio. Wheat futures were supported by reports that China was bidding for 500,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices under a previously announced Agriculture Department offer. But Gerald Zusel, manager of floor operations at the exchange for Balfour Maclaine Corp., dismissed the prospective sale of wheat to China as ``expected business, no big deal.'' After the close, the Agriculture Department released its weekly crop-condition reports. The USDA said corn planting was 97 percent complete as of Sunday compared with the five-year average of 99 percent for that date. Soybean planting was 79 percent finished compared with the average of 88 percent. The USDA said 18 percent of the winter wheat crop was harvested as of Sunday, compared with the average of 20 percent. The USDA rated 78 percent of the crop fair to good with 15 percent rated in excellent condition. Crude oil futures dropped below $16 a barrel for the first time since December 1988 on the New York Mercantile Exchange after OPEC President Sadek Boussena warned the cartel that oil prices will collapse if the organization's members do not adhere to their self-imposed production limits. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 25 cents to 68 cents lower with July at $15.94 a barrel; heating oil was .63 cent lower to .11 cent higher with July at 47.86 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .75 cent lower to .15 cent higher with July at 61.56 cents a gallon. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, pork-belly futures for near-term delivery tumbled the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound for the third straight day. Hog futures settled mixed after falling sharply in the two previous sessions; cattle futures advanced. The recent drop in pork futures reflects a pronounced decline in demand for pork products among retailers, whose pork profit margins were eroded by last month's near-record-high hog prices, said Charles Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Cattle futures rose amid expectations that Tuesday's monthly cattle-on-feed report will show light placements and aggressive marketings of cattle onto feedlots during May, Levitt said. Live cattle futures settled .12 cent to .48 cent higher with June at 76.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent to .72 cent higher with August at 85.37 cents a pound; hogs were .47 cent lower to .25 cent higher with June at 61.27 cents a pound; frozen pork beelies were 2 cents lower to .65 cent higher with July at 64.45 cents a pound. Orange juice futures plummeted for the second consecutive day on the New York Cotton Exchange with all contracts except nearby July down the 5-cent daily limit. Analysts said the market was adjusting to Friday's plunge of more than 10 cents a pound in the limitless July contract, which collapsed amid unconfirmed rumors of price cuts by Brazilian orange-juice producers. Orange juice settled 3.2 cents to 5 cents lower with July at $1.763 a pound. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled 20 cents to 30 cents lower with June at $349.30 a troy ounce; silver was 1.2 cents to 2 cents higher with June at $4.825 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: University Playing a Name Game
DOC.TEXT: For just $5 million, you can have the new business building at the University of Iowa named after you. ``Nobody's been asked to give that much,'' said George Daly, dean of the College of Business Administration. ``But somebody will be.'' For $1 million, companies or individuals could put their names on the computer lab or a 400-seat auditorium. For $25,000, the names could go on a study alcove. The Iowa Legislature has approved $25 million for the building, but Daly is looking to raise $8 million to $10 million over the next three years to ensure the college gets the $34 million building it wants. He's also seeking gifts to buy computers, carpet and furniture to go in it. Daly doesn't look at it as selling parts of the building. ``I would say we're asking people to invest in management education at the University of Iowa, to invest in our destiny if you will,'' Daly said. Sales have been brisk for some rooms. ``If you want to support an executive MBA classroom,'' Daly said, ``I'm sorry, but you're too late.''
