DOC.HEAD: Colorado Senator Promoted Silvarado Chairman for Federal Job
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., wrote letters of support for the former chairman of the failed Silverado thrift when the banking executive sought a federal position, according to copies of the documents. In a letter dated Aug. 9, 1984, Wirth called Michael R. Wise ``extremely able,'' and said he would be ``an excellent appointment'' to the Federal Reserve Board Consumer Advisory Council. At the time, Wise was chairman of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. Wirth was then a House member from Colorado, but he was not a member of the House Banking Committee. In 1985, Wise gave Wirth a $750 campaign contribution for a Senate race he won the next year, according to the Federal Election Commission. Wise also gave to Republicans in 1985-1986, including a total of $1,000 to Wirth's 1986 opponent, Ken Kramer. The House Banking Committee is scheduled to hear testimony from Wise Tuesday at its third session investigating Silverado. The collapse of the thrift in December 1988 is expected to cost taxpayers $1 billion. The committee staff said one theme of the hearing will be why regulators didn't act to clean up the thrift until December 1988 even though there were serious problems at the institution in early 1986. Neil Bush, President Bush's son, served three years on the Silverado board of directors. Wirth, who is a member of the Senate Banking Committee, played down the significance of the letter and blamed its release on political backbiting. He said in a statement that the letter was ``one of hundreds of letters that I write each year on behalf of my constituents.'' Wirth added: ``This is the second time in recent months that documents have been leaked to the press with the obvious intent of causing political embarrassment to me.'' Wirth recently co-sponsored legislation to create a separate Justice Department division charged with investigating and prosecuting illegal activity in the savings and loan industry. ``We must send a strong message to those in the financial services industry who violate the law that their actions will be punished,'' he said last week. Both letters Wirth wrote in support of Wise were addressed to Paul Volcker, then chairman of the Board of Directors of the Federal Reserve Board. The letters were obtained by The Associated Press by sources in the House. In one letter, Wirth said Wise was ``not only qualified but his experience with the thrift industry and housing will add valuable perspective to the council's deliberations on consumer and community affairs.'' The other letter was hand-written by Wirth to Volcker. ``He is extremely able and would be an excellent appointment,'' Wirth said of Wise. Wise was not named to the Fed's consumer advisory council, but he was put on the Fed's Thrift Institutions Advisory Council in 1985. He served on the citizens' advisory group for three years, culminating as the president in 1987. The group meets four times a year with the Fed's Board of Governors to discuss developments in the thrift industry.

DOC.HEAD: License Requirements Eased
DOC.TEXT: The Commerce Department said Monday it is dropping the requirements for export licenses on about $30 billion worth of trade in computers, telecommunications equipment and other high technology goods. Undersecretary Dennis Kloske said the liberalized requirements, which will take effect in early July, will eliminate the need for about 20,000 export licenses a year. The new requirements cover products shipped to U.S. allies in the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls. The 17-nation group, known as COCOM, polices high-technology exports in an effort to keep militarily sensitive products from being diverted to communist countries. With the toppling of communist governments throughout Eastern Europe, the United States has been under heavy pressure from its allies to relax export restrictions. ``This new regulation is one of the most significant steps to relax strategic trade controls with our COCOM allies in the post-war era,'' Kloske said. ``It means giving U.S. businesses an even better chance to compete in the international marketplace.'' The department said it will continue to require licenses for shipments of some sensitive high-technology items such as supercomputers. The 20,000 export licenses being eliminated are among 85,000 total export licenses issued each year by the U.S. government. Still, the relaxed requirement, the outcome of three years of negotiations, will bring the U.S. and its allies closer to a ``license-free zone'' within their borders. The announcement Monday will provide for additional streamlining of controls beyond changes that were approved at a COCOM meeting earlier this month in Paris. The Paris meeting dealt with restrictions on the types of products which could be sold to former communist bloc countries in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Now Making 17 737s a Month
DOC.TEXT: Boeing 737 jetliners are now being produced at a rate of 17 a month, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Monday. The company said in a news release that it had met its previously announced goal of increased production for the small twinjet, up from 14 per month earlier this year. Boeing, which has a backlog of 1,750 passenger jets, has been increasing production rates throughout its product line. Production of 747s went from two-and-a-half per month to five a month last year, while 757 production went from five to seven planes a month and 767s went from four to five in early 1990. Boeing plans to produce 382 jetliners, including five 707s for military use, in 1990, up from 284 in 1989. The company was hit by a 48-day machinists' strike last year, which effectively halted production.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell Monday under the combined strength of an oil glut and the approaching end of trading on July contracts. The July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 68 cents to $15.94 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercentile Exchange. Later contract months posted smaller losses. The price of the July contract had fallen 51 cents Friday. ``The expiration of July contracts is putting pressure on the market for nearby delivery,'' said William Byers, an oil market analyst with Bear, Stearns & Co. ``With a great supply of crude, nobody wanted to take delivery right away.'' The deadline for trading on July contracts is Wednesday. The August contract was off 64 cents at $16.95. Home heating oil also dropped, with the July contract falling .51 cent to 47.86 cents a gallon. Subsequent months fell by similar amounts. Heating oil was off 0.13 cent Friday. Among refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, wholesale unleaded gasoline for July delivery rose 0.05 cents a gallon to 61.56 cents. The contract had risen 1.39 cents Friday. Subsequent months were also off. Prices for natural gas were lower, with the July contract down to $1.540 1,000 cubic feet, from $1.547 on Friday. Other contracts were down by similar amounts.

DOC.HEAD: New President Named at Nike
DOC.TEXT: Richard K. Donahue, a Massachusetts lawyer and former aide to President Kennedy, will become Nike Inc.'s president and chief operating officer July 1, the company announced. ``I have worked everywhere from the White House down,'' Donahue said Monday after the announcement. ``This is the only thing that will actually impress my kids.'' Donahue served as a congressional liaison for President Kennedy from 1960 to 1963. He is a partner at Donahue & Donahue in Lowell, Mass., and has been on Nike's board of directors since 1978. He will be Nike's first president. ``As president and chief operating officer, my goal is to shoulder enough responsibility to allow Nike Inc. to continue to move forward as aggressively as we have in the past several years,'' Donahue said. ``Some companies would simply fan the flames of their success. At Nike, we plan to pour gasoline on them. ``Nike is poised to be as universally recognized and respected as Disney or Coca-Cola,'' Donahue said. ``We aspire to the integrity and credibility of those companies. We can get there by maintaining our commitment to authentic athletic products and by building our management base.'' Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Philip Knight, who founded the company with track coach Bill Bowerman in the 1960s, said Nike was appointing a president because of its strong growth. ``In the past year, Nike surpassed Adidas to become the No. 1 sports and fitness brand in the world,'' Knight said. ``The tremendous success we are experiencing has also put pressure on the organization and on me.''

DOC.HEAD: Trade Rep: U.S.-Japan Trade Improving But Has Far To Go
DOC.TEXT: Japan and the United States have a long way to go to improve trade relations, but some U.S. companies are succeeding in the Japanese marketplace, U.S. Trade Representative Carla A. Hills said Monday. ``Japan is not a completely closed society and the United States isn't a collection of uncompetitive failing industries,'' Hills said at the annual dinner of the Japan Society. Hills said U.S. exports to Japan last year were greater than our exports to West Germany, France and Italy combined. Since 1986, she said, Japan has increased its imports from all nations 64 percent. However, she said, ``the problem is that Japan should be doing more. The United States should be doing more.'' ``Our entrepreneurs must be permitted to trade and invest in Japan as freely as Japanese entrepreneurs are able to trade and invest here in the United States,'' she said. ``The American people will not be satisfied until all American businesses can offer their goods and services in Japan in free and open competition.'' She said U.S. companies face obstacles in trying to market products in Japan in the areas of digital computer networks, telecommunications, auto parts, semiconductors and construction. Mrs. Hills noted that a U.S. company, Motorola, two weeks ago beat out seven companies from Japan, the United States and Europe in a contest to set standards for Japan's next generation of digital cellular telephones. Unfortunately, she said, ``Under the rules of the competition, Motorola must publish the design of its winning system and must license other companies in Japan free of charge ... The United States wants assurances that Motorola will be allowed to market its system and win a piece of the digital cellular market in Japan.'' The dinner was given in honor of Japan's influential film maker Akira Kurosawa, who won the 1990 Japan Society Award for increasing appreciation and understanding of Japanese society and culture. The Japan Society is a private, non-profit organization devoted to cultural, educational and public affairs and improving U.S.-Japan relations.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Gold Narrowly Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT that silver rose 1.4 cents in NY sted fell
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most other major currencies Monday, buffeted by technical factors and expectations of lower U.S. interest rates. Gold prices rose modestly overseas, but slipped lower in later U.S trading. The dollar spent most of the day drifting downward in a continued response to last week's U.S. producer and consumer price reports. The data indicated weaker U.S. demand and heightened prospects for interest rate cuts, dealers said. Traders believe the Federal Reserve, which sets the nation's monetary policy, is more likely to nudge interest rates lower to stimulate the economy amid signs of a slowdown. Such a move would be bearish for the dollar, which is more attractive to investors when U.S. rates are higher. Jerry Rothman, a trader with Merrill Lynch Futures, said there was no news to affect the dollar and that investors were testing the U.S. currency to see how far it will go. However, he said, the dollar likely was nearing its lows. ``It's really a technical market right now,'' a dealer in London said. In Tokyo, where the dollar begins its day, the U.S. currency closed at 153.88 yen, down 0.64 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 153.75 yen. It fell to 153.65 yen in New York from 153.90 yen late Friday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.7130 from $1.7060 late Friday. In later New York, trading, the pound rose to $1.7145 from $1.7090. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.6760 West German marks, down from 1.6885; 1.4157 Swiss francs, down from 1.4330; 5.6395 French francs, down from 5.6805; 1,230.00 Italian lire, down from 1,239.00; and 1.17455 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17085. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Friday's late levels were: 1.6770 West German marks, down from 1.6915; 1.4165 Swiss francs, down from 1.4340; 5.6390 French francs, down from 5.6910; 1.8865 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9065; 1,230.00 Italian lire, down from 1,241.00; and 1.1727 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1698. Gold fell 20 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $349.30 a troy ounce. Later, Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid of $348.25, down 25 cents. Gold rose earlier in London to a late bid price of $349.45 a troy ounce, up from $347.50 late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $348.75 an ounce, up from $347.25 late Friday. The gold market in Hong Kong was closed Monday for a holiday. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $4.85 a troy ounce from $4.80 late Friday. The metal also rose on the New York Comex, closing at $4.825 a troy ounce, up 1.4 cents from Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Motorola Reports Judge's Ruling in Chip Dispute as Temporary Setback
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. said a federal judge indicated Monday he would require the company to pull a key computer chip off the market until a lawsuit over the chip's patent is resolved. But Motorola _ engaged in a legal fight over trade secrets with former partner Hitachi Ltd. _ said it would appeal the decision immediately after it is reported by U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton of Midland. In a statement from its Schaumburg, Ill. headquarters, Motorola said such a decision might temporarily halt the sale of its market-leading 68030 microprocessor, which is made in Austin. But Motorola said it expected the decision would be stayed on appeal, and that it is confident it would continue to provide an uninterrupted supply of the microprocessor to customers. Bunton's order was to be released through the federal district clerk's office in Austin, according to his office. But the ruling was unavailable by the time the office closed Monday at 5 p.m., said Deputy U.S. District Clerk Bob Williams. Motorola said Bunton had disclosed his intent to sign the order but had not yet signed it. Tokyo-based Hitachi filed the motion with Bunton to temporarily halt the sale of the Motorola microprocessor. An attorney for Hitachi in Chicago, Jerry Solovy, had no immediate comment. Bunton banned the sale of the chip on March 29 and fined both companies, saying they violated each other's patents. But the prohibition was reversed a day later after Motorola argued that the chip sales ban could devastate outside computer makers that depend on its microprocessors to run their machines. On Monday, Motorola said Bunton indicated he would lift his stay on the injunction, thereby preventing Motorola from selling its microprocessor and Hitachi from selling its own, dubbed the H8-532. Tim Kellogg, spokesman for Motorola, said the company would file its appeal with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit following Bunton's decision. The court is a special appeals court for patents and customs in Washington. ``We are confident that the CAFC will promptly stay the lower court's decision, pending appeal,'' Motorola said in a statement. It added, ``We are dismayed that Judge Bunton made this decision knowing full well that the two parties have been engaged in earnest attempts to settle this matter.''

DOC.HEAD: Namibia Asks to Join IMF
DOC.TEXT: Namibia, newly independent of South Africa, has asked to join the International Monetary Fund, the fund announced Monday. Switzerland, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia also are seeking to join the 152 governments that are now members. The fund lends only to member countries to help with short-term balance of payments difficulties. Membership in the fund is followed by membership in its sister organization, the World Bank, the biggest source of long-term development aid to Third World countries.
